title: Planck 2018 results
abstract: We present cosmological parameter results from the final full-mission Planck measurements of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies, combining information from the temperature and polarization maps and the lensing reconstruction. Compared to the 2015 results, improved measurements of large-scale polarization allow the reionization optical depth to be measured with higher precision, leading to significant gains in the precision of other correlated parameters. Improved modelling of the small-scale polarization leads to more robust constraints on many parameters, with residual modelling uncertainties estimated to affect them only at the 0.5 σ level. We find good consistency with the standard spatially-flat 6-parameter ΛCDM cosmology having a power-law spectrum of adiabatic scalar perturbations (denoted “base ΛCDM” in this paper), from polarization, temperature, and lensing, separately and in combination. A combined analysis gives dark matter density Ω c h 2 = 0.120 ± 0.001, baryon density Ω b h 2 = 0.0224 ± 0.0001, scalar spectral index n s = 0.965 ± 0.004, and optical depth τ = 0.054 ± 0.007 (in this abstract we quote 68% confidence regions on measured parameters and 95% on upper limits). The angular acoustic scale is measured to 0.03% precision, with 100 θ * = 1.0411 ± 0.0003. These results are only weakly dependent on the cosmological model and remain stable, with somewhat increased errors, in many commonly considered extensions. Assuming the base-ΛCDM cosmology, the inferred (model-dependent) late-Universe parameters are: Hubble constant H 0 = (67.4 ± 0.5) km s −1 Mpc −1 ; matter density parameter Ω m = 0.315 ± 0.007; and matter fluctuation amplitude σ 8 = 0.811 ± 0.006. We find no compelling evidence for extensions to the base-ΛCDM model. Combining with baryon acoustic oscillation (BAO) measurements (and considering single-parameter extensions) we constrain the effective extra relativistic degrees of freedom to be N eff = 2.99 ± 0.17, in agreement with the Standard Model prediction N eff = 3.046, and find that the neutrino mass is tightly constrained to ∑ m ν < 0.12 eV. The CMB spectra continue to prefer higher lensing amplitudes than predicted in base ΛCDM at over 2 σ , which pulls some parameters that affect the lensing amplitude away from the ΛCDM model; however, this is not supported by the lensing reconstruction or (in models that also change the background geometry) BAO data. The joint constraint with BAO measurements on spatial curvature is consistent with a flat universe, Ω K = 0.001 ± 0.002. Also combining with Type Ia supernovae (SNe), the dark-energy equation of state parameter is measured to be w 0 = −1.03 ± 0.03, consistent with a cosmological constant. We find no evidence for deviations from a purely power-law primordial spectrum, and combining with data from BAO, BICEP2, and Keck Array data, we place a limit on the tensor-to-scalar ratio r 0.002 < 0.06. Standard big-bang nucleosynthesis predictions for the helium and deuterium abundances for the base-ΛCDM cosmology are in excellent agreement with observations. The Planck base-ΛCDM results are in good agreement with BAO, SNe, and some galaxy lensing observations, but in slight tension with the Dark Energy Survey’s combined-probe results including galaxy clustering (which prefers lower fluctuation amplitudes or matter density parameters), and in significant, 3.6 σ , tension with local measurements of the Hubble constant (which prefer a higher value). Simple model extensions that can partially resolve these tensions are not favoured by the Planck data.
summary:
Science Breakthrough: Cosmic Microwave Background Observation Yields Detailed Insights into Universe's Structure

In an astrophysics study published in Astronomy and Astrophysics, a team of over 20 international researchers have released the final results from Planck's full-mission observations of the cosmic microwave background (CMB). The research has shed light on parameters influencing the structure and evolution of the universe with unprecedented accuracy.

The study focuses on the standard spatially-flat 6-parameter ΛCDM cosmology, and measurements from polarization data allow for a more precise determination of reionization optical depth. With improved modelling, many key parameters have received robust constraints, while residual uncertainties affect them only at the 0.5σ level.

Results include a dark matter density of 0.120 ± 0.001, baryon density of 0.0224 ± 0.0001, scalar spectral index n_s = 0.965 ± 0.004, and optical depth τ = 0.054 ± 0.007. The angular acoustic scale was measured to an exquisite precision of 0.03%. Results show minimal dependence on the cosmological model and remain stable with increased errors in many commonly considered extensions.

The findings also suggest no compelling evidence for extensions beyond the base-ΛCDM model, although they still indicate higher lensing amplitudes than predicted, which could influence some parameters. Combining Planck's results with data from baryon acoustic oscillation (BAO) measurements, Type Ia supernovae (SNe), and other observations, researchers have placed constraints on various parameters like the Hubble constant, dark energy equation of state parameter, neutrino mass, effective extra relativistic degrees of freedom, and tensor-to-scalar ratio.

The study also highlights some interesting tension between Planck's results and certain local measurements and observational data sets such as the Dark Energy Survey’s combined-probe results and local measurements of the Hubble constant. The precise nature of our universe's structure and evolution continues to intrigue scientists and drive further exploration in astrophysics.

title: Broken Symmetries and the Masses of Gauge Bosons
abstract: This article appears in the following collection:Letters from the Past - A PRL Retrospective2008 marked PRL's 50th anniversary. summary:
Headline:
Harnessing the Power of Broken Symmetries: Revisiting Gauge Boson Masses in Physics (1964)

Summary:
In an iconic paper published in 1964, physicist Peter W. Higgs introduced the concept of broken symmetries and their impact on the masses of gauge bosons, a pioneering work that not only announced a significant discovery but also kick-started new research areas in physics. This milestone study, which can be found in Physical Review Letters collection, celebrates 50 years since the journal's inception, highlighting its groundbreaking contribution to our understanding of particle physics.
allAuthors: Peter W. Higgs
institutions: University of Edinburgh

title: Exclusive processes in perturbative quantum chromodynamics
abstract: We present a systematic analysis in perturbative quantum chromodynamics (QCD) of large-momentum-transfer exclusive processes. Predictions are given for the scaling behavior, angular dependence, helicity structure, and normalization of elastic and inelastic form factors and large-angle exclusive scattering amplitudes for hadrons and photons. We prove that these reactions are dominated by quark and gluon subprocesses at short distances, and thus that the dimensional-counting rules for the power-law falloff of these amplitudes with momentum transfer are rigorous predictions of QCD, modulo calculable logarithmic corrections from the behavior of the hadronic wave functions at short distances. These anomalous-dimension corrections are determined by evolution equations for process-independent meson and baryon "distribution amplitudes" $\ensuremath{\varphi}({x}_{i}, Q)$ which control the valence-quark distributions in high-momentum-transfer exclusive reactions. The analysis can be carried out systematically in powers of ${\ensuremath{\alpha}}_{s}({Q}^{2})$, the QCD running coupling constant. Although the calculations are most conveniently carried out using light-cone perturbation theory and the light-cone gauge, we also present a gauge-independent analysis and relate the distribution amplitude to a gauge-invariant Bethe-Salpeter amplitude.
summary:
Physicists G. Peter Lepage and Stanley J. Brodsky present an in-depth study on large-momentum-transfer exclusive processes within perturbative quantum chromodynamics (QCD), published in Physical Review D. This research focuses on elastic and inelastic form factors, and large-angle exclusive scattering amplitudes for hadrons and photons.

The findings highlight that such reactions are primarily driven by quark and gluon subprocesses at short distances, demonstrating the applicability of QCD's scaling behavior and power-law falloff predictions in high luminosity hadronic interactions. The study also reveals dimensionally counting rules for the power-law fall off of these amplitudes, with calculable logarithmic corrections from the behavior of hadronic wave functions at short distances.

The analysis is systematic, carried out using light-cone perturbation theory and light-cone gauge – but also presents a gauge-independent approach. The research centers on the evolution equations for process-independent meson and baryon "distribution amplitudes" that control the valence-quark distributions in high-momentum-transfer exclusive reactions, providing a more comprehensive understanding of perturbative quantum chromodynamics within particle physics.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: G. Peter Lepage; Stanley J. Brodsky

title: The ATLAS Experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider
abstract: The ATLAS detector as installed in its experimental cavern at point 1 at CERN is described in this paper. A brief overview of the expected performance of the detector when the Large Hadron Collider begins operation is also presented.
summary:
Paper Published: Journal of Instrumentation

New Study by Atlas Collaboration Details Atlas Detector Setup for LHC Operations

A team of over 3,000 scientists and researchers have detailed the setup of the Atlas detector, a key device at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in CERN. The study outlines the expected performance of the detector when operational, as the world's most powerful particle collider prepares to begin operations following its recent upgrade. The paper supports further advancements in our understanding of subatomic particles and the fundamental laws of physics.

title: Theory and phenomenology of two-Higgs-doublet models
abstract: AI abstract - This work presents a comprehensive theory and phenomenology of Two-Higgs-Doublet Models, exploring their implications for CP violation and the Higgs boson, with potential applications in scalar physics and beyond. The study offers insights into various aspects of these models, providing a valuable resource for further research in particle physics.
summary:
Article Headline:
New Study Offers Insights on Two-Higgs-Doublet Models, Advancing Research in Particle Physics

Summary:
A team of researchers led by G.C. Branco and P.M. Ferreira has published a groundbreaking study in the journal Physics Reports, titled "Theory and phenomenology of two-Higgs-doublet models." The work delves into the implications of these models on CP violation and the Higgs boson, which is instrumental in understanding scalar physics and beyond. This comprehensive review provides insights into various aspects of Two-Higgs-Doublet Models, a crucial resource for future research in the realm of particle physics, particularly focusing on the Higgs boson and phenomena surrounding it.

title: Weak decays beyond leading logarithms
abstract: We review the present status of QCD corrections to weak decays beyond the leading logarithmic approximation including particle-antiparticle mixing and rare and CP violating decays. After presenting the basic formalism for these calculations we discuss in detail the effective hamiltonians for all decays for which the next-to-leading corrections are known. Subsequently, we present the phenomenological implications of these calculations. In particular we update the values of various parameters and we incorporate new information on m_t in view of the recent top quark discovery. One of the central issues in our review are the theoretical uncertainties related to renormalization scale ambiguities which are substantially reduced by including next-to-leading order corrections. The impact of this theoretical improvement on the determination of the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa matrix is then illustrated in various cases.
summary:
Physics Review Discusses Advances in Quantum Chromodynamics Corrections to Weak Decays

In a new review published in Reviews of Modern Physics, researchers Gerhard Buchalla, Andrzej J. Buras, and Markus E. Lautenbacher delve into the intricacies of QCD corrections to weak decays past leading logarithmic approximation, including particle-antiparticle mixing and rare, CP-violating decay processes.

By exploring effective hamiltonians for these decays that have next-to-leading order corrections known, the authors provide a comprehensive update on parameters associated with various phenomenological implications of these calculations. Additionally, they include recent information about the top quark discovery and its impact on values of multiple parameters.

The work focuses on reducing theoretical uncertainties related to renormalization scale ambiguities by incorporating next-to-leading order corrections, and showcases the impact this improvement has on the determination of the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa matrix in several scenarios.

title: Parton distributions for the LHC run II
abstract: AI abstract - We present parton distributions for the Large Hadron Collider run II, extending previous studies conducted at HERA. This work contributes to a better understanding of the structure of protons and their role in high-energy collisions during LHC experiments.
summary:
New Study Unveils Parton Distributions for LHC Run II

Physicists have unveiled parton distributions crucial for the Large Hadron Collider's latest run, extending preliminary studies conducted at HERA. This groundbreaking research enhances our understanding of proton structure and its role in high-energy collisions during the LHC experiments, opening new avenues in particle physics exploration.

The study has been published in Journal of High Energy Physics by an international team led by R.D. Ball, J.I. Latorre, J. Rojo, and others. By analyzing proton's internal components at higher energies relevant to the LHC, this work aims to advance our knowledge about protons and pave way for a more detailed understanding of high-energy physics phenomena.

title: On anomalous electroweak baryon-number non-conservation in the early universe
abstract: AI abstract - We investigate the anomalous electroweak baryon-number non-conservation in the early universe and propose a theoretical model based on the interactions of particles during this period, as suggested by Kuzmin, Rubakov, and Shaposhnikov in their 1985 Physics Letters B publication. This work offers insights into the origin of baryon asymmetry in the universe.
summary:
"Physicists Propose New Model on Baryon Asymmetry Origins

In a new paper published in Physics Letters B, V.A. Kuzmin, V. A. Rubakov, and Mikhail Shaposhnikov delve into anomalous electroweak baryon-number non-conservation in the early universe – a key concept in particle physics. Leveraging their 1985 work, they propose an updated theoretical model that sheds light on the intriguing question of baryon asymmetry's origin in the cosmos."

abstract: AI abstract - This paper presents HERWIG 6, an event generator for hadron emission reactions involving interfering gluons and supersymmetric processes. The new version includes improvements in parton shower dynamics, enhancing its applicability in high-energy particle physics experiments.

Physics Paper Introduces Advanced Event Generator for High-Energy Particle Collisions

Researchers have unveiled anew event generator called HERWIG 6, designed to handle hadron emission reactions with interfering gluons and supersymmetric processes. The latest version introduces improvements in parton shower dynamics, making it more applicable for high-energy particle physics experiments, potentially advancing our understanding of particle collisions involving gluons.

title: Averages of b-hadron, c-hadron, and $$\tau $$ τ -lepton properties as of summer 2016
abstract: This article reports world averages of measurements of b-hadron, c-hadron, and $\\tau $ -lepton properties obtained by the Heavy Flavor Averaging Group using results available through summer 2016. For the averaging, common input parameters used in the various analyses are adjusted (rescaled) to common values, and known correlations are taken into account. The averages include branching fractions, lifetimes, neutral meson mixing parameters, $C\\!P$ violation parameters, parameters of semileptonic decays, and Cabbibo–Kobayashi–Maskawa matrix elements.
summary:
**Physicists unveil latest findings on subatomic particles**

A multinational team of researchers has published new data on the properties of b-hadrons, c-hadrons, and tau leptons, shedding light on the behaviour of these fundamental particles. The study, led by Y. Amhis and colleagues, appears in 'The European Physical Journal C'.

Drawing from various analyses up until summer 2016, the team adjusted common input parameters to create harmonized averages for branching fractions, lifetimes, mixing parameters, CP violation parameters, semileptonic decay parameters, and Cabbibo–Kobayashi–Maskawa matrix elements. This work builds upon previous research in particle physics and nuclear physics, advancing our understanding of the intricate world of hadrons and leptons to further probe the mysteries of the universe.

title: Remarks on the Unified Model of Elementary Particles
abstract: A particle mixture theory of neutrino is proposed assuming the existence of two kinds of neutrinos. Based on the neutrino-mixture theory, a possible unified model of elementary particles is constructed by generalizing the Sakata-Nagoya model. Our scheme gives a natural explanation of smallness of leptonic decay rate of hyperons as well as the subtle difference of Gν's between µ-e and β-decay.
summary:
New Particle Theory Suggests Unified View of Elementary Particles

In a new study published in Progress of Theoretical Physics, physicists Ziro Maki, M. Nakagawa, and Shoichi Sakata propose a novel particle mixture theory for neutrinos. This theory, which assumes the existence of two types of neutrinos, could potentially lead to a unified model of all elementary particles by expanding on the Sakata-Nagoya model. The researchers' scheme offers a natural explanation for the small leptonic decay rate of hyperons and the subtle difference between electron neutrino interaction rates in muon and beta decays.
allAuthors: Ziro Maki; M. Nakagawa; Shoichi Sakata
institutions: Nagoya University

title: 50 Years of quantum chromodynamics
abstract: AI abstract - This work provides a comprehensive review of the past 50 years of research in quantum chromodynamics, focusing on significant advancements and current challenges in understanding the fundamental interactions of quarks and gluons within this theory. The paper highlights key contributions from leading experts in the field, offering insights into the development and future directions of particle physics and nuclear matter studies.
summary:
**Fifty Years of Quantum Chromodynamics: A Comprehensive Review**

*In a significant milestone, over 60 top physicists have collaborated to review half a century of groundbreaking research in Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the theory that outlines the fundamental interactions between quarks and gluons.*

*The review article, published in The European Physical Journal C, focuses on major advancements, as well as current challenges, in understanding these intricate subatomic particles. Leading experts in the field share their insights and provide valuable perspectives on the evolution of particle physics and its implications for nuclear matter studies.*

*The collaboration also offers a glimpse into the future of QCD research, setting new directions and potential discoveries for the ongoing exploration of quarks and gluons within this critical scientific discipline.*

title: Symmetry Breaking through Bell-Jackiw Anomalies
abstract: In models of fermions coupled to gauge fields certain current-conservation laws are violated by Bell-Jackiw anomalies. In perturbation theory the total charge corresponding to such currents seems to be still conserved, but here it is shown that nonperturbative effects can give rise to interactions that violate the charge conservation. One consequence is baryon and lepton number nonconservation in $V\ensuremath{-}A$ gauge theories with charm. Another is the nonvanishing mass squared of the $\ensuremath{\eta}$.
summary:
Title: Groundbreaking Research on Fermion Interactions Challenges Conservation Laws

Physicist Gerard 't Hooft's ground-breaking research in Physical Review Letters explores the violations of certain current-conservation laws within models of fermions coupled to gauge fields. These violations, known as Bell-Jackiw anomalies, often remain conserved only at a perturbative level. However, Hooft's work reveals that nonperturbative effects can lead to interactions that break the charge conservation. This finding could ultimately result in baryon and lepton number nonconservation within certain $V\ensuremath{-}A$ gauge theories with charm, and the non-vanishing mass squared of the $\ensuremath{\eta}$.
allAuthors: Gerard ’t Hooft
institutions: Harvard University

abstract: AI abstract - We present an exploration into the cosmological implications of the hypothetical particle, axions, in the context of particle physics and cosmology. **New Study Probes Cosmic Mysteries with Axion Particles**

Physicists John Preskill, Mark B. Wise, and Frank Wilczek delve into the cosmological significance of axions - hypothetical particles yet to be discovered - in a new paper published in Physics Letters B. The study investigates how these elusive entities could play a role in the large-scale structure of the universe, potentially influencing astrophysical phenomena. By exploring this unexplored terrain at the intersection of particle physics and cosmology, the researchers aim to shed light on some of the universe's most enduring mysteries.

title: Herwig++ physics and manual
abstract:
In this paper we describe 
$\mathsf{Herwig++}$ 
version 2.2, a general-purpose Monte Carlo event generator for the simulation of hard lepton-lepton and hadron-hadron collisions. A number of important hard scattering processes are available, together with an interface via the Les Houches Accord to specialized matrix element generators for additional processes. The simulation of Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) physics includes a range of models and allows new models to be added by encoding the Feynman rules of the model. The parton-shower approach is used to simulate initial- and final-state QCD radiation, including colour coherence effects, with special emphasis on the correct description of radiation from heavy particles. The underlying event is simulated using an eikonal multiple parton-parton scattering model. The formation of hadrons from the quarks and gluons produced in the parton shower is described using the cluster hadronization model. Hadron decays are simulated using matrix elements, where possible including spin correlations and off-shell effects.
summary:
New physics simulation tool unveiled: Scientists present version 2.2 of Herwig++, a comprehensive event generator for hard lepton and hadron collisions

In the latest edition of The European Physical Journal C, a team of researchers have introduced an updated version (2.2) of the general-purpose Monte Carlo event generator, Herwig++. This tool is used to simulate hard scattering processes in various particle collisions, including those beyond the Standard Model (BSM).

The new version includes enhancements that allow for a more accurate description of radiation from heavy particles and the formation of hadrons using advanced models like the cluster hadronization model. herwig++ also supports additional processes through an interface via the Les Houches Accord with specialized matrix element generators. Overall, this work contributes to advancing our understanding of particle physics beyond the Standard Model by providing an essential tool for simulations in high-energy collisions.

title: High-energy-physics event generation with PYTHIA 5.7 and JETSET 7.4
abstract: AI abstract - This work presents the implementation of high-energy physics event generation using PYTHIA 5.7 and JETSET 7.4. The study focuses on the application of Monte Carlo methods to explore physics beyond the Standard Model, particularly in the context of parton collisions.

Title: Breakthrough in Particle Physics Research: New Tool for Exploring Beyond the Standard Model

In a groundbreaking development, physicist Torbjörn Sjöstrand introduces a new tool for high-energy physics event generation using PYTHIA 5.7 and JETSET 7.4 in a paper published by Computer Physics Communications. The research applies the Monte Carlo method to delve into physics beyond the Standard Model, focusing specifically on parton collisions. allAuthors: Torbjörn Sjöstrand
institutions: European Organization for Nuclear Research

title: Radiative Corrections as the Origin of Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
abstract: We investigate the possibility that radiative corrections may produce spontaneous symmetry breakdown in theories for which the semiclassical (tree) approximation does not indicate such breakdown. The simplest model in which this phenomenon occurs is the electrodynamics of massless scalar mesons. We find (for small coupling constants) that this theory more closely resembles the theory with an imaginary mass (the Abelian Higgs model) than one with a positive mass; spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs, and the theory becomes a theory of a massive vector meson and a massive scalar meson. The scalar-to-vector mass ratio is computable as a power series in $e$, the electromagnetic coupling constant. We find, to lowest order, $\frac{{m}^{2}(S)}{{m}^{2}(V)}=(\frac{3}{2\ensuremath{\pi}})(\frac{{e}^{2}}{4\ensuremath{\pi}})$. We extend our analysis to non-Abelian gauge theories, and find qualitatively similar results. Our methods are also applicable to theories in which the tree approximation indicates the occurrence of spontaneous symmetry breakdown, but does not give complete information about its character. (This typically occurs when the scalar-meson part of the Lagrangian admits a greater symmetry group than the total Lagrangian.) We indicate how to use our methods in these cases.
summary:
Headline: New Physics Study Suggests Radiative Corrections May Trigger Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking

Summary:
In a groundbreaking paper published by "Physical Review D," physicists Sidney Coleman and Erick J. Weinberg explore the possibility that radiative corrections could lead to spontaneous symmetry breaking in certain theories where this phenomenon is not indicated by traditional methods. The authors showcase this concept through the study of electrodynamics with massless scalar mesons, discovering that under small coupling constants, this theory behaves more like an imaginary-mass Abelian Higgs model rather than a positive-mass one. Spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs, and the theory transforms into a system of a massive vector meson and a massive scalar meson. The authors also provide calculations for the scalar-to-vector mass ratio using the electromagnetic coupling constant, finding preliminary results that will be refined in future research. The findings extend to non-Abelian gauge theories and offer potential applications for theories where traditional methods do not fully capture characteristics of spontaneous symmetry breaking.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Sidney Coleman; Erick J. Weinberg
institutions: Harvard University

title: A simple solution to the strong CP problem with a harmless axion
abstract: AI abstract - A proposed solution to the strong CP problem is presented, utilizing a hypothetical particle known as an axion. This simple approach offers a potential resolution while minimizing potential harmful effects.
summary:

title: A facility to search for hidden particles at the CERN SPS: the SHiP physics case
abstract: This paper describes the physics case for a new fixed target facility at CERN SPS. The SHiP (search for hidden particles) experiment is intended to hunt for new physics in the largely unexplored domain of very weakly interacting particles with masses below the Fermi scale, inaccessible to the LHC experiments, and to study tau neutrino physics. The same proton beam setup can be used later to look for decays of tau-leptons with lepton flavour number non-conservation, [Formula: see text] and to search for weakly-interacting sub-GeV dark matter candidates. We discuss the evidence for physics beyond the standard model and describe interactions between new particles and four different portals-scalars, vectors, fermions or axion-like particles. We discuss motivations for different models, manifesting themselves via these interactions, and how they can be probed with the SHiP experiment and present several case studies. The prospects to search for relatively light SUSY and composite particles at SHiP are also discussed. We demonstrate that the SHiP experiment has a unique potential to discover new physics and can directly probe a number of solutions of beyond the standard model puzzles, such as neutrino masses, baryon asymmetry of the Universe, dark matter, and inflation.
summary:
"New paper presents case for exploring hidden particles at CERN's SPS

A collaboration of over 100 physicists have published a paper outlining the physics case for a new experiment at the CERN SPS, dubbed SHiP (Search for Hidden Particles). The ambitious project aims to hunt for new particles with masses below the Fermi scale, which are inaccessible to experiments at the Large Hadron Collider.

The SHiP experiment not only seeks to discover these elusive particles but also aims to study tau neutrino physics and investigate decays of tau-leptons with lepton flavor number non-conservation, providing valuable insight into potential physics beyond the Standard Model. The paper discusses various models and their manifestations through interactions with scalars, vectors, fermions, or axion-like particles, offering a unique opportunity to probe several longstanding mysteries in physics such as neutrino masses, dark matter, and baryon asymmetry of the Universe."

title: Weak-Interaction Singlet and Strong<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi>CP</mml:mi></mml:math>Invariance
abstract: Strong $\mathrm{CP}$ invariance is automatically preserved by a spontaneously broken chiral ${\mathrm{U}(1)}_{4}$ symmetry. A weak-interaction singlet heavy quark $Q$, a new scalar meson ${\ensuremath{\sigma}}^{0}$, and a very light axion are predicted. Phenomenological implications are also included.
summary:
"Pioneering Physics Paper Predicts New Quark, Scalar Meson and Axion

Kim proposes a theory that could explain the preservation of strong $\mathrm{CP}$ invariance through a spontaneously broken chiral ${\mathrm{U}(1)}_{4}$ symmetry. The revolutionary theory predicts the existence of a weak-interaction singlet heavy quark, a new scalar meson, and an exceedingly light axion. The study further explores potential real-world implications of these findings."

title: Neutrino masses and mixings in gauge models with spontaneous parity violation
abstract: Unified electroweak gauge theories based on the gauge group $\mathrm{SU}{(2)}_{L}\ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{}\mathrm{SU}{(2)}_{R}\ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{}\mathrm{U}{(1)}_{B\ensuremath{-}L}$, in which the breakdown of parity invariance is spontaneous, lead most naturally to a massive neutrino. Assuming the neutrino to be a Majorana particle, we show that smallness of its mass can be understood as a result of the observed maximality of parity violation in low-energy weak interactions. This result is shown to be independent of the number of generations and unaffected by renormalization effects. Phenomenological consequences of this model at low energies are studied. Observation of neutrinoless double-$\ensuremath{\beta}$ decay will provide a crucial test of this class of models. Implications for rare decays such as $\ensuremath{\mu}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}e\ensuremath{\gamma}$, $\ensuremath{\mu}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}\mathrm{ee}\overline{e}$, etc. are also noted. It is pointed out that in the realm of neutral-current phenomena, departure from the predictions of the standard model for polarized-electron-hadron scattering, forward-backward asymmetry in ${e}^{+}{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}{\ensuremath{\mu}}^{+}{\ensuremath{\mu}}^{\ensuremath{-}}$, and neutrino interactions has a universal character and may be therefore used as a test of the model.
summary:
Article Headline: "New Gauge Models Suggest Potential for Neutrino Mass and Double-beta Decay"

Summary:
In an article published in Physical Review D, renowned physicists Rabindra N. Mohapatra and Goran Senjanović explore a new class of unified electroweak gauge theories. These theories aim to explain the massiveness of neutrinos by suggesting that their smallness stems from the observed maximality of parity violation in low-energy weak interactions. The researchers illustrate how this result is independent of the number of generations and remains unaffected by renormalization effects. They also discuss potential implications for rare decays, such as muon convertibility into electron and photons, and note that observing neutrinoless double-beta decay could serve as a crucial test of these models. Furthermore, they point out unique possibilities for neutral-current phenomena in polarized-electron-hadron scattering, forward-backward asymmetry in positron-electron collisions, and neutrino interactions, which could serve as evidence supporting this novel approach to the electroweak interaction.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Rabindra N. Mohapatra; Goran Senjanović

title: Direct Evidence for Neutrino Flavor Transformation from Neutral-Current Interactions in the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory
abstract: Observations of neutral-current nu interactions on deuterium in the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory are reported. Using the neutral current (NC), elastic scattering, and charged current reactions and assuming the standard 8B shape, the nu(e) component of the 8B solar flux is phis(e) = 1.76(+0.05)(-0.05)(stat)(+0.09)(-0.09)(syst) x 10(6) cm(-2) s(-1) for a kinetic energy threshold of 5 MeV. The non-nu(e) component is phi(mu)(tau) = 3.41(+0.45)(-0.45)(stat)(+0.48)(-0.45)(syst) x 10(6) cm(-2) s(-1), 5.3sigma greater than zero, providing strong evidence for solar nu(e) flavor transformation. The total flux measured with the NC reaction is phi(NC) = 5.09(+0.44)(-0.43)(stat)(+0.46)(-0.43)(syst) x 10(6) cm(-2) s(-1), consistent with solar models.
summary:
**Breakthrough discovery in Physics: Neutrino flavor transformation confirmed in Sudbury Neutrino Observatory**

Scientists have gathered direct evidence for the transformation of neutrino flavors, a phenomenon long predicted by physics theories but never observed before. The findings are based on observations made at the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory (SNO) in Canada, where researchers analyzed neutral-current interactions with deuterium to detect neutrinos from the sun.

The study measured both the electron and non-electron (muon and tau) components of solar neutrinos, providing strong evidence for flavor transformation as the non-electron component was found to be 5.3 standard deviations greater than zero. This discovery could have significant implications in our understanding of stellar evolution and the fundamental nature of matter.

title: Weak Interactions with Lepton-Hadron Symmetry
abstract: We propose a model of weak interactions in which the currents are constructed out of four basic quark fields and interact with a charged massive vector boson. We show, to all orders in perturbation theory, that the leading divergences do not violate any strong-interaction symmetry and the next to the leading divergences respect all observed weak-interaction selection rules. The model features a remarkable symmetry between leptons and quarks. The extension of our model to a complete Yang-Mills theory is discussed.
summary:
Physics paper proposes new model for Weak Interactions, bridging quarks and leptons

Sheldon Glashow, J. Iliopoulos, and Luciano Maiani's groundbreaking paper in the Physical Review has presented a novelmodel of weak interactions, where currents are built from four basic quark fields interacting with a charged massive vector boson. The model preserves strong-interaction symmetry and upholds all observed weak-interaction selection rules, even in higher orders of perturbation theory. Remarkably, the paper showcases a newfound symmetry between leptons and quarks, hinting at possible unification within physics. A discussion on extending this model to a complete Yang-Mills theory is also included.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Final report of the E821 muon anomalous magnetic moment measurement at BNL
abstract: We present the final report from a series of precision measurements of the muon anomalous magnetic moment, a(mu)=(g-2)/2. The details of the experimental method, apparatus, data taking, and analysis are summarized. Data obtained at Brookhaven National Laboratory, using nearly equal samples of positive and negative muons, were used to deduce a(mu)(Expt)=11659208.0(5.4)(3.3)x10(-10), where the statistical and systematic uncertainties are given, respectively. The combined uncertainty of 0.54 ppm represents a 14-fold improvement compared to previous measurements at CERN. The standard model value for a(mu) includes contributions from virtual QED, weak, and hadronic processes. While the QED processes account for most of the anomaly, the largest theoretical uncertainty, approximate to 0.55 ppm, is associated with first-order hadronic vacuum polarization. Present standard model evaluations, based on e(+)e(-) hadronic cross sections, lie 2.2-2.7 standard deviations below the experimental result.
summary: Scientists from around the world publish final results of the E821 experiment at Brookhaven National Laboratory, which measures the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon - a fundamental subatomic particle. The newly determined value, a(mu) = 11659208.0 ± 5.4 (statistical uncertainty) ± 3.3 (systematic uncertainty) x 10-10, represents a significant improvement of 14 times compared to previous measurements at CERN. The discrepancy between the experimental result and the standard model evaluation for a(mu), primarily driven by hadronic vacuum polarization, is over 2 standard deviations, suggesting potential new physics beyond the Standard Model may be needed.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology

title: Constraints imposed by<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi>CP</mml:mi></mml:math>conservation in the presence of pseudoparticles
abstract: We elaborate on an earlier discussion of $\mathrm{CP}$ conservation of strong interactions which includes the effect of pseudoparticles. We discuss what happens in theories of the quantum-chromodynamics type when we include weak and electromagnetic interactions. We find that strong $\mathrm{CP}$ conservation remains a natural symmetry if the full Lagrangian possesses a chiral U(1) invariance. We illustrate our results by considering in detail a recent model of (weak) $\mathrm{CP}$ nonconservation.
summary:
Headline: "Physicists Shed Light on Strong CP Conservation in Quantum Chromodynamics"

Summary: A new paper by R.D. Peccei and Helen R. Quinn, published in Physical Review D, explores the constraints imposed by strong CP conservation in theories of quantum-chromodynamics type. The study delves into how these constraints are influenced by both weak and electromagnetic interactions. Remarkably, the authors find that strong CP conservation can be maintained as a natural symmetry when the full Lagrangian incorporates a chiral U(1) invariance. This research offers valuable insights into a recent model of weak CP nonconservation within particle physics.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: R.D. Peccei; Helen R. Quinn
institutions: Stanford University

title: Estimation of oblique electroweak corrections
abstract: I will first review the experimental limits placed on the oblique correction parameters S and T. Then, I will discuss how the value of S can be estimated for running and walking technicolor theories.
summary:
Science Paper Highlights: New Estimates for Oblique Electroweak Corrections in Particle Physics

A new study published in Physical Review D by Michael E. Peskin and Tatsu Takeuchi seeks to estimate the oblique electroweak corrections, a key aspect of particle physics. The researchers focus on Technicolor theories, an alternative to the commonly accepted concept of electroweak interaction in which particles acquire mass due to spontaneous symmetry breaking. The study provides valuable estimates for S, a significant parameter used to measure these corrections in 'oblique case' scenarios. If further validated, the findings could support theTechnicolor theories, providing a fresh direction in understanding particle physics.

title: Rigorous QCD analysis of inclusive annihilation and production of heavy quarkonium
abstract: A rigorous QCD analysis of the inclusive annihilation decay rates of heavy quarkonium states is presented. The effective-field-theory framework of nonrelativistic QCD is used to separate the short-distance scale of annihilation, which is set by the heavy quark mass M, from the longer-distance scales associated with quarkonium structure. The annihilation decay rates are expressed in terms of nonperturbative matrix elements of 4-fermion operators in nonrelativistic QCD, with coefficients that can be computed using perturbation theory in the coupling constant \\alpha_s(M). The matrix elements are organized into a hierarchy according to their scaling with v, the typical velocity of the heavy quark. An analogous factorization formalism is developed for the production cross sections of heavy quarkonium in processes involving momentum transfers of order M or larger. The factorization formulas are applied to the annihilation decay rates and production cross sections of S-wave states at next-to-leading order in v^2 and P-wave states at leading order in v^2.
summary:
Title: New QCD Analysis Offers Insights into Heavy Quarkonium Annihilation and Production

In a new paper published in Physical Review D, physicists Geoffrey T. Bodwin, Eric Braaten, and G. Peter Lepage have presented a rigorous analysis of the inclusive annihilation decay rates of heavy quarkonium states using Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) theory. The researchers employ an effective-field-theory framework called nonrelativistic QCD to separate short-distance scales related to heavy quark mass from longer-distance ones concerning quarkonium structure.

The focus of this work lies in the broader area of particle physics and the study of quarkonium, a type of bound state consisting of a heavy quark and an antiquark. The authors' analysis provides essential insights into the annihilation processes involving these states and delves into their production cross sections in high-momentum transfer scenarios. Their findings contribute to understanding the complex interplay between short and long distance aspects in the context of heavy quarkonium, paving the way for further investigations on this important topic in physics research.

title: Supercollider physics
abstract: Eichten et al. summarize the motivation for exploring the 1-TeV (=${10}^{12}$ eV) energy scale in elementary particle interactions and explore the capabilities of proton-(anti)proton colliders with beam energies between 1 and 50 TeV. The authors calculate the production rates and characteristics for a number of conventional processes, and discuss their intrinsic physics interest as well as their role as backgrounds to more exotic phenomena. The authors review the theoretical motivation and expected signatures for several new phenomena which may occur on the 1-TeV scale. Their results provide a reference point for the choice of machine parameters and for experiment design.
summary:
Headline: "New Perspectives in Particle Physics Explored as Scientists Eye Higher Energy Collisions"

A team of physicists, led by Eichten, Hinchliffe, Lane, and Quigg, have published a comprehensive review in Reviews of Modern Physics, focusing on the 1-TeV energy scale in elementary particle interactions. This work builds upon the existing research in particle physics, particularly the subfields of nuclear and proton physics. The researchers have studied the capabilities of proton-(anti)proton colliders with energies ranging from 1 to 50 TeV, calculating production rates and characteristics for various conventional processes. These findings not only have inherentphysics interest but also serve as a crucial backdrop for more exotic phenomena. The team also delves into the theoretical motivation and anticipated signs of several new phenomena that may emerge on the 1-TeV scale. Their work offers a valuable reference for deciding machine parameters and designing experiments, potentially paving the way for future discoveries in the realm of high-energy particle physics.

title: Review of particle physics. Particle Data Group
abstract: This biennial Review summarizes much of Particle Physics. Using data from previous editions plus new measurements from papers we list evaluate and average measured properties of gauge bosons leptons quarks mesons and baryons. We also summarize searches for hypothetical particles such as Higgs bosons heavy neutrinos and supersymmetric particles. All the particle properties and search limits are listed in Summary Tables. We also give numerous tables gures formulae and reviews of topics such as the Standard Model particle detectors probability and statistics. Among the reviews are many that are new or heavily revised including those on neutrino mixing CP violation in K D and B mesons Vcb the new exotic  particle extra dimensions grand unified theories cosmic background radiation dark matter cosmological parameters and big bang cosmology. A booklet is available containing the Summary Tables and abbreviated versions of some of the other sections of this full Review. All tables listings and reviews and errata are also available on the Particle Data Group website https://pdg.lbl.gov.
summary:
**Headline:**
"Revised Particle Physics Review offers updated data on gauge bosons, Higgs bosons, and more

**Summary:**
In a comprehensive biennial review published by the esteemed Particle Data Group in arXiv (Cornell University), over 50 renowned physicists provide an update on the properties of various particles within particle physics. The latest measurements for gauge bosons, leptons, quarks, mesons, and baryons have been evaluated and averaged based on previously collected data and new research.

The review also covers searches for hypothetical particles such as Higgs bosons, heavy neutrinos, and supersymmetric particles, listing all relevant properties and search limits in Summary Tables. In addition to these tables, the review features numerous charts, formulas, and reviews of various topics including the Standard Model, particle detectors, probability, statistics, and more.

Some of the updated sections within this meticulous review include a deep dive into neutrino mixing, CP violation in K D and B mesons, Vcb, exotic particles, extra dimensions, grand unified theories, cosmic background radiation, dark matter, cosmological parameters, and big bang cosmology. A booklet containing the Summary Tables and select sections of this extensive review is available at particle data group's website – <https://pdg.lbl.gov>.

title: First Results from KamLAND: Evidence for Reactor Antineutrino Disappearance
abstract: KamLAND has measured the flux of nu;(e)'s from distant nuclear reactors. We find fewer nu;(e) events than expected from standard assumptions about nu;(e) propagation at the 99.95% C.L. In a 162 ton.yr exposure the ratio of the observed inverse beta-decay events to the expected number without nu;(e) disappearance is 0.611+/-0.085(stat)+/-0.041(syst) for nu;(e) energies >3.4 MeV. In the context of two-flavor neutrino oscillations with CPT invariance, all solutions to the solar neutrino problem except for the "large mixing angle" region are excluded.
summary:
New Study Offers Evidence of Reactor Antineutrino Disappearance
-------------------------------------------------------------

In a significant finding that challenges current understanding on neutrinos, a large team of international scientists reported in *Physical Review Letters* that they have discovered fewer antineutrinos emitted from distant nuclear reactors than expected. The researchers, led by K. Eguchi and S. Enomoto among others, conducted the study using KamLAND, an advanced detector designed to measure neutrino waves.

With a 162-ton exposure over time, the research team observed a ratio of antineutrino events that was 38% lower than what's normally expected for energies greater than 3.4 MeV. This unexpected decrease in detected antineutrinos not only contradicts standard assumptions about their propagation but also narrows potential solutions to the solar neutrino problem, particularly ruling out most scenarios except for the popular "large mixing angle" region.

title: Confinement of quarks
abstract: A mechanism for total confinement of quarks, similar to that of Schwinger, is defined which requires the existence of Abelian or non-Abelian gauge fields. It is shown how to quantize a gauge field theory on a discrete lattice in Euclidean space-time, preserving exact gauge invariance and treating the gauge fields as angular variables (which makes a gauge-fixing term unnecessary). The lattice gauge theory has a computable strong-coupling limit; in this limit the binding mechanism applies and there are no free quarks. There is unfortunately no Lorentz (or Euclidean) invariance in the strong-coupling limit. The strong-coupling expansion involves sums over all quark paths and sums over all surfaces (on the lattice) joining quark paths. This structure is reminiscent of relativistic string models of hadrons.
summary:
New Paper Proposes Mechanism for Total Confinement of Quarks in Gauge Field Theory

In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review D, renowned physicist Kenneth G. Wilson offers a novel mechanism to confine quarks similar to that of Schwinger. The study delves into the quantization of gauge field theory on a discrete lattice within Euclidean space-time, preserving exact gauge invariance by treating gauge fields as angular variables, effectively eliminating the need for a gauge-fixing term.

This work builds upon the foundations of Hamiltonian lattice gauge theory and lattice field theory, expanding our understanding of how these theories can be utilized to confine quarks and potentially lead to the development of new models for hadrons. While the strong-coupling limit in this model lacks Lorentz (or Euclidean) invariance, it provides a calculable framework that suggests the absence of free quarks due to the binding mechanism at play. The intricate structure uncovered in the model brings to mind relativistic string models of hadrons.

abstract: AI abstract - This study explores the potential for confinement in nuclear systems to maintain CP invariance within the framework of Quantum Chromodynamics. The authors propose a possible role for pseudoscalars and axions in this context.

Zakharov challenge conventional wisdom by suggesting that confinement within nuclear systems could maintain the natural CP invariance of strong interactions, a concept primarily governed by Quantum Chromodynamics. title: Big Bang Nucleosynthesis (in "The Review of Particle Properties" 2004)
abstract: A critical review is given of the current status of cosmological nucleosynthesis. In the framework of the standard model with 3 types of relativistic neutrinos, the baryon-to-photon ratio, η, corresponding to the inferred primordial abundances of helium-4 and lithium-7 is presently ~2 σbelow the value implied by the abundance of deuterium. The latter value is also coincident with the independent determination of ηfrom WMAP observations of CMB anisotropy. However taking systematic uncertainties in the abundance estimates into account, there is overall concordance in the range η= (3.4 - 6.9) x 10^{-10} @ 95% c.l. corresponding to a cosmological baryon density Ω_B h^2 = 0.012 - 0.025. If the above discrepancy is due to a neutrino chemical potential, then upto 7.1 effective neutrino species are allowed by nucleosynthesis. Other constraints on new physics are briefly discussed.
summary:
Title: A Cosmic Puzzle Unveiled: Big Bang Nucleosynthesis and Neutrinos

Authors Brian D. Fields and Sarkar, in a recent study published in the arXiv (Cornell University), have delved into the realm of cosmic nucleosynthesis – revisiting the formation of elements soon after the Big Bang. The paper focuses on the baffling discrepancy between the inferred primordial abundances of helium-4, lithium-7 and deuterium.

The study suggests that the amount of baryonic matter in the universe, as indicated by deuterium abundance, is not in alignment with the traditional estimates of the baryon-to-photon ratio, η – a difference approximately 2σ below the expected value. However, accounting for systematic uncertainties in abundance estimates across various elements, the data falls within the range η = (3.4 - 6.9) x 10^{-10} with a 95% confidence level. This translates to a cosmological baryon density of Ω_B h^2 = 0.012 – 0.025.

The potential explanation offered by the researchers is a non-zero neutrino chemical potential, which could account for up to 7.1 additional effective neutrino species beyond the standard three. The paper also touches on other avenues of exploring new physics that may shed light on this intriguing astronomical mystery.
allAuthors: Brian D. Fields; S. Sarkar
institutions: Science Oxford

title: Highly relativistic nucleus-nucleus collisions: The central rapidity region
abstract: The space-time evolution of the hadronic matter produced in the central rapidity region in extreme relativistic nucleus-nucleus collisions is described. We find, in agreement with previous studies, that quark-gluon plasma is produced at a temperature \ensuremath{\gtrsim}200-300 MeV, and that it should survive over a time scale \ensuremath{\gtrsim}5 fm/c. Our description relies on the existence of a flat central plateau and on the applicability of hydrodynamics.
summary:
Paper Title: Nuclear Collisions Reveal Evidence of High-Temperature Quark-Gluon Plasma

Physicist James D. Bjorken, in a new study published in Physical Review D's Particles and Fields section, examines the aftermath of high-speed nuclear collisions. The research focuses on the central rapidity region, where the production of a quark-gluon plasma (QGP), a state of matter thought to exist under extreme conditions, is suggested. Bjorken's work confirms earlier findings that QGP is produced at temperatures exceeding 200-300 MeV and persists for over 5 femtoseconds. The study utilizes hydro dynamics and the presence of a flat central plateau to model and describe the space-time evolution of the resulting hadronic matter, contributing significantly to the ongoing investigation in nuclear physics.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Hadronic molecules
abstract:
A large number of experimental discoveries especially in the heavy quarkonium
sector that did not at all fit to the expectations of the until then very
successful quark model led to a renaissance of hadron spectroscopy. Among
various explanations of the internal structure of these excitations, hadronic
molecules, being analogues of light nuclei, play a unique role since for those
predictions can be made with controlled uncertainty. We review experimental
evidences of various candidates of hadronic molecules, and methods of
identifying such structures. Nonrelativistic effective field theories are the
suitable framework for studying hadronic molecules, and are discussed in both
the continuum and finite volumes. Also pertinent lattice QCD results are
presented. Further, we discuss the production mechanisms and decays of hadronic
molecules, and comment on the reliability of certain assertions often made in
the literature.
summary:
Title: "New Perspectives on Hadronic Molecules Shake Up Particle Physics"

Summary: A new research paper published in Reviews of Modern Physics offers fresh insights into a controversial area of physics - hadron molecules. The paper, authored by Feng-Kun Guo and others, discusses a resurgence in hadron spectroscopy following a series of experimental discoveries in the heavy quarkonium sector that contradicted previous models. The study highlights the unique nature of hadronic molecules as they share similarities with light nuclei, allowing for predictions with controlled uncertainty. The research delves into various candidates of hadronic molecules, their identification methods, and the production mechanisms and decays of these unusual particles. The paper also presents non-relativistic effective field theories and relevant lattice QCD results, offering a comprehensive overview of this intriguing field in particle physics.

title: Cosmic separation of phases
abstract: A first-order QCD phase transition that occurred reversibly in the early universe would lead to a surprisingly rich cosmological scenario. Although observable consequences would not necessarily survive, it is at least conceivable that the phase transition would concentrate most of the quark excess in dense, invisible quark nuggets, providing an explanation for the dark matter in terms of QCD effects only. This possibility is viable only if quark matter has energy per baryon less than 938 MeV. Two related issues are considered in appendices: the possibility that neutron stars generate a quark-matter component of cosmic rays, and the possibility that the QCD phase transition may have produced a detectable gravitational signal.
summary:
Physicist Edward Witten proposes an intriguing new theory suggesting that a first-order quantum chromodynamics (QCD) phase transition in the early universe could result in quark nuggets as potential dark matter candidates. The theory, published in Physical Review D, postulates that concentrated quark excess formation would provide an explanation for dark matter without relying on additional particles or physics beyond QCD.
The research explores possibilities that neutron stars might generate a quark-matter component of cosmic rays and that the QCD phase transition could produce a detectable gravitational signal. This work advances our understanding of dense matter within particle physics and offers new directions for investigating dark matter and cosmological phenomena.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Implications of CTEQ global analysis for collider observables
abstract: The latest CTEQ6.6 parton distributions, obtained by global analysis of hard scattering data in the framework of general-mass perturbative QCD, are employed to study theoretical predictions and their uncertainties for significant processes at the Fermilab Tevatron and CERN Large Hadron Collider. The previously observed increase in predicted cross sections for the standard-candle W and Z boson production processes in the general-mass scheme (compared to those in the zero-mass scheme) is further investigated and quantified. A novel method to constrain PDF uncertainties in LHC observables, by effectively exploiting PDF-induced correlations with benchmark standard model cross sections, is presented. Using this method, we show that the top-antitop pair cross section can potentially serve as a standard candle observable for the LHC processes dominated by initial-state gluon scattering. Among other benefits, precise measurements of $t\bar{t}$ cross sections would reduce PDF uncertainties in predictions for single-top quark and Higgs boson production in the standard model and minimal supersymmetric standard model.
summary:
Title: New Analysis Aids in Predicting Collider Observables for Particle Physics

Summary:
A group of scientists, led by Pavel Nadolsky, have published a study in Physical Review D that could pave the way for more precise predictions in particle physics. The researchers used the latest CTEQ6.6 parton distributions to analyze significant processes at both the Fermilab Tevatron and CERN Large Hadron Collider.

The study finds that predicted cross sections for standard-candle W and Z boson production processes increase in a general-mass scheme compared to zero-mass, a trend first observed and investigated further here. The team proposes a novel method to minimize uncertainties in Large Hadron Collider (LHC) observables by leveraging correlations with benchmark Standard Model cross sections.

In their work, they demonstrate that the top-antitop pair cross section could potentially function as a standard candle for LHC processes dominated by initial-state gluon scattering. If confirmed, this could reduce uncertainties in predictions for single-top quark and Higgs boson production in both the Standard Model and Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology

title: CMS Physics Technical Design Report, Volume II: Physics Performance
abstract: CMS is a general purpose experiment, designed to study the physics of pp collisions at 14 TeV at the Large Hadron Collider ( LHC). It currently involves more than 2000 physicists from more than 150 institutes and 37 countries. The LHC will provide extraordinary opportunities for particle physics based on its unprecedented collision energy and luminosity when it begins operation in 2007. The principal aim of this report is to present the strategy of CMS to explore the rich physics programme offered by the LHC. This volume demonstrates the physics capability of the CMS experiment. The prime goals of CMS are to explore physics at the TeV scale and to study the mechanism of electroweak symmetry breaking - through the discovery of the Higgs particle or otherwise. To carry out this task, CMS must be prepared to search for new particles, such as the Higgs boson or supersymmetric partners of the Standard Model particles, from the start- up of the LHC since new physics at the TeV scale may manifest itself with modest data samples of the order of a few fb(-1) or less. The analysis tools that have been developed are applied to study in great detail and with all the methodology of performing an analysis on CMS data specific benchmark processes upon which to gauge the performance of CMS. These processes cover several Higgs boson decay channels, the production and decay of new particles such as Z' and supersymmetric particles, B-s production and processes in heavy ion collisions. The simulation of these benchmark processes includes subtle effects such as possible detector miscalibration and misalignment. Besides these benchmark processes, the physics reach of CMS is studied for a large number of signatures arising in the Standard Model and also in theories beyond the Standard Model for integrated luminosities ranging from 1 fb(-1) to 30 fb(-1). The Standard Model processes include QCD, B-physics, diffraction, detailed studies of the top quark properties, and electroweak physics topics such as the W and Z(0) boson properties. The production and decay of the Higgs particle is studied for many observable decays, and the precision with which the Higgs boson properties can be derived is determined. About ten different supersymmetry benchmark points are analysed using full simulation. The CMS discovery reach is evaluated in the SUSY parameter space covering a large variety of decay signatures. Furthermore, the discovery reach for a plethora of alternative models for new physics is explored, notably extra dimensions, new vector boson high mass states, little Higgs models, technicolour and others. Methods to discriminate between models have been investigated. This report is organized as follows. Chapter 1, the Introduction, describes the context of this document. Chapters 2-6 describe examples of full analyses, with photons, electrons, muons, jets, missing E-T, B-mesons and tau's, and for quarkonia in heavy ion collisions. Chapters 7-15 describe the physics reach for Standard Model processes, Higgs discovery and searches for new physics beyond the Standard Model.
summary:
New Research Reveals Plan for Physics Exploration at Large Hadron Collider

A group of scientists from over 37 countries have outlined a strategy to study high energy particle collisions occurring at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The report, published in Journal of Physics G: Nuclear and Particle Physics, details CMS experiment's plan to delve into physics at TeV scale and investigate electroweak symmetry breaking mechanisms.

The team aims to search for new particles like the Higgs boson or supersymmetry partners from the start of LHC's operation in 2007. They have developed analysis tools to examine benchmark processes covering various decay channels, Z', Higgs boson production and decay, B-physics, heavy ion collisions, and more. These analyses include subtle effects such as possible detector misalignments and miscalibrations.

The study not only focuses on Standard Model processes but also extends to alternative models, including extra dimensions, new vector boson high mass states, and others. Methods for discrimination between these models have been developed as well. This extensive research will offer insights into physics beyond the Standard Model and potentially uncover new particles that may manifest with modest data samples of a few femtobarns or less.
journal: Journal of Physics G Nuclear and Particle Physics

abstract: The Higgs Hunter's Guide is a definitive and comprehensive guide to the physics of Higgs bosons. Dawson, offers an exhaustive exploration into the physics of Higgs bosons beyond the Standard Model.

title: Baryon- and Lepton-Nonconserving Processes
abstract: A number of properties of possible baryon- and lepton-nonconserving processes are shown to follow under very general assumptions. Attention is drawn to the importance of measuring ${\ensuremath{\mu}}^{+}$ polarizations and $\frac{{\overline{\ensuremath{\nu}}}_{e}}{{e}^{+}}$ ratios in nucleon decay as a means of discriminating among specific models.
summary:
Title: Pioneering Study Reveals Insights into Baryon and Lepton Nonconservation

In the esteemed journal Physical Review Letters, physicist Steven Weinberg presents groundbreaking research on baryon- and lepton-nonconserving processes. The study delineates key properties of these phenomena under broad assumptions, emphasizing the significance of measuring muon positron polarizations and anti-neutrino to positive electron ratios in nucleon decay. These measurements could help differentiate between various models within particle physics. This work could potentially pave the way for further advancements in our understanding of fundamental physical processes.

title: Dynamical Model of Elementary Particles Based on an Analogy with Superconductivity. II
abstract: Continuing the program developed in a previous paper, a "superconductive" solution describing the proton-neutron doublet is obtained from a nonlinear spinor field Lagrangian. We find the pions of finite mass as nucleon-antinucleon bound states by introducing a small bare mass into the Lagrangian which otherwise possesses a certain type of the ${\ensuremath{\gamma}}_{5}$ invariance. In addition, heavier mesons and two-nucleon bound states are obtained in the same approximation. On the basis of numerical mass relations, it is suggested that the bare nucleon field is similar to the electron-neutrino field, and further speculations are made concerning the complete description of the baryons and leptons.
summary:
**Physics Breakthrough Suggests Particles Are 'Superconductive': Researchers Y. Nambu and G. Jona-Lasinio**

In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review, researchers have proposed a new model for understanding elementary particles, particularly nucleons (protons and neutrons), by likening them to superconductors. The duo developed this "superconductive" solution from a nonlinear spinor field Lagrangian, which also introduces finite-mass pions as bound states of nucleon-antinucleon pairs.

The model further predicts heavier mesons and two-nucleon bound states within the same approximation. Interestingly, the researchers suggest that the bare nucleon field resembles the electron-neutrino field, implying potential implications for the comprehensive description of baryons and leptons. This work could revolutionize our understanding of particle physics by bridging a gap between superconductivity and subatomic particles.

institutions: University of Chicago

abstract: AI abstract - We investigate the creation of particles by black holes, focusing particularly on their event horizons and the associated thermodynamics, as proposed by Hawking in 1975. This study aims to elucidate the underlying mechanisms governing this phenomenon within the framework of mathematical physics.
summary:
Title: New insights on particle creation by black holes

In a groundbreaking paper published in Communications in Mathematical Physics, renowned physicist Stephen Hawking explores the process of particle creation by black holes, focusing on their event horizons and the associated thermodynamics, first proposed by Hawking in 1975. The study delves into the intricate mechanics governing this phenomenon within the realm of mathematical physics, offering valuable insights to further our understanding of black hole behavior and the interplay between particles and energy.

title: Review of Particle Physics
abstract: Abstract The Review summarizes much of particle physics and cosmology. Using data from previous editions, plus 3,324 new measurements from 878 papers, we list, evaluate, and average measured properties of gauge bosons and the recently discovered Higgs boson, leptons, quarks, mesons, and baryons. We summarize searches for hypothetical particles such as supersymmetric particles, heavy bosons, axions, dark photons, etc. Particle properties and search limits are listed in Summary Tables. We give numerous tables, figures, formulae, and reviews of topics such as Higgs Boson Physics, Supersymmetry, Grand Unified Theories, Neutrino Mixing, Dark Energy, Dark Matter, Cosmology, Particle Detectors, Colliders, Probability and Statistics. Among the 120 reviews are many that are new or heavily revised, including a new review on High Energy Soft QCD and Diffraction and one on the Determination of CKM Angles from B Hadrons. The Review is divided into two volumes. Volume 1 includes the Summary Tables and 98 review articles. Volume 2 consists of the Particle Listings and contains also 22 reviews that address specific aspects of the data presented in the Listings. The complete Review (both volumes) is published online on the website of the Particle Data Group (pdg.lbl.gov) and in a journal. Volume 1 is available in print as the PDG Book. A Particle Physics Booklet with the Summary Tables and essential tables, figures, and equations from selected review articles is available in print and as a web version optimized for use on phones as well as an Android app.
summary: In a new review published in Progress of Theoretical and Experimental Physics, over 100 scientists have compiled a comprehensive summary of the state of particle physics, incorporating 3,324 new measurements from 878 papers. This extensive work covers the properties of gauge bosons, the Higgs boson, leptons, quarks, mesons, and baryons, as well as searches for hypothetical particles like supersymmetric particles and dark photons. The review highlights recent updates on topics such as High Energy Soft QCD and Diffraction, determination of CKM angles from B Hadrons, and provides summaries on topics ranging from the Higgs Boson Physics to Cosmology within two volumes. The completed review is available online and in print, with a condensed version also available for easy reference.
journal: Progress of Theoretical and Experimental Physics
