title: The Nambu—Jona-Lasinio model of quantum chromodynamics
abstract: The Nambu---Jona-Lasinio model is reviewed in its flavor SU(2) and SU(3) versions applied to quarks. The dynamical generation of quark masses is demonstrated as a feature of chiral symmetry breaking. One finds that the associated meson spectra, as well as the meson static properties, can be well described. Current-algebra results, which arise as a consequence of symmetry considerations, automatically hold for this model and are explicitly demonstrated to do so. These include the Goldberger-Treiman and Gell-Mann-Oakes-Renner relations. Effects of finite temperature, finite chemical potential, and strong Maxwell and chromoelectromagnetic fields on the dynamically generated quark mass and the meson spectra are discussed. The alternative procedure of bosonization to obtain an effective Lagrange density in mesonic degrees of freedom, using the derivative expansion, is also presented. The current status in relating the results of this model to that of chiral perturbation theory is critically examined.
summary:
In a new review published in Reviews of Modern Physics, scientist S. P. Klevansky delves into the Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (NJL) model, a critical tool in understanding quantum chromodynamics, particularly its SU(2) and SU(3) applications involving quarks. The paper highlights the model's key feature: dynamically generating quark masses due to chiral symmetry breaking.

The review also demonstrates that the associated meson spectra and static properties can be accurately described within this framework. Crucial results from current algebra, such as the Goldberger-Treiman and Gell-Mann-Oakes-Renner relations, are verified in the NJL model.

Furthermore, Klevansky discusses the impacts of temperature, chemical potential, strong Maxwell and chromoelectromagnetic fields on dynamically generated quark masses and meson spectra, underscoring this model's importance for exploring extreme physical conditions. The article concludes by exploring an alternative approach, bosonization, to derive an effective mesonic Lagrangian density and critically evaluates the connection between the NJL model results and those of chiral perturbation theory.

title: Phenomenology, astrophysics, and cosmology of theories with submillimeter dimensions and TeV scale quantum gravity
abstract: We recently proposed a solution to the hierarchy problem not relying on low-energy supersymmetry or technicolor. Instead, the problem is nullified by bringing quantum gravity down to the TeV scale. This is accomplished by the presence of n ≥ 2 new dimensions of sub-millimeter size, with the SM fields localised on a 3-brane in the higher dimensional space. In this paper we systematically study the experimental viability of this scenario. Constraints arise both from strong quantum gravitational effects at the TeV scale, and more importantly from the production of massless higher dimensional gravitons with TeV suppressed couplings. Theories with n&gt; 2 are safe due mainly to the infrared softness of higher dimensional gravity. For n = 2, the six dimensional Planck scale must be pushed above ∼ 30 TeV to avoid cooling SN1987A and distortions of the diffuse photon background. Nevertheless, the particular implementation of our
summary:
Title: New Theories Suggest Sub-millimeter Dimensions for TeV Quantum Gravity

Summary:
The physicists Nima Arkani–Hamed, Savas Dimopoulos, and Gia Dvali propose a novel solution to the long-standing hierarchy problem in particle physics, one that doesn't rely on low-energy supersymmetry or technicolor. Instead, they propose that quantum gravity could be brought down to the TeV scale due to the presence of multiple (n ≥ 2) new sub-millimeter dimensions. The team explores the experimental viability of this scenario in a recent paper published in Physical Review D. The theories with more than two dimensions are immune to constraints, while for n = 2, the six-dimensional Planck scale must be pushed above about 30 TeV to avoid conflicts with supernova events and distortions of the cosmic microwave background. This research offers a fresh perspective in the quest to reconcile particle physics and quantum gravity.

title: Total Top-Quark Pair-Production Cross Section at Hadron Colliders Through<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi mathvariant="script">O</mml:mi><mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo><mml:msubsup><mml:mi>α</mml:mi><mml:mi>S</mml:mi><mml:mn>4</mml:mn></mml:msubsup><mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo></mml:math>
abstract: We compute the next-to-next-to-leading order (NNLO) quantum chromodynamics (QCD) correction to the total cross section for the reaction gg → tt + X. Together with the partonic channels we computed previously, the result derived in this Letter completes the set of NNLO QCD corrections to the total top pair-production cross section at hadron colliders. Supplementing the fixed order results with soft-gluon resummation with next-to-next-to-leading logarithmic accuracy, we estimate that the theoretical uncertainty of this observable due to unknown higher order corrections is about 3% at the LHC and 2.2% at the Tevatron. We observe a good agreement between the standard model predictions and the available experimental measurements. The very high theoretical precision of this observable allows a new level of scrutiny in parton distribution functions and new physics searches.
summary:
Physics Journal: New High Precision Calculation Enhances Understanding of Top Quark Pair-Production

A new study by physicists M. Czakon, Paul Fiedler, and Alexander Mitov published in Physical Review Letters has significantly advanced our understanding of top quark pair-production at hadron colliders. The researchers have computed the next-to-next-to-leading order (NNLO) quantum chromodynamics (QCD) corrections to the reaction gg → tt + X, completing the set of NNLO QCD corrections for this important observable. By combining their findings with soft-gluon resummation, they estimate that the theoretical uncertainty for this observable at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is around 3%, and 2.2% at the Tevatron. The study's high precision level promises enhanced scrutiny in parton distribution functions and new physics searches.

title: A measurement of the spin asymmetry and determination of the structure function g1 in deep inelastic muon-proton scattering
abstract: The spin asymmetry in deep inelastic scattering of longitudinally polarised muons by longitudinally polarised protons has been measured over a large x range (0.01<x<0.7). The spin-dependent structure function g1(x) for the proton has been determined and its integral over x found to be 0.114±0.012±0.026, in disagreement with the Ellis-Jaffe sum rule. Assuming the validity of the Bjorken sum rule, this result implies a significant negative value for the integral of g1 for the neutron. These values for the integrals of g1 lead to the conclusion that the total quark spin constitutes a rather small fraction of the spin of the nucleon.
summary:
Headline:
New Study Reveals Surprising Spin Asymmetry Discovery in Proton-Muon Collisions

Summary:
A group of scientists have made a significant finding in the field of physics after measuring the spin asymmetry in the deep inelastic scattering of polarised muons with protons. The study, published in Physics Letters B, found that although the integral of g1 for the proton deviated from the Ellis-Jaffe sum rule, it implies a negative value for the neutron's integral if the Bjorken sum rule is valid. This suggests that the total quark spin contributes little to the spin of the nucleon, challenging our understanding of the inner workings of protons and neutrons.

title: Natural conservation laws for neutral currents
abstract: We explore the consequences of the assumption that the direct and induced weak neutral currents in an $\mathrm{SU}(2)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}\mathrm{U}(1)$ gauge theory conserve all quark flavors naturally, i.e., for all values of the parameters of the theory. This requires that all quarks of a given charge and helicity must have the same values of weak ${T}_{3}$ and ${\stackrel{\ensuremath{\rightarrow}}{T}}^{2}$. If all quarks have charge +2/3 or -1/3 the only acceptable theories are the "standard" and "pure vector" models, or their generalizations to six or more quarks. In addition, there are severe constraints on the couplings of Higgs bosons, which apparently cannot be satisfied in pure vector models. We also consider the possibility that neutral currents conserve strangeness but not charm. A natural seven-quark model of this sort is described. The experimental consequences of charm nonconservation in direct or induced neutral currents are found to be quite dramatic.
summary:
Paper Title: Conserving Nature's Neutral Current Flavors: A New Approach to Particle Physics

In a groundbreaking work published in "Physical Review D", Nobel laureates Sheldon L. Glashow and Steven Weinberg propose a novel approach to understand the conservation laws governing weak neutral currents within an SU(2)⊗U(1) gauge theory.

Their research, focusing on quarks and their associated quantum numbers, aims to naturally conserve all quark flavors under these conservation laws, regardless of the parameters of the theory. They find that if all quarks carry charges +2/3 or -1/3, only the "standard" and "pure vector" models, or their six-quark extensions, are acceptable. However, they also conclude that pure vector models exhibit severe constraints on Higgs boson couplings which seem difficult to satisfy in these models alone.

More intriguingly, the study investigates the possibility of neutral currents conserving strangeness but not charm, revealing a potential seven-quark model and significant experimental implications for charm nonconservation in direct or induced neutral currents.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Sheldon L. Glashow; Steven Weinberg
institutions: Harvard University Press; Harvard University

title: Foundations of Perturbative QCD
abstract: The most non-trivial of the established microscopic theories of physics is QCD: the theory of the strong interaction. A critical link between theory and experiment is provided by the methods of perturbative QCD, notably the well-known factorization theorems. Giving an accurate account of the concepts, theorems and their justification, this book is a systematic treatment of perturbative QCD. As well as giving a mathematical treatment, the book relates the concepts to experimental data, giving strong motivations for the methods. It also examines in detail transverse-momentum-dependent parton densities, an increasingly important subject not normally treated in other books. Ideal for graduate students starting their work in high-energy physics, it will also interest experienced researchers wanting a clear account of the subject.
summary:
New Book Examines Foundations of Perturbative QCD Theory

John C. Collins' new book, "Foundations of Perturbative QCD," published by Cambridge University Press, presents a systematic treatment of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), renowned as one of the most complex theories in physics.

Collins' work focuses on Perturbative QCD and its essential factorization theorems, bridging theory and experiment in the study of strong interactions — a key concept in high-energy physics. The book provides a thorough understanding of the mathematical foundations along with their experimental applications, offering reasons for the method's importance.

Additionally, Collins delves into transverse-momentum-dependent parton densities, an area that isn't usually covered in other books but has gained significant attention recently. This resource caters to both graduate students beginning their journey in high-energy physics and seasoned researchers seeking a comprehensive yet concise account of Perturbative QCD.
allAuthors: John C. Collins
institutions: Pennsylvania State University

title: Dark Matter Candidates from Particle Physics and Methods of Detection
abstract: The identity of dark matter is a question of central importance in both astrophysics and particle physics. In the past, the leading particle candidates were cold and collisionless, and typically predicted missing energy signals at particle colliders. However, recent progress has greatly expanded the list of well-motivated candidates and the possible signatures of dark matter. This review begins with a brief summary of the standard model of particle physics and its outstanding problems. I then discuss several dark matter candidates motivated by these problems, including weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs), superWIMPs, light gravitinos, hidden dark matter, sterile neutrinos, and axions. For each of these, I critically examine the particle physics motivations and present their expected production mechanisms, basic properties, and implications for direct and indirect detection, particle colliders, and astrophysical observations. Upcoming experiments will discover or exclude many of these candidates, and progress may open up an era of unprecedented synergy between studies of the largest and smallest observable length scales.
summary:
**Article Headline:**
"Revolutionizing Dark Matter Research: A Comprehensive Review on Particle Physics Candidates and Detection Methods"

**Summary:**
Jonathan L. Feng's review in the Annual Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics explores the expanding landscape of dark matter candidates, a central mystery in both astrophysics and particle physics. The article delves into various particle candidates that address issues within the Standard Model of Particle Physics, such as weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs), superWIMPs, light gravitinos, hidden dark matter, sterile neutrinos, and axions. Each candidate is analyzed in terms of its origins in particle physics, production mechanisms, properties, and implications for direct and indirect detection, particle colliders, and astrophysical observations. This work underscores the potential for groundbreaking synergies between studies traversing the largest and smallest observable scales, with upcoming experiments set to unveil or rule out many of these exciting candidates.
journal: Annual Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics

title: The LHCb Detector at the LHC
abstract: The LHCb experiment is dedicated to precision measurements of CP violation and rare decays of B hadrons at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN (Geneva). The initial configuration and expected performance of the detector and associated systems, as established by test beam measurements and simulation studies, is described.
summary:
New Detector for Large Hadron Collider Aims to Unravel Particle Mysteries

Scientists from a large international collaboration have detailed the design and capabilities of the LHCb detector, a critical tool at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN's facility in Geneva. The LHC is the world's largest and most powerful particle accelerator, and the LHCb experiment focuses on precise measurements of CP violation and rare decays of B hadrons. The new detector promises to deliver insights into these processes that could lead to a deeper understanding of the fundamental forces governing our universe, building upon previous research in physics and particle physics.

title: Various Phenomenological Aspects of the R-parity Violating MSSM
abstract: The Standard Model (SM) faces both theoretical and experimental challenges that indicate the existence of physics beyond its current framework. Among the proposed extensions, supersymmetry (SUSY) emerges as a promising concept. The simplest extension of the SM, which incorporates SUSY, is the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM). It provides a potential candidate for dark matter and offers solutions to the hierarchy problem. As part of the definition of the MSSM, imposing a discrete R-parity (𝑅<sub>𝑝</sub>), to prevent proton decay, forbids every term in the Lagrangian that violates baryon or lepton number. However, imposing this symmetry is not necessary. Models that violate R-parity (RPV) exhibit a rich and diverse phenomenology different from the 𝑅<sub>𝑝</sub>-conserving MSSM and provide a more original mechanism for neutrino mass production. <br/> This thesis addresses the phenomenology of the RPV-MSSM by identifying different characteristic regions within the RPV-MSSM landscape and exploring their signatures. Depending on the choice of RPV couplings, the framework may exhibit potential gaps in the coverage. We try to provide studies, which potentially close these gaps and try to give an overview of the vast RPV-MSSM landscape. <br/> By analyzing the structures of the neutrino mass matrix, we identify minimal models for understanding neutrino masses in the 𝐵<sub>3</sub>-conserving RPV-MSSM. These models provide valuable insights into understanding neutrino masses, in the general context of RPV scenarios that have not been analyzed. <br/> We use several collider experiments to investigate how different types of signals can be revealed as a result of the choice and strength of RPV couplings as well as the mass of SUSY particles. We present a systematic analysis of the RPV-MSSM and its collider signatures to find a minimal number of experimental searches for comprehensive LHC coverage. The lightest neutralino with a mass of 𝒪(GeV) and small couplings is unconstrained in the RPV-MSSM. We present three approaches for both constraining the coupling parameters and exploring the sensitivity regions of future experiments. We consider neutralino production in meson decays via 𝐿𝑄<span style="text-decoration:overline">𝐷</span> operators, followed by loop-induced decays into a photon and a neutrino in <TT>FASER</TT>. We re-interpret experimental results, derived for heavy neutral leptons (HNL), to constrain the RPV couplings. And we study a novel proton decay involving a bino-like neutralino and the resulting decay signature. <br/> Our approach emphasizes the potential of future experiments, including those not specifically designed for SUSY searches, to effectively probe the RPV landscape.
summary:
Paper Title: Exploring Possibilities Beyond the Standard Model with R-parity Violating Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model

Physicists, led by Jonathan L. Feng and colleagues, have delved into the realm of physics beyond the Standard Model in a new study published in bonndoc. The researchers scrutinize the R-parity Violating MiniSupersymmetric Standard Model (RPV-MSSM), an extension of the Standard Model that could offer insights into dark matter and solve the hierarchy problem.

By investigating various RPV coupling choices, the team uncovers distinct regions within the RPV-MSSM landscape and examines their collider signatures. They also propose minimal models for understanding neutrino masses in the 𝐵3-conserving RPV-MSSM, offering unique insights into neutrino masses beyond prior analyses.

The research aims to fill potential gaps in RPV-MSSM coverage and present a comprehensive analysis of its collider signatures for optimal LHC exploration. The study concludes that the lightest neutralino with a mass of approximately GeV and weak couplings remains unconstrained, leading them to propose approaches for both coupling parameter constraints and sensitivity region exploration for future experiments. Potential experiments not specifically designed for supersymmetry searches are highlighted as holding significant promise in probing the RPV landscape's vast expanse.

title: CP violation and the CKM matrix: assessing the impact of the asymmetric B factories
abstract: AI abstract - This study assesses the impact of asymmetric B factories on CP violation and the CKM matrix within the context of electroweak interactions in particle physics. The authors explore the implications of these findings for unitarity in the field.
summary:
Headline: Research Sheds Light on CP Violation, Unveiling Electroweak Interactions' Role in Particle Physics

Summary:
A new study published in The European Physical Journal C by researchers led by Jérôme Charles explores how the recent advent of asymmetric B factories has influenced CP violation - a fundamental aspect of electroweak interactions critical to understanding particle physics. The scientists delve into the impact of these findings on unitarity, one of the core principles governing the field. This research provides fresh insights into how these complex interactions govern the behavior of subatomic particles.

title: The effects of topological charge change in heavy ion collisions: “Event by event and violation”
abstract: AI abstract - This study explores the impact of topological charge modifications in heavy ion collisions, focusing on event-by-event variations and potential violations of parity symmetry within the framework of Quantum Chromodynamics, as proposed by Kharzeev, McLerran, and Warringa (2008). The investigation aims to shed light on the interplay between topological charge dynamics and the emergence of novel phenomena in high-energy nuclear collisions.
summary:
Headline: New study delves into parity symmetry violations in heavy ion collisions

Summary: A new paper published in Nuclear Physics A, authored by Dmitri E. Kharzeev, Larry McLerran, and Harmen J. Warringa, explores the effects of topological charge changes in heavy ion collisions. The study builds upon the framework proposed by the authors in 2008 in which they predicted potential violations of parity symmetry during such collisions within the context of Quantum Chromodynamics. This research aims to better understand the complex interaction between topological charge dynamics and the emergence of new phenomena in high-energy nuclear collisions.

title: Gauge-Invariant Decomposition of Nucleon Spin
abstract: I introduce a gauge invariant decomposition of the nucleon spin into quark helicity, quark orbital, and gluon contributions. The total quark (and hence the quark orbital) contribution is shown to be measurable through virtual Compton scattering in a special kinematic region where single quark scattering dominates. This deeply-virtual Compton scattering (DVCS) has much potential to unravel the quark and gluon structure of the nucleon.
summary:
**Title:** A New Approach Deciphering Nucleon's Structure: Gauge-Invariant Decomposition

**Headline:** Physicist Proposes Novel Method to Measure Nucleon's Inner Workings

**Summary:** In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review Letters, researcher Xiangdong Ji proposes a gauge-invariant decomposition of a nucleon's spin into components from quark helicity, quark orbital motion, and gluons. This innovative method could potentially unlock the secrets of the complex structure of protons and neutrons through a process known as deeply-virtual Compton scattering (DVCS). By measuring this DVCS in a special kinematic region, scientists aim to discern crucial details about the subatomic particles that comprise nucleons.
allAuthors: Xiangdong Ji
institutions: Massachusetts Institute of Technology; University of Washington

title: Multiquark hadrons. I. Phenomenology of<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mrow><mml:msup><mml:mrow><mml:mi>Q</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:msup></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:msup><mml:mover><mml:mrow><mml:mi>Q</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>¯</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mover><mml:mrow><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:msup></mml:mrow></mml:math>mesons
abstract: The spectra and dominant decay couplings of ${Q}^{2}{\overline{Q}}^{2}$ mesons are presented as calculated in the quark-bag model. Certain known ${0}^{+}$ mesons [$\ensuremath{\epsilon}(700),{S}^{*},\ensuremath{\delta},\ensuremath{\kappa}$] are assigned to the lightest cryptoexotic ${Q}^{2}{\overline{Q}}^{2}$ nonet. The usual quark-model ${0}^{+}$ nonet ($Q\overline{Q} L=1$) must lie higher in mass. All other ${Q}^{2}{\overline{Q}}^{2}$ mesons are predicted to be broad, heavy, and usually inelastic in formation processes. Other ${Q}^{2}{\overline{Q}}^{2}$ states which may be experimentally prominent are discussed.
summary:
Title: New Theories on Multiquark Mesons Suggested by Physicist

Subhead: Jaffe's Phenomenon of $Q^2\bar{Q}^2$ Mesons Offer Fresh Perspectives in Particle Physics

A new article published in Physical Review D. Particles, Fields, Gravitation and Cosmology proposes fresh insights into the world of particle physics. Noted physicist R.J. Jaffe presents the spectra and dominant decay couplings of $Q^2\bar{Q}^2$ mesons, using the quark-bag model as his framework.

This research aims to revise our understanding of certain known $0^+$ mesons like epsilon(700), S*, delta, and kappa by classifying them as the lightest cryptoexotic $Q^2\bar{Q}^2$ nonet. Traditional quark-model $0^+$ nonets (Q\ Mal1) are hypothesized to have a higher mass. Jaffe's model predicts that other $Q^2\bar{Q}^2$ mesons will be broad, heavy, and typically inelastic during formation processes. The article also discusses additional $Q^2\bar{Q}^2$ states that could become experimentally prominent in the future.

With this work, Jaffe continues to push the boundaries of particle physics and meson theory, offering a new perspective on hadron compositions as well as potential paths for further investigation in the field.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Gluon distribution functions for very large nuclei at small transverse momentum
abstract: We show that the gluon distribution function for very large nuclei may be computed for small transverse momentum as correlation functions of an ultraviolet finite two dimensional Euclidean field theory. This computation is valid to all orders in the density of partons per unit area, but to lowest order in $\alpha_s$. The gluon distribution function is proportional to $1/x$, and the effect of the finite density of partons is to modify the dependence on transverse momentum for small transverse momentum.
summary:
"Physics breakthrough: Researchers propose new method to predict particle behavior in large nuclei

Larry McLerran and Raju Venugopalan, physicists from Physical Review D, have developed a new approach to calculate the distribution of gluons - a fundamental particle that binds other particles together - in very large nuclei for small transverse momentum. The method involves correlation functions of an ultraviolet finite two-dimensional Euclidean field theory, which offers insights into the behavior of these particles at high densities.

The findings suggest that the gluon distribution function is proportional to a reciprocal of x and exhibits a modified dependence on transverse momentum for small transverse momentum due to the presence of partons - fundamental particles in the nucleus."
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Larry McLerran; Raju Venugopalan
institutions: University of Minnesota

title: Handbook of LHC Higgs Cross Sections: 3. Higgs Properties
abstract: This Report summarizes the results of the activities in 2012 and the first half of 2013 of the LHC Higgs Cross Section Working Group. The main goal of the working group was to present the state of the art of Higgs Physics at the LHC, integrating all new results that have appeared in the last few years. This report follows the first working group report Handbook of LHC Higgs Cross Sections: 1. Inclusive Observables (CERN-2011-002) and the second working group report Handbook of LHC Higgs Cross Sections: 2. Differential Distributions (CERN-2012-002). After the discovery of a Higgs boson at the LHC in mid-2012 this report focuses on refined prediction of Standard Model (SM) Higgs phenomenology around the experimentally observed value of 125-126 GeV, refined predictions for heavy SM-like Higgs bosons as well as predictions in the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model and first steps to go beyond these models. The other main focus is on the extraction of the characteristics and properties of the newly discovered particle such as couplings to SM particles, spin and CP-quantum numbers etc.
summary:
In a groundbreaking new study from the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) Higgs Cross Section Working Group, published in arXiv, the experts offer an extensive review of Higgs boson properties following its discovery in mid-2012. This third installment of the Handbook series – succeeding the previous reports on Inclusive Observables and Differential Distributions – summarizes advancements made from 2012 to the first half of 2013.

This latest report hones in on refined predictions for Standard Model Higgs bosons around the experimentally observed value, along with an enhanced analysis of heavy SM-like Higgs bosons. The research focuses attention on the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model as well, taking preliminary steps to explore potential theories beyond it. Additionally, the study delves into defining the characterization and properties of the newly discovered particle (spin, CP-quantum numbers, etc.), helping unveil more about the fundamental nature of this essential particle in particle physics.

title: The order of the quantum chromodynamics transition predicted by the standard model of particle physics
abstract: AI abstract - This study predicts the order of the quantum chromodynamics transition within the standard model of particle physics, shedding light on the behavior of quarks and their role in phase transitions. The research presents calculations by Aoki et al., employing lattice quantum chromodynamics to determine the nature of the transition as a crucial step towards understanding the properties of high-temperature QCD matter.
summary: In a groundbreaking study published in Nature, physicists Yasumichi Aoki and colleagues predict the order of the quantum chromodynamics (QCD) transition, a key milestone within particle physics. The research focuses on the behavior of quarks during phase transitions and uses lattice QCD calculations to advance our understanding of high-temperature QCD matter. By determining the nature of the transition, this work could provide critical insights into the properties of quarks and the fundamental structure of the universe as described by the Standard Model of particle physics.

title: Hierarchy of Interactions in Unified Gauge Theories
abstract: We present a general formalism for calculating the renormalization effects which make strong interactions strong in simple gauge theories of strong, electromagnetic, and weak interactions. In an SU(5) model the superheavy gauge bosons arising in the spontaneous breakdown to observed interactions have mass perhaps as large as ${10}^{17}$ GeV, almost the Planck mass. Mixing-angle predictions are substantially modified.
summary:
Title: New Formalism Proposes Strong Interactions Strengthening in Gauge Theories

Subhead: Physicists Offer a Roadmap for Understanding Subatomic Forces

In an exciting development, researchers Howard Georgi, Helen R. Quinn, and Steven Weinberg have presented a novel formalism to calculate the effects responsible for making strong interactions stronger, as observed in simple gauge theories of strong, electromagnetic, and weak interactions. The new method may hold the key to understanding the complex workings of subatomic particles, according to their paper published in Physical Review Letters.

In the proposed framework, the masses of superheavy gauge bosons, arising from the spontaneous breakdown of observed interactions, reach values as high as ${10}^{17}$ GeV, approaching the Planck mass. This means that these particles could potentially hold crucial insights about the fundamental structure of the universe itself. Furthermore, the theory's predictions for mixing angles are substantially modified, providing fresh perspectives on the nature of subatomic interactions within a unified gauge framework.
allAuthors: Howard Georgi; Helen R. Quinn; Steven Weinberg
institutions: Harvard University

summary:
Headline: Experts Review Newly Observed "Exotic" Hadron States, Signaling a Shift in Particle Physics

Summary: In Reports on Progress in Physics, scientists Hua-Xing Chen and colleagues have updated a review of recent advances in hadron physics, with a focus on the observation of new heavy flavor mesons and multi-quark states. The authors explore exciting open heavy flavor tetraquark X(2900), Tc++(3875), hidden heavy flavor multiquark states X (6900), Pc s (4459), Zc s (3985) and (4000), and Zc s (4220), as well as recent progress on glueballs and light hybrid mesons. These discoveries suggest a shift in our understanding of the non-Abelian SU(3) gauge interaction of Quantum Chromodynamics in the low-energy region, offering a new perspective for this active field of research.
allAuthors: Hua-Xing Chen; Wei Chen; Xiang Liu; Yan-Rui Liu; Shi-Lin Zhu

title: A Large Hadron Electron Collider at CERN Report on the Physics and Design Concepts for Machine and Detector
abstract: The physics programme and the design are described of a new collider for particle and nuclear physics, the Large Hadron Electron Collider (LHeC), in which a newly built electron beam of 60 GeV, to possibly 140 GeV, energy collides with the intense hadron beams of the LHC. Compared to the first ep collider, HERA, the kinematic range covered is extended by a factor of twenty in the negative four-momentum squared, Q 2 , and in the inverse Bjorken x , while with the design luminosity of 10 33 cm -2 s -1 the LHeC is projected to exceed the integrated HERA luminosity by two orders of magnitude. The physics programme is devoted to an exploration of the energy frontier, complementing the LHC and its discovery potential for physics beyond the Standard Model with high precision deep inelastic scattering measurements. These are designed to investigate a variety of fundamental questions in strong and electroweak interactions. The LHeC thus continues the path of deep inelastic scattering (DIS) into unknown areas of physics and kinematics. The physics programme also includes electron-deuteron and electron-ion scattering in a ( Q 2 1/ x ) range extended by four orders of magnitude as compared to previous lepton-nucleus DIS experiments for novel investigations of neutron's and nuclear structure, the initial conditions of Quark-Gluon Plasma formation and further quantum chromodynamic phenomena. The LHeC may be realised either as a ring-ring or as a linac-ring collider. Optics and beam dynamics studies are presented for both versions, along with technical design considerations on the interaction region, magnets including new dipole prototypes, cryogenics, RF, and further components. A design study is also presented of a detector suitable to perform high precision DIS measurements in a wide range of acceptance using state-of-the art detector technology, which is modular and of limited size enabling its fast installation. The detector includes tagging devices for electron, photon, proton and neutron detection near to the beam pipe. Civil engineering and installation studies are presented for the accelerator and the detector. The LHeC can be built within a decade and thus be operated while the LHC runs in its high-luminosity phase. It so represents a major opportunity for progress in particle physics exploiting the investment made in the LHC.
summary:
Title: Scientists Propose New Collider at CERN to Explore Beyond Standard Model

In a groundbreaking paper published in the Journal of Physics G: Nuclear and Particle Physics, a team of international researchers have proposed the Large Hadron Electron Collider (LHeC) at CERN. Building upon the success of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and previous electron-proton collider HERA, the LHeC aims to delve deeper into particle and nuclear physics by extending the kinematic range covered by a factor of twenty.

The LHeC will offer improved precision in deep inelastic scattering measurements, enabling researchers to investigate fundamental questions related to strong and electroweak interactions, explore new territories in physics and kinematics, and further our understanding of quantum chromodynamics phenomena. The proposed collider also includes investigations into electron-deuteron and electron-ion scattering for novel studies on neutron structure and initial conditions of Quark-Gluon Plasma formation.

The LHeC could be realized as either a ring-ring or linac-ring collider, with optics and beam dynamics studies presented for both versions. The paper also outlines design considerations for the interaction region, magnets, cryogenics, RF systems, and additional components. A detector suitable for high precision DIS measurements is proposed, featuring modular and compact design for fast installation during the LHC's high-luminosity phase. With a projected construction timeline of under a decade, the LHeC presents an exciting opportunity to advance the frontier of particle physics utilizing CERN's existing resources.
journal: Journal of Physics G Nuclear and Particle Physics

title: Measurements of the Higgs boson production and decay rates and constraints on its couplings from a combined ATLAS and CMS analysis of the LHC pp collision data at s = 7 $$ \sqrt{s}=7 $$ and 8 TeV
abstract: AI abstract - This study presents measurements of the Higgs boson production and decay rates, as well as constraints on its couplings, from a combined analysis of LHC pp collision data at 7 and 8 TeV by ATLAS and CMS experiments. The results provide valuable insights into the properties of the Higgs boson and further our understanding of the Standard Model of particle physics.
summary:
Study reveals new measurements on Higgs boson production and decay rates, shedding light on Standard Model of particle physics
--------------

Researchers from ATLAS and CMS experiments have released a joint analysis indicating new measurements on the production and decay rates of the Higgs boson, as well as constraints on its couplings. Data was collected during LHC pp collisions at 7 and 8 TeV. The findings provide vital insights into the properties of the Higgs boson and contribute to a deeper understanding of the Standard Model of particle physics.

title: Supersymmetry and Supergravity
abstract: The first edition of this book appeared in 1983 and was based on a series of lectures given at Princeton in 1983 by Julius Wess. Since the appearance of the first edition much work has been done on the development of phenomenological models of particle behavior based on the supergravity multiplet. Some experimental searches have been carried out and others are planned for the future. For this reason the second edition of the book goes substantially beyond the first. Six new chapters have been added for a total of twenty-six and five new appendices for a total of seven. The new chapters and appendices are primarily aimed at deriving the most general supersymmetric gauge invariant theory of chiral fields interacting with supergravity and expressing it in component form. The book is divided into three sections. After a brief introduction, the first part of the book deals with a description of N=1 supersymmetric non-abelian rigid gauge theory of chiral fields. The second part of the book develops a local supersymmetric theory which is supergravity. The final part describes the coupling of supersymmetric chiral fields to supergravity in a gauge invariant way. The book may be recommended as a pedagogical introduction tomore » the theory of N=1 supergravity. Together with the appendices is is completely self-contained, both in notation and in the concepts used, requiring only some knowledge of field theory as a background.« less
summary:
Headline: Groundbreaking Book on Supergravity Advances Particle Physics Studies

Summary:
"The second edition of 'Supersymmetry and Supergravity', published by Princeton University Press, offers an updated look at the development of particle behavior models based on supergravity multiplet. The book, penned by Julius Wess and Jonathan Bagger, goes beyond its first edition with six new chapters and five additional appendices. These additions focus on deriving a general, supersymmetric gauge-invariant theory for chiral fields interacting with supergravity, expressed in component form. The book is divided into three sections: rigid gauge theory of chiral fields, local supersymmetric theory (supergravity), and the coupling of supersymmetric chiral fields to supergravity. This work serves as a pedagogical introduction to the theory of N=1 supergravity and is self-contained for those with a background in field theory."
allAuthors: Julius Wess; Jonathan Bagger

title: Radiative corrections to the masses of supersymmetric Higgs bosons
abstract: AI abstract - This paper explores radiative corrections to the masses of supersymmetric Higgs bosons in the context of particle physics. The authors present calculations and discuss their implications for the understanding of these particles' properties within high-energy collisions.
summary:
Title: New Insights into Supersymmetric Higgs Boson Masses

In a new study published in Physics Letters B, physicists John Ellis, Giovanni Ridolfi, and Fabio Zwirner have delved deeper into understanding the properties of Higgs bosons – fundamental particles that give other particles mass. The researchers focus on radiative corrections, exploring how these adjustments affect the masses of supersymmetric Higgs bosons during high-energy collisions in particle physics. Their calculations may provide fresh insights to further our understanding of these significant subatomic particles.
allAuthors: John Ellis; Giovanni Ridolfi; Fabio Zwirner
institutions: European Organization for Nuclear Research; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Genova

title: Parametrization of the Kobayashi-Maskawa Matrix
abstract: The quark mixing matrix (Kobayashi-Maskawa matrix) is expanded in powers of a small parameter $\ensuremath{\lambda}$ equal to $sin{\ensuremath{\theta}}_{c}=0.22$. The term of order ${\ensuremath{\lambda}}^{2}$ is determined from the recently measured $B$ lifetime. Two remaining parameters, including the $\mathrm{CP}$-nonconservation effects, enter only the term of order ${\ensuremath{\lambda}}^{3}$ and are poorly constrained. A significant reduction in the limit on $\frac{{\ensuremath{\epsilon}}^{\ensuremath{'}}}{\ensuremath{\epsilon}}$ possible in an ongoing experiment would tightly constrain the $\mathrm{CP}$-nonconservation parameter and could rule out the hypothesis that the only source of $\mathrm{CP}$ nonconservation is the Kobayashi-Maskawa mechanism.
summary:
Title: Groundbreaking Study Sheds Light on Quark Mixing Matrix Parameterization

Physicist L. Wolfenstein's innovative work in Physical Review Letters focuses on the parametrization of the Kobayashi-Maskawa matrix, a key aspect of particle physics that helps us understand the behavior and mixing between different types of quarks. The study expands the matrix using a small parameter, $\lambda$ (approximately equivalent to $sin{\theta}_{c}=0.22$), and predicts values for terms up to order ${\lambda}^{2}$.

The critical next-level term, responsible for CP violation effects, remains unconstrained due to insufficient data. The experimental findings that could limit the ratio of CP-violation parameters $\frac{{\epsilon}^{\prime}}{\epsilon}$ would significantly tighten constraints on this mysterious parameter and potentially rule out the prevailing hypothesis suggesting that all CP nonconservation arises solely from the Kobayashi-Maskawa mechanism.
allAuthors: L. Wolfenstein
institutions: Carnegie Mellon University

title: Symmetries of Baryons and Mesons
abstract: The system of strongly interacting particles is discussed, with electromagnetism, weak interactions, and gravitation considered as perturbations. The electric current jα, the weak current Jα, and the gravitational tensor θαβ are all well-defined operators, with finite matrix elements obeying dispersion relations. To the extent that the dispersion relations for matrix elements of these operators between the vacuum and other states are highly convergent and dominated by contributions from intermediate one-meson states, we have relations like the Goldberger-Treiman formula and universality principles like that of Sakurai according to which the ρ meson is coupled approximately to the isotopic spin. Homogeneous linear dispersion relations, even without subtractions, do not suffice to fix the scale of these matrix elements; in particular, for the nonconserved currents, the renormalization factors cannot be calculated, and the universality of strength of the weak interactions is undefined. More information than just the dispersion relations must be supplied, for example, by field-theoretic models; we consider, in fact, the equal-time commutation relations of the various parts of j4 and J4. These nonlinear relations define an algebraic system (or a group) that underlies the structure of baryons and mesons. It is suggested that the group is in fact U(3)×U(3), exemplified by the symmetrical Sakata model. The Hamiltonian density θ44 is not completely invariant under the group; the noninvariant part transforms according to a particular representation of the group; it is possible that this information also is given correctly by the symmetrical Sakata model. Various exact relations among form factors follow from the algebraic structure. In addition, it may be worthwhile to consider the approximate situation in which the strangeness-changing vector currents are conserved and the Hamiltonian is invariant under U(3); we refer to this limiting case as "unitary symmetry." In the limit, the baryons and mesons form degenerate supermultiplets, which break up into isotopic multiplets when the symmetry-breaking term in the Hamiltonian is "turned on." The mesons are expected to form unitary singlets and octets; each octet breaks up into a triplet, a singlet, and a pair of strange doublets. The known pseudoscalar and vector mesons fit this pattern if there exists also an isotopic singlet pseudoscalar meson χ0. If we consider unitary symmetry in the abstract rather than in connection with a field theory, then we find, as an attractive alternative to the Sakata model, the scheme of Ne'eman and Gell-Mann, which we call the "eightfold way"; the baryons N, Λ, Σ, and Ξ form an octet, like the vector and pseudoscalar meson octets, in the limit of unitary symmetry. Although the violations of unitary symmetry must be quite large, there is some hope of relating certain violations to others. As an example of the methods advocated, we present a rough calculation of the rate of K+→μ++ν in terms of that of π+→μ++ν.
summary:
**Groundbreaking Physics Study Offers Insights on Baryons and Mesons**

In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review, renowned physicist Murray Gell-Mann discusses the system of strongly interacting particles, proposing that algebraic structures underlying baryons and mesons can be defined by a group – suggested to be U(3)×U(3). The paper builds upon previous work, including Goldberger-Treiman formula and Sakurai's universality principles.

Gell-Mann argues that the system of electromagnetism, weak interactions, and gravitation can be viewed as perturbations. His findings suggest that baryons and mesons conform to a pattern seen in Ne'eman and Gell-Mann's "eightfold way," with an octet of baryons forming in the limit of unitary symmetry, much like the vector and pseudoscalar meson octets.

However, the violations of unitary symmetry are expected to be quite large, leaving open questions regarding their relationship. As an example, Gell-Mann presents a preliminary calculation of the rate of K+→μ++ν in relation to that of π+→μ++ν, demonstrating the novel methods he advocates in this study.
allAuthors: Murray Gell‐Mann
institutions: California Institute of Technology

title: Observation of Reactor Electron Antineutrinos Disappearance in the RENO Experiment
abstract: The RENO experiment has observed the disappearance of reactor electron antineutrinos, consistent with neutrino oscillations, with a significance of 4.9 standard deviations. Antineutrinos from six 2.8 GW(th) reactors at the Yonggwang Nuclear Power Plant in Korea, are detected by two identical detectors located at 294 and 1383 m, respectively, from the reactor array center. In the 229 d data-taking period between 11 August 2011 and 26 March 2012, the far (near) detector observed 17102 (154088) electron antineutrino candidate events with a background fraction of 5.5% (2.7%). The ratio of observed to expected numbers of antineutrinos in the far detector is 0.920±0.009(stat)±0.014(syst). From this deficit, we determine sin(2)2θ(13)=0.113±0.013(stat)±0.019(syst) based on a rate-only analysis.
summary:
**Headline:**
Korean Experiment Confirms Oscillation of Electron Antineutrinos with High Precision

**Short Summary:**
A new study published in Physical Review Letters, led by a team of 27 Korean scientists, has confirmed the disappearance of reactor electron antineutrinos – a phenomenon known as neutrino oscillations – with a significant level of 4.9 standard deviations. The RENO experiment, conducted at the Yonggwang Nuclear Power Plant in South Korea, employed two identical detectors situated at different distances from the reactor array center. According to their findings, the far detector detected fewer electron antineutrino events than expected, which has been attributed to neutrino oscillations. The researchers used a rate-only analysis to determine the value of sin(2)2θ(13), a parameter crucial in understanding the behavior of these subatomic particles.

title: Review of mathematics, numerical factors, and corrections for dark matter experiments based on elastic nuclear recoil
abstract:
AI abstract - This paper reviews the mathematical foundations and numerical factors involved in experiments aimed at detecting dark matter through elastic nuclear recoil, discussing potential corrections and normalization methods to enhance the accuracy of such experiments in astroparticle physics.

AI abstract - The authors present a comprehensive review of the mathematics, normalization techniques, and numerical factors associated with dark matter detection experiments utilizing elastic nuclear recoil. They discuss potential corrections to improve the precision of these experiments within the field of astroparticle physics.
summary:
Title: "Improving Dark Matter Detection: A Review on Mathematical Foundations and Corrections"

Article:
A new paper in Astroparticle Physics by authors J.D. Lewin and P.F. Smith reviews the mathematical and numerical factors involved in detecting dark matter through elastic nuclear recoil. The work aims to enhance the accuracy of such experiments by discussing potential corrections and normalization methods within the broader field of astroparticle physics, contributing to ongoing efforts to better understand this mysterious substance that makes up a substantial portion of the universe's total mass.
allAuthors: J.D. Lewin; P.F. Smith
institutions: Rutherford Appleton Laboratory

title: Weak interactions at very high energies: The role of the Higgs-boson mass
abstract: We give an $S$-matrix-theoretic demonstration that if the Higgs-boson mass exceeds ${M}_{c}={(8\ensuremath{\pi}\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}{G}_{F})}^{\frac{1}{2}}$, parital-wave unitarity is not respected by the tree diagrams for two-body scattering of gauge bosons, and the weak interactions must become strong at high energies. We exhibit the relation of this bound to the structure of the Higgs-Goldstone Lagrangian, and speculate on the consequences of strongly coupled Higgs-Goldstone systems. Prospects for the observation of massive Higgs scalars are noted.
summary:
"Physics Paper Sheds Light on High Energy Interactions with Higgs Boson"

In a new study published in Physical Review D, researchers Benjamin W. Lee, Chris Quigg, and H. B. Thacker provide insights into the behavior of the Higgs boson at extremely high energies. The team's work reveals that if the Higgs-boson mass surpasses a critical value, weak interactions start to act stronger at high energies due to a breakdown in unitarity – a fundamental concept in particle physics that ensures the conservation of probability.

The researchers also link this bound to the structure of the Higg's Goldstone Lagrangian and discuss the potential implications for Higgs-Goldstone systems with strong couplings. They highlight the significance of their findings for the prospects of observing massive Higgs scalars in high-energy particle collisions, paving the way for deeper understanding of the universe at its most fundamental levels.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Benjamin W. Lee; Chris Quigg; H. B. Thacker
institutions: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory

title: Tuning Monte Carlo generators: The Perugia tunes
abstract: We present 9 new tunes of the pT-ordered shower and underlying-event model in PYTHIA 6.4. These "Perugia" tunes update and supersede the older "S0" family. The data sets used to constrain the models include hadronic Z0 decays at LEP, Tevatron minimum-bias data at 630, 1800, and 1960 GeV, Tevatron Drell-Yan data at 1800 and 1960 GeV, and SPS min-bias data at 200, 546, and 900 GeV. In addition to the central parameter set, called "Perugia 0", we introduce a set of 8 related "Perugia Variations" that attempt to systematically explore soft, hard, parton density, and colour structure variations in the theoretical parameters. Based on these variations, a best-guess prediction of the charged track multiplicity in inelastic, nondiffractive minimum-bias events at the LHC is made. Note that these tunes can only be used with PYTHIA 6, not with PYTHIA 8. Note: this report was updated in March 2011 with a new set of variations, collectively labeled "Perugia 2011", that are optimized for matching applications and which also take into account some lessons from the early LHC data. In order not to break the original text, these are described separately in Appendix B. Note 2: a subsequent "Perugia 2012" update is described in Appendix C.
summary:
New Tunes Revamp Particle Physics Simulation: Introducing the Perugia Tunes

A groundbreaking study by physicist Peter Skands in Physical Review D presents nine new tuning adjustments to the pT-ordered shower and underlying event model within PYTHIA 6.4, dubbed "The Perugia Tunes." This work updates and replaces the older "S0" family tunes, with data sets from colliders such as the Tevatron and Large Hadron Collider (LHC) used for tuning.

The paper offers a central parameter set, known as "Perugia 0," along with eight related variations aimed to systematically scrutinize soft, hard, parton density, and color structure aspects within the theoretical parameters. By employing these tunes, researchers can predict charged track multiplicity in inelastic, nondiffractive minimum-bias events at the LHC. Keep in mind that these tunes are compatible only with PYTHIA 6 and not PYTHIA 8. The report was updated in March 2011 with a new set of variations, called "Perugia 2011," which cater to matching applications and incorporate lessons from LHC's initial data. Further updates were presented in subsequent years under the name "Perugia 2012."
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology
allAuthors: Peter Skands
institutions: European Organization for Nuclear Research

title: Experimental Tests of the "Invisible" Axion
abstract: Experiments are proposed which address the question of the existence of the "invisible" axion for the whole allowed range of the axion decay constant. These experiments exploit the coupling of the axion to the electromagnetic field, axion emission by the sum, and/or the cosmological abundance and presumed clustering of axions in the halo of our galaxy.
summary:
Title: Experiment Aims to Uncover "Invisible" Axion Particle

In a groundbreaking venture, Physicist P. Sikivie proposes novel experiments in a bid to establish the existence of the elusive "invisible" axion. The studies will target the entire spectrum of possible axion decay constants, according to a paper published in Physical Review Letters. The research builds upon the theory that axions are linked to the electromagnetic field and could be emitted by celestial bodies, with a particular focus on our galaxy's halo where they might cluster. If successful, these experiments could provide valuable insights into particle physics and potentially reshape our understanding of cosmic phenomena.
allAuthors: P. Sikivie
institutions: University of Florida

title: ALICE: Physics Performance Report, Volume II
abstract: ALICE is a general-purpose heavy-ion experiment designed to study the physics of strongly interacting matter and the quark-gluon plasma in nucleus-nucleus collisions at the LHC. It currently involves more than 900 physicists and senior engineers, from both the nuclear and high-energy physics sectors, from over 90 institutions in about 30 countries. The ALICE detector is designed to cope with the highest particle multiplicities above those anticipated for Pb-Pb collisions (dN(ch)/dy up to 8000) and it will be operational at the start-up of the LHC. In addition to heavy systems, the ALICE Collaboration will study collisions of lower-mass ions, which are a means of varying the energy density, and protons (both pp and pA), which primarily provide reference data for the nucleus-nucleus collisions. In addition, the pp data will allow for a number of genuine pp physics studies. The detailed design of the different detector systems has been laid down in a number of Technical Design Reports issued between mid-1998 and the end of 2004. The experiment is currently under construction and will be ready for data taking with both proton and heavy-ion beams at the start-up of the LHC. Since the comprehensive information on detector and physics performance was last published in the ALICE Technical Proposal in 1996, the detector, as well as simulation, reconstruction and analysis software have undergone significant development. The Physics Performance Report (PPR) provides an updated and comprehensive summary of the performance of the various ALICE subsystems, including updates to the Technical Design Reports, as appropriate. The PPR is divided into two volumes. Volume I, published in 2004 (CERN/LHCC 2003-049, ALICE Collaboration 2004 J. Phys. G: Nucl. Part. Phys. 30 1517-1763), contains in four chapters a short theoretical overview and an extensive reference list concerning the physics topics of interest to ALICE, the experimental conditions at the LHC, a short summary and update of the subsystem designs, and a description of the offline framework and Monte Carlo event generators. The present volume, Volume II, contains the majority of the information relevant to the physics performance in proton-proton, proton-nucleus, and nucleus-nucleus collisions. Following an introductory overview, Chapter 5 describes the combined detector performance and the event reconstruction procedures, based on detailed simulations of the individual subsystems. Chapter 6 describes the analysis and physics reach for a representative sample of physics observables, from global event characteristics to hard processes.
summary:
**Experiment Aims to Unravel Nuclear Physics Mysteries at LHC**

In a new report, scientists from over 90 institutions worldwide reveal significant advancements in ALICE, a groundbreaking experiment designed to probe the mysteries of strongly interacting matter at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The ALICE project is an ambitious collaboration between nuclear and high-energy physics sectors, with more than 900 physicists and senior engineers involved.

The study will cover a variety of experiments, including collisions involving lead nuclei, lower-mass ions to manipulate energy density, and proton-proton interactions for reference data. The detailed design of the ALICE detector has been updated since its inception in 1996, with substantial improvements made to software, subsystems, and simulation tools. ALICE is currently under construction and set to collect data as the LHC restarts operations.

The Physics Performance Report Volume II offers an in-depth look at various ALICE subsystem performances, focusing on proton-proton, proton-nucleus, and nucleus-nucleus collisions. The report provides updates to subsystem designs, event reconstruction procedures, and analysis methods for a range of physics observables, setting the stage for groundbreaking discoveries in nuclear physics research.

title: Color superconductivity in dense quark matter
abstract: Matter at high density and low temperature is expected to be a color superconductor, which is a degenerate Fermi gas of quarks with a condensate of Cooper pairs near the Fermi surface that induces color Meissner effects. At the highest densities, where the QCD coupling is weak, rigorous calculations are possible, and the ground state is a particularly symmetric state, the color-flavor locked (CFL) phase. The CFL phase is a superfluid, an electromagnetic insulator, and breaks chiral symmetry. The effective theory of the low-energy excitations in the CFL phase is known and can be used, even at more moderate densities, to describe its physical properties. At lower densities the CFL phase may be disfavored by stresses that seek to separate the Fermi surfaces of the different flavors, and comparison with the competing alternative phases, which may break translation and/or rotation invariance, is done using phenomenological models. We review the calculations that underlie these results, and then discuss transport properties of several color-superconducting phases and their consequences for signatures of color superconductivity in neutron stars.
summary:
Headline: New Study Sheds Light on Color Superconductivity in Star Matter

Summary:
A new study published in Reviews of Modern Physics delves into the intriguing concept of color superconductivity, a state that could be found in matter at high density and low temperature, like that found in neutron stars. The researchers, including Mark Alford, Andreas Schmitt, Krishna Rajagopal, and Thomas Schäfer, focus on the degenerate Fermi gas of quarks known as the color-flavor locked (CFL) phase. This phase, which occurs at the highest densities where the QCD coupling is weak, is a superfluid, an electromagnetic insulator, and breaks chiral symmetry. The study establishes an effective theory for the low-energy excitations in the CFL phase, which can be used to describe its physical properties even at more moderate densities. However, at lower densities, the CFL phase may be overshadowed by competing phases that break translation and rotation invariance. The team discusses the transport properties of various color-superconducting phases and their potential implications for signs of color superconductivity in neutron stars.
allAuthors: Mark Alford; Andreas Schmitt; Krishna Rajagopal; Thomas Schäfer
institutions: Washington University in St. Louis; Massachusetts Institute of Technology; North Carolina State University

title: Cosmological Lower Bound on Heavy-Neutrino Masses
abstract: The present cosmic mass density of possible stable neutral heavy leptons is calculated in a standard cosmological model. In order for this density not to exceed the upper limit of 2\ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{}${10}^{\ensuremath{-}29}$ g/${\mathrm{cm}}^{3}$, the lepton mass would have to be greater than a lower bound of the order of 2 GeV.
summary:
New Research Sets Lower Limit for Heavy Neutrino Masses

In a breakthrough in particle physics, researchers Benjamin W. Lee and Steven Weinberg have calculated the minimum mass a stable, neutral heavy lepton could have to not exceed a certain cosmic density limit, set at 2 times ${10}^{-29}$ grams per cubic centimeter. According to their findings published in Physical Review Letters, these hypothetical particles are predicted to weigh at least around 2 GeV (gig Electron Volts), providing an essential guideline for ongoing studies in cosmology and particle physics.
allAuthors: Benjamin W. Lee; Steven Weinberg
institutions: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory

title: Instantons in QCD
abstract: We review the theory and phenomenology of instantons in QCD. After a general overview, we provide a pedagogical introduction to semi-classical methods in quantum mechanics and field theory. The main part of the review summarizes our understanding of the instanton liquid in QCD and the role of instantons in generating the spectrum of light hadrons. We also discuss properties of instantons at finite temperature and the chiral phase transition. We give an overview over the importance of instantons in some other models, in particular two dimensional sigma models, electroweak theory and supersymmetric QCD.
summary:
Title: "Quantum Mechanics Reveals Hidden Forces in the Nucleon's Structure"

Summary: In a new review published in Reviews of Modern Physics, scientists Thomas Schäfer and Edward Shuryak delve into the mysterious world of instantons - an essential concept in quantum chromodynamics (QCD), the theory underpinning the strong nuclear force. The paper provides a comprehensive explanation of how these 'pre-historic' spacetime solutions could offer insight into the origin of light hadrons and chiral phase transitions. Despite their predominant relevance to QCD, the authors also explore the role instantons play in other models such as electroweak theory and supersymmetric QCD, suggesting a broader significance for this elusive entity.
allAuthors: Thomas Schäfer; Edward Shuryak
institutions: University of Washington; State University of New York; Stony Brook University

title: A SUPERSYMMETRY PRIMER
abstract:
I provide a pedagogical introduction to supersymmetry. The level of
discussion is aimed at readers who are familiar with the Standard Model and
quantum field theory, but who have had little or no prior exposure to
supersymmetry. Topics covered include: motivations for supersymmetry, the
construction of supersymmetric Lagrangians, superspace and superfields, soft
supersymmetry-breaking interactions, the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model
(MSSM), R-parity and its consequences, the origins of supersymmetry breaking,
the mass spectrum of the MSSM, decays of supersymmetric particles, experimental
signals for supersymmetry, and some extensions of the minimal framework.
summary:
Title: "A Comprehensive Guide to Supersymmetry: Unraveling Beyond the Standard Model"

Newspaper Article:

In a new study published in Advanced series on directions in high energy physics, Stephen P. Martin offers a pedagogical deep dive into supersymmetry – an intriguing concept that could fill gaps in our understanding of the universe beyond the Standard Model.

Targeted at readers familiar with quantum field theory but relatively novice to supersymmetry, this article covers essential topics such as motivations for its exploration, constructing supersymmetric Lagrangians, examining superspace and superfields, soft supersymmetry-breaking interactions, and the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM).

Martin's work sheds light on various aspects of this promising theoretical framework, including R-parity, its consequences, origins of supersymmetry breaking, the mass spectrum of the MSSM, decays of supersymmetric particles, and potential experimental signals for the existence of these intriguing particles.
journal: Advanced series on directions in high energy physics
allAuthors: Stephen P. Martin
institutions: University of Michigan

title: Weak transition form factors between heavy mesons
abstract: AI abstract - Weak transition form factors between heavy mesons are studied in this work, focusing on the quantification of their behavior during transitions. The results provide insights into the understanding of these interactions within the framework of particle physics, particularly in homogeneous spaces.
summary:
New Study Reveals Insights Into Interactions Between Heavy Mesons

Physicists Nathan Isgur and Mark B. Wise have delved into the world of particle physics with a new study focused on weak transition form factors between heavy mesons. The research, published in Physics Letters B, offers valuable insights into the complex behavior of these interactions, particularly within homogeneous spaces – regions known to play a crucial role in understanding particles at a fundamental level.

title: Phenomenology with massive neutrinos
abstract: AI abstract - This work presents a comprehensive review on the phenomenology of massive neutrinos, focusing on their oscillation properties and implications. The authors delve into the theoretical framework for understanding neutrino behavior in various experimental scenarios, providing insights into current understanding and future directions in this field.
summary:
Title: "Review ExploresMassive Neutrino Oscillations and Future Research Directions"

Summary:

A new report published in Physics Reports offers a comprehensive overview of the phenomenology of massive neutrinos, focusing on their oscillation properties and implications. The work, authored by M. C. González-García and Michele Maltoni, delves into the theoretical framework used to understand the behavior of these elusive particles in various experimental scenarios. By providing insights into current understanding and future directions in this field, this review aims to accelerate progress in one of physics' most intriguing mysteries: neutrino oscillation. The study draws on concepts from physics, philosophy, and neutrino research, including neutrino, neutrino oscillation, phenomenology, and experiments like MINOS.
allAuthors: M. C. González-García; Michele Maltoni

title: Discrete flavor symmetries and models of neutrino mixing
abstract: We review the application of non abelian discrete groups to the theory of neutrino masses and mixing, which is strongly suggested by the agreement of the Tri-Bimaximal mixing pattern with experiment. After summarizing the motivation and the formalism, we discuss specific models, based on A4, S4 and other finite groups, and their phenomenological implications, including lepton flavor violating processes, leptogenesis and the extension to quarks. In alternative to Tri-Bimaximal mixing the application of discrete flavor symmetries to quark-lepton complementarity and Bimaximal Mixing is also considered.
summary:
"Physics Review Explores Non-Abelian Discrete Groups for Neutrino Mixing Theory"

In a new article published in Reviews of Modern Physics, authors Guido Altarelli and Ferruccio Feruglio delve into the application of non-Abelian discrete groups to the theory of neutrino masses and mixing. The researchers focus on the Tri-Bimaximal mixing pattern, which aligns with experimental data.

The paper reviews the motivation behind this approach, outlines specific models based on A4, S4, and other finite groups, and discusses their potential implications, such as lepton flavor violating processes, leptogenesis, and extensions to quarks. Additionally, the authors consider the application of discrete flavor symmetries to quark-lepton complementarity and Bimaximal Mixing.
allAuthors: Guido Altarelli; Ferruccio Feruglio
institutions: Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma Tre; Roma Tre University

title: HERWIG 5.1 - a Monte Carlo event generator for simulating hadron emission reactions with interfering gluons
abstract: AI abstract - This paper introduces HERWIG 5.1, a Monte Carlo event generator for simulating hadron emission reactions in particle physics, with particular focus on interfering gluons and parton shower effects, contributing significantly to the understanding of high-energy collisions. The newly developed version offers improved accuracy and efficiency for event generation in various hadronic processes, providing valuable tools for experimentalists and theorists alike.
summary:
Title: New Event Generator Simulates High-Energy Collisions with Improved Precision

In a recent publication in Computer Physics Communications, a team of scientists led by G. Marchesini and B.R. Webber have introduced HERWIG 5.1, a next-generation event generator for simulating hadron emission reactions in particle physics. The novelty lies in the improved focus on interfering gluons and parton shower effects, providing a significant boost to understanding high-energy collisions.

The updated version provides both enhanced accuracy and efficiency for a multitude of hadronic processes, making it an essential tool for experimentalists and theorists alike, as they strive to advance our knowledge in particle physics.

title: Glauber Modeling in High-Energy Nuclear Collisions
abstract: We review the theoretical background, experimental techniques, and phenomenology of what is known in relativistic heavy ion physics as the Glauber model, which is used to calculate geometric quantities. A brief history of the original Glauber model is presented, with emphasis on its development into the purely classical, geometric picture used for present-day data analyses. Distinctions are made between the optical limit and Monte Carlo approaches, which are often used interchangeably but have some essential differences in particular contexts. The methods used by the four RHIC experiments are compared and contrasted, although the end results are reassuringly similar for the various geometric observables. Finally, several important RHIC measurements are highlighted that rely on geometric quantities, estimated from Glauber calculations, to draw insight from experimental observables. The status and future of Glauber modeling in the next generation of heavy ion physics studies is briefly discussed.
summary:
Newspaper Headline: "Glauber Model Shines Light on High-Energy Nuclear Collisions"
Summary:
A new review paper published in Annual Review of Nuclear and Particle Science by M. L. Miller, et al. delves into the Glauber model, a crucial tool used in relativistic heavy ion physics to calculate geometric quantities in high-energy nuclear collisions. The analysis offers insights into the history, techniques, and practical applications of the model, which have evolved from its original form into a purely classical, geometric picture essential for contemporary data analyses. Distinctions are made between the optical limit and Monte Carlo approaches, with each method's unique benefits emphasized in specific contexts. The research highlights comparisons among four RHIC experiments, revealing reassuringly consistent results across different observables. Important nuclear collision measurements relying on geometric quantities, estimated from Glauber calculations, are underscored as offering key insights into experimental data. Looking ahead to future heavy ion physics studies, the paper discusses the current status and anticipated developments in Glauber modeling.
journal: Annual Review of Nuclear and Particle Science
allAuthors: M. L. Miller; Klaus Johannes Reygers; S. Sanders; P. Steinberg
institutions: Massachusetts Institute of Technology; University of Münster; University of Kansas; Brookhaven National Laboratory

title: Cosmological parameters from SDSS and WMAP
abstract: We measure cosmological parameters using the three-dimensional power spectrum P(k) from over 200,000 galaxies in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) in combination with WMAP and other data. Our results are consistent with a ``vanilla'' flat adiabatic Lambda-CDM model without tilt (n=1), running tilt, tensor modes or massive neutrinos. Adding SDSS information more than halves the WMAP-only error bars on some parameters, tightening 1 sigma constraints on the Hubble parameter from h~0.74+0.18-0.07 to h~0.70+0.04-0.03, on the matter density from Omega_m~0.25+/-0.10 to Omega_m~0.30+/-0.04 (1 sigma) and on neutrino masses from <11 eV to <0.6 eV (95%). SDSS helps even more when dropping prior assumptions about curvature, neutrinos, tensor modes and the equation of state. Our results are in substantial agreement with the joint analysis of WMAP and the 2dF Galaxy Redshift Survey, which is an impressive consistency check with independent redshift survey data and analysis techniques. In this paper, we place particular emphasis on clarifying the physical origin of the constraints, i.e., what we do and do not know when using different data sets and prior assumptions. For instance, dropping the assumption that space is perfectly flat, the WMAP-only constraint on the measured age of the Universe tightens from t0~16.3+2.3-1.8 Gyr to t0~14.1+1.0-0.9 Gyr by adding SDSS and SN Ia data. Including tensors, running tilt, neutrino mass and equation of state in the list of free parameters, many constraints are still quite weak, but future cosmological measurements from SDSS and other sources should allow these to be substantially tightened.
summary:
Title: "SDSS Data Bolsters 'Vanilla' Cosmology Model, Halving Error Margins"

Summary:
A group of researchers have combined data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) with WMAP and other sources to measure cosmological parameters more accurately. The study, published in Physical Review D, supports a standard "vanilla" flat adiabatic Lambda-CDM model without tilt, running tilt, tensor modes or massive neutrinos. The SDSS data significantly improves the precision of key parameters such as the Hubble parameter, matter density and neutrino masses. The researchers found that dropping assumptions about space curvature and adding SDSS data improved the constraints on the age of the universe and other cosmological factors. Future measurements from SDSS and other sources are expected to provide even tighter constraints on these factors.
