title: Multiphase transport model for relativistic heavy ion collisions
abstract: We describe in detail how the different components of a multi-phase transport (AMPT) model, that uses the Heavy Ion Jet Interaction Generator (HIJING) for generating the initial conditions, Zhang's Parton Cascade (ZPC) for modeling partonic scatterings, the Lund string fragmentation model or a quark coalescence model for hadronization, and A Relativistic Transport (ART) model for treating hadronic scatterings, are improved and combined to give a coherent description of the dynamics of relativistic heavy ion collisions. We also explain the way parameters in the model are determined, and discuss the sensitivity of predicted results to physical input in the model. Comparisons of these results to experimental data, mainly from heavy ion collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC), are then made in order to extract information on the properties of the hot dense matter formed in these collisions.
summary:
Headline: Scientists Present Advanced Model for Understanding High-Speed Collisions of Heavy Atomic Nuclei

Summary:
In a new study published in PRC, scientists have developed an improved multi-phase transport model (AMPT) to enhance the understanding of relativistic heavy ion collisions. The detailed work explains how component parts—from initial conditions generated by the Heavy Ion Jet Interaction Generator (HIJING), to modeling partonic scatterings via Zhang's Parton Cascade (ZPC), and treatments of hadronic scattering through A Relativistic Transport (ART) model, among others—were combined for a coherent description of these intricate collisions. Parameters within the comprehensive AMPT model were also determined, with sensitivity to physical input examined. Crucially, the researchers compared their findings from heavy ion collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) to experimental data in order to provide insights into the properties of the matter created during these high-speed encounters.
allAuthors: Zi-Wei Lin; Che Ming Ko; Bao-An Li; Bin Zhang; Subrata Pal
institutions: The Ohio State University; Texas A&M University; Arkansas State University; Michigan State University

title: Can the mass of the lightest Higgs boson of the minimal supersymmetric model be larger than<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mi mathvariant="italic">m</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi mathvariant="italic">Z</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:math>?
abstract: In the minimal supersymmetric model (MSSM), the tree-level mass of the lightest Higgs scalar ${\mathit{h}}^{0}$ cannot be larger than the mass of the Z boson. We have computed the one-loop radiative correction to the upper bound on ${\mathit{m}}_{\mathit{h}}^{0}$ as a function of the free parameters of the MSSM. We find that the dominant correction to ${\mathit{m}}_{\mathit{h}}^{0}$-${\mathit{m}}_{\mathit{Z}}$ is large and positive and grows like ${\mathit{m}}_{\mathit{t}}^{4}$, where ${\mathit{m}}_{\mathit{t}}$ is the top-quark mass. As a result, the MSSM cannot be ruled out if the CERN ${\mathit{e}}^{+}$${\mathit{e}}^{\mathrm{\ensuremath{-}}}$ collider LEP-200 fails to discover the Higgs boson.
summary:
Scientists challenge conventional wisdom in new study on the Higgs boson

Two physicists, Howard E. Haber and Ralf Hempfling, have proposed a theory which suggests the mass of the lightest Higgs boson in the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model could be larger than previously believed.

In their paper published in Physical Review Letters, the duo argue that one-loop radiative corrections significantly impact the upper bound on the Higgers's mass, with the dominant correction growing like the square of the top quark mass. If confirmed, this finding could keep the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model viable even if the CERN particle collider LEP-200 fails to discover the Higgs boson as initially expected.
allAuthors: Howard E. Haber; Ralf Hempfling
institutions: University of California, Santa Cruz

title: The Next-to-Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model
abstract: We review the theoretical and phenomenological aspects of the Next-to-Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model: the Higgs sector including radiative corrections and the 2-loop β-functions for all parameters of the general NMSSM; the tadpole and domain wall problems, baryogenesis; NMSSM phenomenology at colliders, B physics and dark matter; specific scenarios as the constrained NMSSM, gauge mediated supersymmetry breaking, U(1)′-extensions, CP and R-parity violation.
summary:
Article Headline:
New Model Sheds Light on Particle Physics and Dark Matter

Summary:
A new study by Ulrich Ellwanger, Cyril Hugonie, and A. M. Teixeira published in a physics journal offers a comprehensive review of the Next-to-Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (NMSSM). This model delves into the Higgs sector, radiative corrections, and 2-loop beta functions of General NMSSM parameters. The research also addresses challenges like tadpole and domain wall problems, baryogenesis (the origin of matter's asymmetry), and offers insights into NMSSM phenomenology at colliders, B physics, and dark matter. Specific scenarios examined include the constrained NMSSM, gauge-mediated supersymmetry breaking, U(1)′ extensions, and CP and R-parity violation, aiming to advance our understanding of particle physics beyond the current Standard Model.

title: Dynamics of spontaneous symmetry breaking in the Weinberg-Salam theory
abstract: We argue that the existence of fundamental scalar fields constitutes a serious flaw of the Weinberg-Salam theory. A possible scheme without such fields is described. The symmetry breaking is induced by a new strongly interacting sector whose natural scale is of the order of a few TeV.
summary:
Title: Physicist Challenges Fundamental Flaw in Weinberg-Salam Theory

In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review D, Leonard Susskind proposes an alternative to the widely accepted Weinberg-Salam theory. The scholar asserts that the theory's reliance on fundamental scalar fields may be a critical weak point. To rectify this, Susskind suggests a new framework that eliminates these problematic fields, instead inducing symmetry breaking through a newly-introduced sector of strongly interacting particles with a scale around severalTeV. This work seeks to support approaches aiming to streamline and strengthen the foundations of particle physics.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Baryons in a relativized quark model with chromodynamics
abstract: We have studied the three-quark system in a relativized version of the quark potential model with chromodynamics. With parameters consistent with those of an analogous study of the qq\ifmmode\bar\else\textasciimacron\fi{} system, we obtain a good description of the known baryons. Our model generally supports the phenomenology of nonrelativistic calculations: it naturally explains the apparent absence of spin-orbit interactions in baryons, and leads to spectra and internal compositions for the baryons which are qualitatively similar to those of the usual nonrelativistic model.
summary:
"Physicists Simon Capstick and Nathan Isgur Propose Next-Level Approach to Understanding Baryons

In a new study published in Physical Review D, physicists Simon Capstick and Nathan Isgur propose a breakthrough approach using a relativized quark model with Quantum Chromodynamics. Their model aims to provide a more accurate description of known baryons, building upon previous work focused on the qq\ifmmode\bar\else\textasciimacron\fi{} system.

Their study presents a significant step in particle physics by focusing on a three-quark system. The model shows promise in supporting the phenomenology of nonrelativistic calculations, particularly in explaining the apparent absence of spin-orbit interactions in baryons."
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Constraint on the Photino Mass from Cosmology
abstract: A lower bound for the photino mass ${m}_{\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{\ensuremath{\gamma}}}$ as a function of the spin-0 fermion superpartner mass ${m}_{\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{f}}$ is derived as an extension of the calculation of Lee and Weinberg. The Majorana nature of the photino induces a $p$-wave threshold for annihilation $\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{\ensuremath{\gamma}}\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{\ensuremath{\gamma}}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}f\overline{f}$ into light fermions, and leads to a rather unexpected form for the bound: for $25 \mathrm{GeV}\ensuremath{\lesssim}{m}_{\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{f}}\ensuremath{\lesssim}45 \mathrm{GeV}$, ${({m}_{\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{\ensuremath{\gamma}}})}_{min}\ensuremath{\simeq}{m}_{\ensuremath{\tau}}=1.8$ GeV; for ${m}_{\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{f}}>45$ GeV, ${({m}_{\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{\ensuremath{\gamma}}})}_{min}$ increases approximately linearly with ${m}_{\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{f}}$ to a value of 20 GeV when ${m}_{\stackrel{\ifmmode \tilde{}\else \~{}\fi{}}{f}}=100$ GeV.
summary:
**Physicist sets lower limit on 'photino' mass, challenging Lee and Weinberg calculation**

In a new paper published in Physical Review Letters, Dr. Haim Goldberg challenges the previous calculations of particle physicists Lee and Weinberg concerning the mass of photinos - hypothetical fermionic counterparts of the photon. The study extends their work by taking into account the Majorana nature of photinos, which induces a p-wave threshold for annihilation, leading to an unexpected lower bound.

For spin-0 fermion superpartners with masses between 25 and 45 GeV, Goldberg's findings indicate a minimum photino mass of approximately 1.8 GeV (equal to the mass of a tau lepton). For higher mass superpartners, the calculated lower limit on the photino mass increases linearly, reaching 20 GeV for superpartner masses of 100 GeV. This new study provides valuable insight into the potential properties and behaviors of these enigmatic particles in particle physics.
allAuthors: Haim Goldberg
institutions: Northeastern University

title: Scaling Laws at Large Transverse Momentum
abstract: The application of simple dimensional counting to bound states of pointlike particles enables us to derive scaling laws for the asymptotic energy dependence of electromagnetic and hadronic scattering at fixed c.m. angle which only depend on the number of constituent fields of the hadrons. Assuming quark constituents, some of the s→∞, fixed-ts predictions are ($\\frac{dσ}{dt}$)<sub>πp→πp</sub>~s<sup>-8</sup>, ($\\frac{dσ}{dt}$)<sub>pp→pp</sub>~s<sup>-10</sup>, ($\\frac{dσ}{dt}$)<sub>γp→πp</sub>~s<sup>-7</sup>, ($\\frac{dσ}{dt}$)<sub>γp→γp</sub>~s<sup>-6</sup>, F<sub>π</sub>(q<sup>2</sup>)~(q<sup>2</sup>)<sup>-1</sup>, and F<sub>1p</sub>(q<sup>2</sup>)~(q<sup>2</sup>)<sup>-2</sup>. We show that such scaling laws are characteristic of renormalizable field theories satisfying certain conditions.
summary:
In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review Letters, physicists Stanley J. Brodsky and Glennys R. Farrar have derived new scaling laws for energy dependence at large transverse momentum in particle scattering. The researchers apply a method involving dimensional counting to bound states of pointlike particles to make their predictions, focusing specifically on hadrons made up of quark constituents.

The study suggests that the cross-section for interactions between particles, like pions and protons, decreases dramatically with energy (squared) as follows: for πp→πp it's ~s⁻⁸, for pp→pp it's ~s⁻¹⁰, and for γp→πp it's ~s⁻7. Similarly, the study finds that the scattering between a photon (γ) and a proton (p) would exhibit a ~s⁻6 scaling. The authors also illustrate how these scaling laws are characteristic of renormalizable field theories meeting specific conditions.
allAuthors: Stanley J. Brodsky; Glennys R. Farrar
institutions: SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory; Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource; Stanford University; California Institute of Technology

title: Three exceptions in the calculation of relic abundances
abstract: The calculation of relic abundances of elementary particles by following their annihilation and freeze-out in the early Universe has become an important and standard tool in discussing particle dark-matter candidates. We find three situations, all occurring in the literature, in which the standard methods of calculating relic abundances fail. The first situation occurs when another particle lies near in mass to the relic particle and shares a quantum number with it. An example is a light squark with neutralino dark matter. The additional particle must be included in the reaction network, since its annihilation can control the relic abundance. The second situation occurs when the relic particle lies near a mass threshold. Previously, annihilation into particles heavier than the relic particle was considered kinematically forbidden, but we show that if the mass difference is \ensuremath{\sim}5-15%, these "forbidden" channels can dominate the cross section and determine the relic abundance. The third situation occurs when the annihilation takes place near a pole in the cross section. Proper treatment of the thermal averaging and the annihilation after freeze-out shows that the dip in relic abundance caused by a pole is not nearly as sharp or deep as previously thought.
summary:
Physicists propose corrections to standard model for dark matter calculations

In a new paper published in the Journal of Physical Review (D), physicists K. Griest and D. Seckel identify three significant exceptions that challenge the current methods used to calculate relic abundances of particle dark matter candidates. The team suggests improvements by taking into account additional particles sharing quantum numbers, near-mass thresholds, and annihilation poles in cross sections that were previously thought negligible.

The paper's focus is on particle physics, delving into the realm of annihilation processes within dark matter research. The authors uncover crucial oversights in existing methodologies when dealing with matters such as light squarks and neutralinos, mass thresholds, and cross-section poles. Their findings suggest revising the calculation of relic abundances to account for these exceptions, offering valuable guidance for future studies in this vital field.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: K. Griest; D. Seckel

title: A review of the open charm and open bottom systems
abstract: Since the discovery of the first charmed meson in 1976, many open-charm and open-bottom hadrons were observed. In 2003 two narrow charm-strange states [Formula: see text] and D <sub>s1</sub>(2460) were discovered by the BaBar and CLEO Collaborations, respectively. After that, more excited heavy hadrons were reported. In this work, we review the experimental and theoretical progress in this field.

Title: "Review of open charm and open bottom systems offers new insights into particle physics"

title: The physics of heavy<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:msup><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msup></mml:math>gauge bosons
abstract: The U(1)' symmetry associated with a possible heavy Z' would have profound implications for particle physics and cosmology. The motivations for such particles in various extensions of the standard model, possible ranges for their masses and couplings, and classes of anomaly-free models are discussed. Present limits from electroweak and collider experiments are briefly surveyed, as are prospects for discovery and diagnostic study at future colliders. Implications of a Z' are discussed, including an extended Higgs sector, extended neutralino sector, and solution to the mu problem in supersymmetry; exotic fermions needed for anomaly cancellation; possible flavor changing neutral current effects; neutrino mass; possible Z' mediation of supersymmetry breaking; and cosmological implications for cold dark matter and electroweak baryogenesis.
summary:
Title: Exploring the Physics of Potential Heavy Z' Gauge Bosons

In a groundbreaking study published in Reviews of Modern Physics, renowned physicist Paul Langacker delves into the intriguing world of heavy Z' gauge bosons. This exploration expands on theories beyond the Standard Model of particle physics, addressing their potential implications for particle interactions and cosmology.

The paper discusses various extensions to the standard model that might necessitate the existence of heavy Z' particles, their possible mass ranges, and anomaly-free models. Langacker also reviews current limits from electroweak and collider experiments while outlining possibilities for their discovery and further study at future colliders.

Key aspects considered include an expanded Higgs sector, enlarged neutralino sector, and a solution to the mu problem in supersymmetry; requirements for exotic fermions required for anomaly cancellation; potential for flavor changing neutral current effects; neutrino mass exploration; possible Z' mediation of supersymmetry breaking; and cosmological implications for dark matter and electroweak baryogenesis.

title: Left-right gauge symmetry and an "isoconjugate" model of<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi>CP</mml:mi></mml:math>violation
abstract: Left-right symmetry in the starting gauge interactions provides the basis for an "isoconjugate" model of $\mathrm{CP}$ violation with the consequence that ${\ensuremath{\eta}}_{+\ensuremath{-}}={\ensuremath{\eta}}_{00}$. The magnitude of $\mathrm{CP}$ violation is naturally suppressed at least to the extent that $V+A$ interactions are suppressed in nature compared to the $V\ensuremath{-}A$ interactions. This allows the possibility that intrinsic $\mathrm{CP}$-violating phase (arising through spontaneous symmetry breaking, for example) may have a maximal character, which may reveal itself at intermediate high energies to possibly disappear at still higher energies. $\mathrm{CP}$ violation in leptonic, semileptonic, and $\ensuremath{\Delta}Y=0$ parity-violating nonleptonic interactions (which could contribute to the electric dipole moment of the neutron) arise on the one hand in fourth order of the weak gauge interactions and on the other via Yukawa interactions between fermions and leftover Higgs mesons as well as via ${W}_{L}\ensuremath{-}{W}_{R}$ mixing. The magnitude of the latter contributions may be limited to be less than or of order ${G}_{F}\ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{}{10}^{\ensuremath{-}4}$ in order that the experimentally observed relation ${\ensuremath{\eta}}_{+\ensuremath{-}}={\ensuremath{\eta}}_{00}$ may hold at least to a few percent. Thus the electric dipole moment of the neutron ${d}_{n}$ is expected to be less than or of order ${10}^{\ensuremath{-}24}e$ cm. $\mathrm{CP}$ violation in all $|\ensuremath{\Delta}S|=1$ nonleptonic decays ($Y\ensuremath{\rightarrow}N+\ensuremath{\pi}$, etc.) should, in general, have the same order of magnitude as $|{\ensuremath{\eta}}_{+\ensuremath{-}}|$.
summary:
Headline: Physicists propose new model for CP violation in particle interactions

Summary:
In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review D, physicists Rabindra N. Mohapatra and Jogesh C. Pati present an innovative "isoconjugate" model of CP (charge-parity) violation based on left-right symmetry. This new model could potentially explain the suppression of CP violation seen in nature, where V+A (vector plus axial vector) interactions are weaker compared to V-A interactions. The researchers suggest that at intermediate high energies, intrinsic CP-violating phases may exhibit maximal character, possibly vanishing at higher energies. The model further predicts CP violation in leptonic, semileptonic, and certain nonleptonic interactions, which might contribute to the electric dipole moment of the neutron, theoretically estimated to be less than or equal to ${10}^{-24} e$ cm. The study could have significant implications for understanding and predicting CP violation in various particle decays.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Rabindra N. Mohapatra; Jogesh C. Pati
institutions: University of Maryland, College Park

title: String axiverse
abstract:
String theory suggests the simultaneous presence of many ultralight axions
possibly populating each decade of mass down to the Hubble scale 10^-33eV.
Conversely the presence of such a plenitude of axions (an "axiverse") would be
evidence for string theory, since it arises due to the topological complexity
of the extra-dimensional manifold and is ad hoc in a theory with just the four
familiar dimensions. We investigate how upcoming astrophysical experiments will
explore the existence of such axions over a vast mass range from 10^-33eV to
10^-10eV. Axions with masses between 10^-33eV to 10^-28eV cause a rotation of
the CMB polarization that is constant throughout the sky. The predicted
rotation angle is of order \alpha~1/137. Axions in the mass range 10^-28eV to
10^-18eV give rise to multiple steps in the matter power spectrum, that will be
probed by upcoming galaxy surveys. Axions in the mass range 10^-22eV to
10^-10eV affect the dynamics and gravitational wave emission of rapidly
rotating astrophysical black holes through the Penrose superradiance process.
When the axion Compton wavelength is of order of the black hole size, the
axions develop "superradiant" atomic bound states around the black hole
"nucleus". Their occupation number grows exponentially by extracting rotational
energy from the ergosphere, culminating in a rotating Bose-Einstein axion
condensate emitting gravitational waves. This mechanism creates mass gaps in
the spectrum of rapidly rotating black holes that diagnose the presence of
axions. The rapidly rotating black hole in the X-ray binary LMC X-1 implies an
upper limit on the decay constant of the QCD axion f_a<2*10^17GeV, much below
the Planck mass. This reach can be improved down to the grand unification scale
f_a<2*10^16GeV, by observing smaller stellar mass black holes.
summary:
New Study Explores Possibility of a "String Axiverse" Invisible Particles

In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review D, researchers led by Asimina Arvanitaki propose the existence of a vast array of ultralight axions known as a "string axiverse." This research, which builds upon previous work in particle physics and axion theory, suggests that string theory may be validated by the presence of these extra axions.

The team investigates how upcoming astrophysical experiments could confirm the existence of such axions over a wide mass range from 10^-33eV to 10^-10eV. Axions in specific mass ranges impact components of cosmic microwave background polarization, matter power spectrum, and gravitational wave emission in rapidly rotating astrophysical black holes, providing unique opportunities for detection. The research provides insights into the potential implications, such as diagnosing the presence of axions and creating mass gaps in the spectrum of rapidly rotating black holes, which could revolutionize our understanding of dark matter and particle physics.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology
allAuthors: Asimina Arvanitaki; Savas Dimopoulos; Sergei Dubovsky; Nemanja Kaloper; John March-Russell

title: Observation of a neutrino burst from the supernova SN1987A
abstract: A neutrino burst was observed in the Kamiokande II detector on 23 February, 7:35:35 UT (\ifmmode\pm\else\textpm\fi{}1 min) during a time interval of 13 sec. The signal consisted of 11 electron events of energy 7.5 to 36 MeV, of which the first two point back to the Large Magellanic Cloud with angles 18\ifmmode^\circ\else\textdegree\fi{}\ifmmode\pm\else\textpm\fi{}18\ifmmode^\circ\else\textdegree\fi{} and 15\ifmmode^\circ\else\textdegree\fi{}\ifmmode\pm\else\textpm\fi{}27\ifmmode^\circ\else\textdegree\fi{}.
summary:
Newsworthy Findings: Neutrino Burst Detected from Supernova SN1987A

A groundbreaking observation of a neutrino burst has been reported by a team of international researchers, led by Keiko Hirata and T. Kajita. The discovery was made on February 23, 1987, using the Kamiokande II detector, during a time interval of 13 seconds.The burst consisted of 11 high-energy electron events, which originated from the direction of the Large Magellanic Cloud, providing compelling evidence for the first detection of neutrinos from a celestial source — the supernova SN1987A. The researchers' findings not only support the theory that supernovae are primarily powered by neutrino interactions but also open new avenues towards understanding cosmic energy signals and stellar phenomena.

title: Nonstandard heavy mesons and baryons: Experimental evidence
abstract:
Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the generally accepted theory for the strong
interactions, describes the interactions between quarks and gluons. The
strongly interacting particles that are seen in nature are hadrons, which are
composites of quarks and gluons. Since QCD is a strongly coupled theory at
distance scales that are characteristic of observable hadrons, there are no
rigorous, first-principle methods to derive the spectrum and properties of the
hadrons from the QCD Lagrangian, except for Lattice QCD simulations that are
not yet able to cope with all aspects of complex and short-lived states.
Instead, a variety of "QCD inspired" phenomenological models have been
proposed. Common features of these models are predictions for the existence of
hadrons with substructures that are more complex than the standard
quark-antiquark mesons and the three quark baryons of the original quark model
that provides a concise description of most of the low-mass hadrons. Recently,
an assortment of candidates for non-standard multi-quark mesons, meson-gluon
hybrids and pentaquark baryons that contain heavy (charm or bottom) quarks have
been discovered. Here we review the experimental evidence for these states and
make some general comparisons of their measured properties with standard
quark-model expectations and predictions of various models for non-standard
hadrons. We conclude that the spectroscopy of all but simplest hadrons is not
yet understood.
summary:
Physical Review: Experts explore puzzling new particles - Newly discovered heavy mesons and multi-quark baryons could redefine physics understanding

A team of experts have reviewed experimental evidence for a variety of newly discovered particles that challenge conventional wisdom in particle physics, as reported in the latest issue of Reviews of Modern Physics. These particles, known as nonstandard multi-quark mesons, meson-gluon hybrids and pentaquark baryons, contradict basic expectations set by Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the current accepted theory for strong interactions between particles.

The researchers highlight that these complex hadrons with heavy quarks were previously undetectable due to their short lifespan and complexity. They discuss the experimental evidence for these states, comparing them with standard quark-model expectations and predictions of various models for nonstandard hadrons. The study suggests that our current understanding of particle spectroscopy remains incomplete, hinting at significant advancements needed within the field.
allAuthors: S. L. Olsen; T. Skwarnicki; D. Ziemińska
institutions: Institute for Basic Science; Syracuse University; Indiana University Bloomington

title: Topology of cosmic domains and strings
abstract: The possible domain structures which can arise in the universe in a spontaneously broken gauge theory are studied. It is shown that the formation of domain wall, strings or monopoles depends on the homotopy groups of the manifold of degenerate vacua. The subsequent evolution of these structures is investigated. It is argued that while theories generating domain walls can probably be eliminated (because of their unacceptable gravitational effects), a cosmic network of strings may well have been formed and may have had important cosmological effects.
summary:
Paper Title: "Cosmic Strings Network Could Have Altered the Universe's Evolution"

In a groundbreaking study featured in the Journal of Physics A Mathematical and General, renowned physicist T. W. B. Kibble explores the potential structures that could have emerged in the universe due to spontaneously broken gauge theories.

The research focuses on cosmic strings, one-dimensional entities with enormous energy density. According to the paper, these strings' formation and evolution are influenced by the homotopy groups of the manifold of degenerate vacua.

Kibble argues that theories suggesting domain walls may be eliminated due to their detrimental gravitational effects. However, a network of cosmic strings could have played a significant role in the universe's development, according to the study. This finding could revolutionize our understanding of cosmological phenomena.
journal: Journal of Physics A Mathematical and General

title: Charmonium: Comparison with experiment
abstract: The charmonium model, formulated in detail in an earlier publication, is compared in a comprehensive fashion with the data on the $\ensuremath{\psi}$ family. The parameters of the "naive" model, in which the system is described as a $c\overline{c}$ pair, are determined from the observed positions of $\ensuremath{\psi}$, ${\ensuremath{\psi}}^{\ensuremath{'}}$, and the $P$ states. The model then yields a successful description of the spectrum of spin-triplet states above the charm threshold. It also accounts for the ratio of the leptonic widths of ${\ensuremath{\psi}}^{\ensuremath{'}}$ and $\ensuremath{\psi}$. When the $c\overline{c}$ potential is applied to the $\ensuremath{\Upsilon}$ family, it accounts, without any readjustment of parameters, for the positions of the $2S$ and $3S$ levels and for the leptonic widths of $\ensuremath{\Upsilon}$ and ${\ensuremath{\Upsilon}}^{\ensuremath{'}}$ relative to that of $\ensuremath{\psi}$. The model does not give acceptable values of the absolute leptonic widths, a shortcoming which is ascribed to large quantum-chromodynamic corrections to the van Royen-Weisskopf formula. The calculated $E1$ rates are about twice the values observed in the $\ensuremath{\psi}$ family. This naive model is also extended with considerable success to mesons composed of one heavy and one light quark. A significant extension of the model is achieved by incorporating coupling to charmed-meson decay channels. This gives a satisfactory understanding of $\ensuremath{\psi}(3772)$ as the $1^{3}D_{1}$ $c\overline{c}$ state, mixed via open and closed decay channels to $2^{3}S$. The model has decay amplitudes that are oscillatory functions of the decay momentum; these oscillations are a direct consequence of the radial nodes in the $c\overline{c}$ parent states. These amplitudes provide a qualitative understanding of the observed peculiar branching ratios into various charmed-meson channels near the resonance at 4.03 GeV, which is assigned to $3^{3}S$. The coupling of the $c\overline{c}$ states below the charm threshold to closed decay channels modifies the bound states and leads to reduction of about 20% in $E1$ rates in comparison to those of the naive model.
summary:
**Physics Breakthrough: New Model Successfully Predicts Charmonium and Upsilon Spectra**

A groundbreaking study by Eichten et al., published in Physical Review D, presents a detailed 'charmonium' model that explains the spectrum and properties of charmonium and bottomonium states. The team analyzes the $\psi$ family of charmonia, using the model to predict the positions of the $\psi$, ${\psi}'$, and P states with remarkable accuracy.

The study further extends to the $\Upsilon$ family without adjusting parameters, accounting for the positions of the $2S$ and $3S$ levels and leptonic width ratios. However, absolute leptonic widths are underestimated due to substantial quantum-chromodynamic corrections to a standard formula.

The model also explains the observed peculiar branching ratios into various charmed-meson channels near the resonance at 4.03 GeV. The incorporation of coupling to charmed-meson decay channels provides insights into the nature of the $\psi(3772)$ as a mixed $1^{3}D_{1}$ state and the resonance at 4.03 GeV as $3^{3}S$. The model's decay amplitudes are oscillatory functions of the decay momentum, shedding light on these intriguing phenomena.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

institutions: Cornell University

title: Chiral magnetic effect
abstract: Topological charge changing transitions can induce chirality in the quark-gluon plasma by the axial anomaly. We study the equilibrium response of the quark-gluon plasma in such a situation to an external magnetic field. To mimic the effect of the topological charge changing transitions we will introduce a chiral chemical potential. We will show that an electromagnetic current is generated along the magnetic field. This is the Chiral Magnetic Effect. We compute the magnitude of this current as a function of magnetic field, chirality, temperature, and baryon chemical potential.
summary:
Physical Review D publishes groundbreaking research on Chiral Magnetic Effect

Researchers Kenji Fukushima, Dmitri E. Kharzeev, and Harmen J. Warringa have made significant strides in understanding the Chiral Magnetic Effect (CME). The study explores the behavior of quark-gluon plasma in response to an external magnetic field, given a scenario where topological charge changing transitions induce chirality. To simulate this effect, they introduce a "chiral chemical potential." The team's findings show that an electromagnetic current is generated along the magnetic field—a phenomenon known as the Chiral Magnetic Effect. They have computed the magnitude of this current in relation to magnetic field strength, chirality, temperature, and baryon chemical potential, advancing our comprehension of this fascinating physical phenomenon.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology

title: Precision corrections in the minimal supersymmetric standard model
abstract:
In this paper we compute one-loop corrections to masses and couplings in the
minimal supersymmetric standard model. We present explicit formulae for the
complete corrections and a set of compact approximations which hold over the
unified parameter space associated with radiative electroweak symmetry
breaking. We illustrate the importance of the corrections and the accuracy of
our approximations by scanning over the parameter space. We calculate the
supersymmetric one-loop corrections to the W-boson mass, the effective weak
mixing angle, and the quark and lepton masses, and discuss implications for
gauge and Yukawa coupling unification. We also compute the one-loop corrections
to the entire superpartner and Higgs-boson mass spectrum. We find significant
corrections over much of the parameter space, and illustrate that our
approximations are good to O(1%) for many of the superparticle masses.
summary:
Title: New calculations offer refined insights into supersymmetry

In a new study published in Nuclear Physics B, researchers led by Damien M. Pierce, Jonathan Bagger, K. Matchev, and Renjie Zhang have made significant strides in the realm of particle physics. The paper focuses on the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM), expanding existing knowledge about electroweak interactions and Yukawa potentials.

The researchers have calculated one-loop corrections to masses and coupling constants within the MSSM, providing explicit formulas for the complete corrections and a set of compact approximations suitable for the unified parameter space related to radiative electroweak symmetry breaking. The study's importance lies in its implications for gauge and Yukawa coupling unification, offering a more refined understanding of supersymmetry.

The findings demonstrate significant corrections over a large portion of the parameter space, with the authors' approximations proving accurate to within 1% for many superparticle masses. The paper also delves into the one-loop corrections associated with the entire superpartner and Higgs boson mass spectrum, offering valuable insights for future research in particle physics and supersymmetry.
allAuthors: Damien M. Pierce; Jonathan Bagger; K. Matchev; Renjie Zhang
institutions: Stanford University; Johns Hopkins University

title: Effects of Superheavy Quarks and Leptons in Low-Energy Weak Processes KL-> Formula, K+-> + Formula and K0 Formula0
abstract: We investigate potentially important effects due to the existence of superheavy quarks and leptons of the sequential type in higher-order weak processes at low energies. The second-order ΔS≠0 neutral-current processes KL→µµ, K+→π+νν and KL-KS mass difference are analysed allowing for fermions of masses comparable to or larger than the weak-boson mass in the Kobayashi-Maskawa scheme and in the general sequential scheme with an arbitrary number of generations. Possible connection between heavy-quark masses and light-heavy quark mixing are also examined. The requirement that the rare decay processes such as KL→µµ and K+→π+νν be absent up to order αGF yields a rather stringent bound on the magnitude of light-heavy quark mixing: Such mixing has to be less than mW/mQuark times a factor much smaller than unity.
summary:
Title: New Study Sheds Light on Superheavy Quarks and Leptons in Low-Energy Weak Processes

A new research paper published in Progress of Theoretical Physics explores the potential effects of superheavy quarks and leptons on low-energy weak processes, such as KL→μμ, K+→π+νν, and K0 mass difference. Authored by T. Inami and Chin Seong Lim, the study investigates these effects within higher-order weak processes, particularly in the context of the Kobayashi-Maskawa scheme and the general sequential scheme with an arbitrary number of generations.

The research aims to understand the possible connection between heavy-quark masses and light-heavy quark mixing, delving into the implications of rare decay processes like KL→μμ and K+→π+νν. The work concludes that light-heavy quark mixing must be less than mW/mQuark times a factor much smaller than unity, providing a stringent bound on this critical aspect of particle physics. This exciting study continues our understanding of the intricate world of particles and their interactions.
allAuthors: T. Inami; Chin Seong Lim
institutions: The University of Tokyo

The study's central aim is to understand these concepts and their implications for gauge bosons and their interactions within the context of local symmetry. This work could potentially reshape our understanding of particle behavior, offering significant advancements in particle physics research.
allAuthors: Masako Bando; Taichiro Kugo; Koichi Yamawaki
institutions: Aichi University; Kyoto University; Nagoya University

title: Detectability of certain dark-matter candidates
abstract: We consider the possibility that the neutral-current neutrino detector recently proposed by Drukier and Stodolsky could be used to detect some possible candidates for the dark matter in galactic halos. This may be feasible if the galactic halos are made of particles with coherent weak interactions and masses 1--${10}^{6}$ GeV; particles with spin-dependent interactions of typical weak strength and masses 1--${10}^{2}$ GeV; or strongly interacting particles of masses 1--${10}^{13}$ GeV.
summary:
Title: New Approach for Potential Dark Matter Detection in Galactic Halos

New research led by physicists Mark W. Goodman and Edward Witten suggests that a neutral-current neutrino detector could be used to detect dark matter candidates within galactic halos. The study focuses on particles with coherent weak interactions, masses ranging from 1 GeV to ${10}^{6}$ GeV; particles with spin-dependent interactions of typical weak strength and masses between 1 GeV to ${10}^{2}$ GeV; and strongly interacting particles at masses up to ${10}^{13}$ GeV. If this method proves viable, it could pave the way for significant advancements in understanding dark matter compositions within our galaxy. [Physical Review D: Particles, Fields, Gravitation and Cosmology]
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Mark W. Goodman; Edward Witten
institutions: Princeton University

title: Neutrino mass and baryon-number nonconservation in superstring models
abstract: We propose new mechanisms for understanding neutrino masses in superstring models that contain E6-singlet zero-mass fields after compactification. We show that the low-energy gauge group of these models can be phenomenologically acceptable. We then comment on ΔB=1 and ΔB=2 baryon-number-violating processes in these models.
summary:
**Newton's Apple Daily, August 29**

Physicists Propose Novel Mechanisms for Neutrino Mass Exploration in Superstring Models

Rabindra N. Mohapatra and J.W.F. Valle of the Physical Review journal propose a groundbreaking study that could shed light on neutrino mass in superstring models. The researchers focus on models containing E6-singlet zero-mass fields after compactification, suggesting potential for phenomenologically acceptable low-energy gauge groups.

The study also offers insights into baryon-number violating processes within these models, providing a new direction for research on neutrino mass and its implications in the realm of particle physics. This work continues the ongoing exploration of neutrinos as elusive particles with zero charge but nonzero mass, and superstring theory as a framework linking all fundamental forces.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Rabindra N. Mohapatra; J. W. F. Valle
institutions: University of Maryland, College Park

title: Equations of state for supernovae and compact stars
abstract: A review is given of various theoretical approaches for the equation of state (EoS) of dense matter, relevant for the description of core-collapse supernovae, compact stars, and compact star mergers. The emphasis is put on models that are applicable to all of these scenarios. Such EoS models have to cover large ranges in baryon number density, temperature, and isospin asymmetry. The characteristics of matter change dramatically within these ranges, from a mixture of nucleons, nuclei, and electrons to uniform, strongly interacting matter containing nucleons, and possibly other particles such as hyperons or quarks. As the development of an EoS requires joint efforts from many directions, different theoretical approaches are considered and relevant experimental and observational constraints which provide insights for future research are discussed. Finally, results from applications of the discussed EoS models are summarized.
summary:
Title: New Equation Approaches Shed Light on Supernova & Compact Star Mysteries

Scientists have published a comprehensive review in Reviews of Modern Physics that outlines several theoretical methods to study the equation of state (EoS) of dense matter, crucial for understanding core-collapse supernovae, compact stars, and mergers. The approaches, focusing on models applicable across all these scenarios, aim to cover vast ranges of baryon number density, temperature, and isospin asymmetry.

As the research uncovers the transformation of matter within these ranges—from a mix of nucleons, nuclei, and electrons to strongly interacting matter containing potential additions like hyperons or quarks—it marks a significant step towards understanding the behavior of celestial bodies in extreme conditions. The authors emphasize the collaborative nature of EoS development, considering multiple theoretical approaches and discussing crucial experimental and observational constraints for future research. Overall, the study aims to pave the way for a better understanding of stellar phenomena and the properties of dense matter.
allAuthors: Micaela Oertel; Matthias Hempel; T. Klähn; S. Typel
institutions: Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique; Délégation Paris 7; Laboratoire Univers et Théories; Sorbonne Paris Cité; Université Paris Cité; Université Paris Sciences et Lettres

title: The search for heavy Majorana neutrinos
abstract:
The Majorana nature of neutrinos can be experimentally verified only via {\it
lepton-number} violating processes involving charged leptons. We study 36
lepton-number violating ($\lv$) processes from the decays of tau leptons and
pseudoscalar mesons. These decays are absent in the Standard Model but, in
presence of Majorana neutrinos in the mass range $\sim 100 \mev$ to $5 \gev$,
the rates for these processes would be enhanced due to their resonant
contribution. We calculate the transition rates and branching fractions and
compare them to the current bounds from direct experimental searches for
$\dl=2$ tau and rare meson decays. The experimental non-observation of such
$\lv$ processes places stringent bounds on the Majorana neutrino mass and
mixing and we summarize the existing limits. We also extend the search to
hadron collider experiments. We find that, at the Tevatron with $8 {fb}^{-1}$
integrated luminosity, there could be $2\sigma$ ($5\sigma$) sensitivity for
resonant production of a Majorana neutrino in the $\mu^\pm \mu^\pm$ modes in
the mass range of $\sim 10 - 180 {\gev} (10 - 120 {\gev})$. This reach can be
extended to $\sim 10 - 375 {\gev} (10 - 250 mbox{\gev})$ at the LHC of 14 TeV
with $100 {fb}^{-1}$. The production cross section at the LHC of 10 TeV is also
presented for comparison. We study the $\mu^\pm e^\pm$ modes as well and find
that the signal could be large enough even taking into account the current
bound from neutrinoless double-beta decay. The signal from the gauge boson
fusion channel $W^+ W^+\to \ell^+_1 \ell^+_2$ at the LHC is found to be very
weak given the rather small mixing parameters. We comment on the search
strategy when a $\tau$ lepton is involved in the final state.
summary:
Title: New Study Sheds Light on Search for Heavy Majorana Neutrinos

In an exciting new development, physicists Anupama Atre and collaborators have outlined a strategy to detect heavy Majorana neutrinos. This work, published in Journal of High Energy Physics, builds upon the concept that the Majorana nature of neutrinos can only be verified through lepton-number violating processes involving charged leptons like tau leptons and pseudoscalar mesons.

The researchers focus on 36 such lepton-number violating processes, which occur more frequently in the presence of Majorana neutrinos with masses ranging from 100 MeV to 5 GeV. The team calculates transition rates, branching fractions, and compares them to current experimental bounds, setting new stringent limits on the Majorana neutrino mass and mixing.

The study extends the search for these elusive particles to hadron collider experiments. Notably, the Tevatron with 8 fb-1 integrated luminosity could have a 2σ (5σ) sensitivity for resonant production of a Majorana neutrino in the μ± μ± mass range of 10 - 180 GeV (10 - 120 GeV). This reach could be further extended to masses up to 375 GeV at the LHC with 14 TeV and 100 fb-1, while the production cross section at the LHC of 10 TeV is also presented for comparison.

The researchers also explore other possible modes, such as the μ± e± modes, and find that signals from these could be significant even considering current bounds from neutrinoless double-beta decay. However, the signal from the gauge boson fusion channel W^+ W^+ → ℓ^+₁ ℓ^+₂ at the LHC is found to be weak due to small mixing parameters. The team also comments on search strategies when tau leptons are involved in the final state. This work strengthens the pursuit for discovering heavy Majorana neutrinos at collider experiments.
allAuthors: Anupama Atre; Tao Han; Silvia Pascoli; Bin Zhang
institutions: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory; University of California, Santa Barbara; Tsinghua University; University of Wisconsin–Madison; Durham University

title: Physics interplay of the LHC and the ILC
abstract: AI abstract - This report presents an analysis of the interplay between the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the International Linear Collider (ILC), focusing on their physics implications, particularly in the context of electroweak interactions. The study further explores the synergies and potential complementarities between these two high-energy particle colliders.
summary:
Headline: "Physicists outline strategies for LHC and ILC collaboration to deepen understanding of electroweak interactions"

Summary:
A team of over 50 physicists have published a comprehensive review in the journal Physics Reports, detailing the potential synergies and complementarities between the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the International Linear Collider (ILC). The study focuses on their shared goal of deepening understanding of electroweak interactions – fundamental forces that bind particles together. By combining data from both colliders, scientists aim to validate and expand upon the Standard Model of particle physics, potentially leading to discoveries beyond it.

title: Commutator of the Quark Mass Matrices in the Standard Electroweak Model and a Measure of Maximal<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi>CP</mml:mi></mml:math>Nonconservation
abstract: The structure of the quark mass matrices in the standard electroweak model is investigated. The commutator of the quark mass matrices is found to provide a convention-independent measure of $\mathrm{CP}$ nonconservation. The question of maximal $\mathrm{CP}$ nonconservation is discussed. The present experimental data indicate that nowhere is $\mathrm{CP}$ nonconservation maximal.
summary:
**Physicist Proposes New Measure for Symmetry Violation in Standard Model**

In a groundbreaking paper published in Physical Review Letters, physicist Cecilia Jarlskog explores the structure of quark mass matrices within the standard electroweak model.

Jarlskog proposes that the commutator of quark mass matrices offers a convention-independent measure for CP nonconservation, a phenomenon linked to the violation of fundamental symmetries in particle physics. Jarlskog's work builds upon earlier research into CP (charge conjugation and parity) nonconservation, yet provides new implications about the extent to which this symmetry is violated.

With the current experimental data suggesting that maximal CP nonconservation remains undetected, this study offers a fresh perspective to ongoing investigations in particle physics.
allAuthors: Cecilia Jarlskog
institutions: University of Bergen

title: Long-lived particles at the energy frontier: the MATHUSLA physics case
abstract: We examine the theoretical motivations for long-lived particle (LLP) signals at the LHC in a comprehensive survey of standard model (SM) extensions. LLPs are a common prediction of a wide range of theories that address unsolved fundamental mysteries such as naturalness, dark matter, baryogenesis and neutrino masses, and represent a natural and generic possibility for physics beyond the SM (BSM). In most cases the LLP lifetime can be treated as a free parameter from the [Formula: see text]m scale up to the Big Bang Nucleosynthesis limit of [Formula: see text] m. Neutral LLPs with lifetimes above [Formula: see text]100 m are particularly difficult to probe, as the sensitivity of the LHC main detectors is limited by challenging backgrounds, triggers, and small acceptances. MATHUSLA is a proposal for a minimally instrumented, large-volume surface detector near ATLAS or CMS. It would search for neutral LLPs produced in HL-LHC collisions by reconstructing displaced vertices (DVs) in a low-background environment, extending the sensitivity of the main detectors by orders of magnitude in the long-lifetime regime. We study the LLP physics opportunities afforded by a MATHUSLA-like detector at the HL-LHC, assuming backgrounds can be rejected as expected. We develop a model-independent approach to describe the sensitivity of MATHUSLA to BSM LLP signals, and compare it to DV and missing energy searches at ATLAS or CMS. We then explore the BSM motivations for LLPs in considerable detail, presenting a large number of new sensitivity studies. While our discussion is especially oriented towards the long-lifetime regime at MATHUSLA, this survey underlines the importance of a varied LLP search program at the LHC in general. By synthesizing these results into a general discussion of the top-down and bottom-up motivations for LLP searches, it is our aim to demonstrate the exceptional strength and breadth of the physics case for the construction of the MATHUSLA detector.
summary:
Title: New Detectors Proposed for Breakthrough in Physics Beyond Standard Model

In a groundbreaking study appearing in Reports on Progress in Physics, an international team of experts argues for the development of a novel detector called MATHUSLA, which could revolutionize our understanding of physics beyond the standard model.

The researchers emphasize that a wide range of theories addressing fundamental mysteries such as dark matter, baryogenesis, and neutrino masses predict the existence of long-lived particles (LLPs). However, their elusive nature has so far hampered detection by main LHC detectors like ATLAS or CMS due to challenging backgrounds and limited acceptances.

MATHUSLA, the new proposed detector, would be placed near ATLAS or CMS and boasts minimal instrumentation while capitalizing on a large-volume surface area. The technology aims to search for neutral LLPs produced in HL-LHC collisions by reconstructing displaced vertices (DVs) in a low-background environment, potentially extending the sensitivity of main detectors by orders of magnitude in the long-lifetime regime.

By synthesizing results into a comprehensive study on top-down and bottom-up motivations for LLP searches, the research underlines the importance of a varied LLP search program at the LHC. The construction of MATHUSLA would pave the way for unprecedented discoveries in physics beyond the standard model.

The results contribute significantly to our understanding of this fundamental process in high-energy collisions.

Physics study offers comprehensive calculations on a crucial correction factor for the Drell-Yan process

Matsuura have made significant strides by completing a detailed calculation of an important order αs² correction to the K-factor in the Drell-Yan process. title: Asymptotic behaviour of exclusive processes in QCD
abstract: AI abstract - This study explores the asymptotic behavior of exclusive processes in Quantum Chromodynamics, focusing on hadronic systems and mesons within the framework of Particle Physics. The investigation aims to provide insights into the fundamental characteristics of these processes in QCD.
summary:
New Study Unveils Asymptotic Behavior of Exclusive Processes in Quantum Chromodynamics
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

V.L. Chernyak's latest research in *Physics Reports* delves into the behavior of exclusive processes within Quantum Chromodynamics, specifically in hadronic systems and mesons as part of particle physics. The study aims to shed light on the intrinsic attributes of these processes to foster a deeper understanding of QCD.

The research builds upon previous studies involving exclusive processes in quantum chromodynamics but offers new insights into their asymptotic behavior. This work serves to further advance our knowledge in this key area of particle physics.
allAuthors: V.L. Chernyak

title: Theory of the Fermi Interaction
abstract: The representation of Fermi particles by two-component Pauli spinors satisfying a second order differential equation and the suggestion that in β decay these spinors act without gradient couplings leads to an essentially unique weak four-fermion coupling. It is equivalent to equal amounts of vector and axial vector coupling with two-component neutrinos and conservation of leptons. (The relative sign is not determined theoretically.) It is taken to be "universal"; the lifetime of the μ agrees to within the experimental errors of 2%. The vector part of the coupling is, by analogy with electric charge, assumed to be not renormalized by virtual mesons. This requires, for example, that pions are also "charged" in the sense that there is a direct interaction in which, say, a π0 goes to π- and an electron goes to a neutrino. The weak decays of strange particles will result qualitatively if the universality is extended to include a coupling involving a Λ or Σ fermion. Parity is then not conserved even for those decays like K→2π or 3π which involve no neutrinos. The theory is at variance with the measured angular correlation of electron and neutrino in He6, and with the fact that fewer than 10^-4 pion decay into electron and neutrino.
summary:
**Feynman and Gell-Mann Propose Unique Fermi Interaction Theory**

Physicists Richard Feynman and Murray Gell-Mann present a novel theory on the interactions of Fermi particles in a paper published in Physical Review, suggesting that these particles can be represented by two-component Pauli spinors. In their proposed theory, Fermion particles exhibit both vector and axial vector couplings during beta decay, leading to a unique four-fermion weak interaction.

This interaction, which also ensures lepton conservation, is considered universally applicable in various particle decays. While the relative sign between vector and axial vector coupling remains undetermined theoretically, the authors hypothesize that the vector part of the coupling does not get renormalized by virtual mesons — a concept akin to electric charge.

The theory, when extended to involve particles like Λ or Σ fermions, promises to explain the decays of strange particles; however, it contradicts experimental findings on the angular correlation of electron and neutrino in He6 and underestimates pion decay into electron and neutrino by several orders of magnitude.
allAuthors: Richard P. Feynman; Murray Gell‐Mann
institutions: California Institute of Technology

title: Deep-inelastic scattering beyond the leading order in asymptotically free gauge theories
abstract: We calculate the full order-${g}^{2}$ corrections to the coefficient functions which determine the ${Q}^{2}$ dependence of the moments of deep-inelastic structure functions. The calculation is performed in the minimal-subtraction scheme of 't Hooft. The results are combined with the recent two-loop calculations of anomalous dimensions by Floratos, Ross, and Sachrajda to give the full ${\overline{g}}^{2}$ corrections to the leading order of asymptotic freedom. We present results for ${C}_{n}(1,{\overline{g}}^{2})$ relevant for electroproduction and neutrino reactions for both nonsinglet and singlet combinations of the structure functions. Phenomenological consequences of the full ${\overline{g}}^{2}$ corrections to the nonsinglet structure function are discussed. The corrections to the Gross-Llewellyn Smith and Bjorken sum rules are estimated to be of the order of 15%.
summary:
Physicists propose breakthrough in deep inelastic scattering theory

A new study published in Physical Review D by authors William A. Bardeen, Andrzej J. Buras, Dennis W. Duke, and T. Muta presents groundbreaking calculations on the full order-${g}^{2}$ corrections to the coefficients determining the ${Q}^{2}$ dependence of deep-inelastic structure functions moments. The research, performed using a minimal subtraction scheme of 't Hooft, builds upon recent two-loop anomalous dimensions calculations by Floratos et al. The findings offer a significant enhancement to the leading order of asymptotic freedom, providing results for ${C}_{n}(1,{\overline{g}}^{2})$ essential for electroproduction and neutrino reactions in nonsinglet and singlet combinations of structure functions.

The paper also explores the potential implications for nonsinglet structure functions, suggesting a 15% deviation from established Gross-Llewellyn Smith and Bjorken sum rules. These findings could pave the way for future advancements in deep inelastic scattering and our understanding of particle physics.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: William A. Bardeen; Andrzej J. Buras; Dennis W. Duke; T. Muta
institutions: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory

title: Sterile neutrinos as dark matter
abstract: The simplest model that can accomodate a viable nonbaryonic dark matter candidate is the standard electroweak theory with the addition of right-handed or sterile neutrinos. We reexamine this model and find that the sterile neutrinos can be either hot, warm, or cold dark matter. Since their only direct coupling is to left-handed or active neutrinos, the most efficient production mechanism is via neutrino oscillations. If the production rate is always less than the expansion rate, then these neutrinos will never be in thermal equilibrium. However, enough of them may be produced so that they provide the missing mass necessary for closure. We consider a single generation of neutrino fields $\left (\nu_L,\,\nu_R\right )$ with a Dirac mass, $\mu$, and a Majorana mass for the right-handed components only, $M$. For $M\gg \mu$ we show that the number density of sterile neutrinos is proportional to $\mu^2/M$ so that the energy density today is {\it independent of} $M$. However $M$ is crucial in determining the large scale structure of the Universe. In particular, $M\simeq 0.1-1.0 {\rm ~keV}$ leads to warm dark matter and a structure formation scenario that may have some advantages over both the standard hot and cold dark matter scenarios.
summary:
Title: "Sterile Neutrinos As Potential Dark Matter Candidates Explored in New Study"

New research published in Physical Review Letters by Scott Dodelson and Lawrence M. Widrow is shedding light on a potential solution for the mystery of dark matter, using the concept of sterile neutrinos as a candidate. The scientists are delving into a model that combines the Standard Electroweak Theory with right-handed or sterile neutrinos. By examining efficient production mechanisms via neutrino oscillations, they find these neutrinos could be any temperature of dark matter – hot, warm, or cold. The study reveals intriguing possibilities about structure formation, particularly suggesting that a Majorana mass for the right-handed components within the range of 0.1 to 1.0 keV could result in "warm" dark matter, offering advantages for understanding cosmic large scale structure over current hot and cold dark matter frameworks.
allAuthors: Scott Dodelson; Lawrence M. Widrow
institutions: Canadian Institute for Theoretical Astrophysics; Queen's University; University of Toronto; Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory

title: Supergravity as the messenger of supersymmetry breaking
abstract: A systematic study is made of theories in which supergravity is spontaneously broken in a "hidden" sector of superfields that interact with ordinary matter only through supergravity. General rules are given for calculating the low-energy effective potential in such theories. This potential is given as the sum of ordinary supersymmetric terms involving a low-energy effective superpotential whose mass terms arise from integrating out the heavy particles associated with grand unification, plus supersymmetry-breaking terms that depend on the details of the hidden sector and the K\"ahler potential only through the values of four small complex mass parameters. The result is not the same as would be obtained by ignoring grand unification and inserting small mass parameters into the superpotential from the beginning. The general results are applied to a class of models with a pair of Higgs doublets.
summary:
**New Physics Paper Reveals Unseen Sector's Role in Breaking Supersymmetry**

In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review D, scientists Lawrence J. Hall, Joe Lykken, and Steven Weinberg propose a new understanding of how supersymmetry can be broken through supergravity. The research focuses on theories where supergravity resides in an unseen sector ("hidden sector") that interacts with ordinary matter only via supergravity.

The scientists present general guidelines for calculating the effective potential at low energies in such theories – revealing it as a sum of supersymmetric elements involving an effective superpotential, and terms that depend on the specifics of the hidden sector and the Kähler potential mainly through four small complex mass parameters. This deviates from simpler models where mass parameters are inserted directly into the superpotential due to the influence of Grand Unification theories.

The study delves into a class of models with two Higgs doublets, applying their findings in a significant way that could pave the path forward for understanding how supersymmetry may manifest in these complex scenarios.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Lawrence J. Hall; Joe Lykken; Steven Weinberg
institutions: University of California, Berkeley; The University of Texas at Austin

title: Gaugino mass without singlets
abstract: AI abstract - We propose a novel approach to calculate gaugino masses in the context of supersymmetry, without requiring the presence of singlet fields. This work could potentially provide a significant advancement in our understanding of hidden sector physics and its implications for particle physics.
summary: Researchers Gian F. Giudice, Riccardo Rattazzi, Markus A. Luty, and Hitoshi Murayama have proposed a groundbreaking method to calculate Gaugino masses in the framework of supersymmetry, eliminating the need for singlet fields – a move that could revolutionize the study of hidden sector physics and its impact on particle physics, as published in Journal of High Energy Physics. This potential advancement may have profound implications for the understanding and exploration of these hidden sectors, expanding our grasp of fundamental physics.
allAuthors: Gian F. Giudice; Riccardo Rattazzi; Markus A. Luty; Hitoshi Murayama

title: Update on vector boson pair production at hadron colliders
abstract: We present numerical results (including full one-loop QCD corrections) for the processes p p-bar and pp -> W+ W-, W+/- Z/gamma* and Z/gamma* Z/gamma* followed by the decay of the massive vector bosons into leptons. In addition to their intrinsic importance as tests of the standard model, these processes are also backgrounds to conjectured non-standard model processes. Because of the small cross sections at the Tevatron, full experimental control of these backgrounds will be hard to achieve. This accentuates the need for up-to-date theoretical information. A comparison is made with earlier work and cross section results are presented for p p-bar collisions at sqrt{s}=2 TeV and pp collisions at sqrt{s}=14 TeV. Practical examples of the use of our calculations are presented.
summary:
Title: Pioneering Study Enhances Understanding of Lepton Production in Hadron Collisions

In a significant development within particle physics, physicists John M. Campbell and R. Keith Ellis have published an enlightening research paper titled "Update on vector boson pair production at hadron colliders" in Physical Review D. The study aims to provide improved insights into the production of W and Z bosons - fundamental particles in the Standard Model - and their subsequent decays into leptons at Tevatron-like and LHC energies.

The authors' work builds upon previous research on vector boson pair production, seeking to offer more precise theoretical data for these processes than past attempts. As background processes for potential non-Standard Model events, better understanding of these reactions plays a pivotal role in the search for physics beyond the Standard Model. With cross-section results presented for proton-antiproton collisions at 2 TeV and proton-proton collisions at 14 TeV, the study offers valuable information essential for future experimental efforts at accelerators.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Secluded WIMP dark matter
abstract: We consider a generic mechanism via which thermal relic WIMP dark matter may be decoupled from the Standard Model, namely through a combination of WIMP annihilation to metastable mediators with subsequent delayed decay to Standard Model states. We illustrate this with explicit examples of WIMPs connected to the Standard Model by metastable bosons or fermions. In all models, provided the WIMP mass is greater than that of the mediator, it can be secluded from the Standard Model with an extremely small elastic scattering crosssection on nuclei and rate for direct collider production. In contrast, indirect signatures from WIMP annihilation are consistent with a weak scale cross-section and provide potentially observable γ-ray signals. We also point out that γ-ray constraints and flavor physics impose severe restrictions on MeV-scale variants of secluded models, and identify limited classes that pass all the observational constraints. The overwhelming astrophysical and cosmological evidence for dark matter has in recent years led to a dramatic expansion in experimental programs that aim to detect observational
summary:
Title: New Theory Suggests "Secluded WIMP Dark Matter" Could Evade Direct Detection

In a new study published in Physics Letters B, scientists Maxim Pospelov, Adam Ritz, and M.B. Voloshin propose an intriguing hypothesis for Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs), a leading dark matter candidate. The researchers suggest that WIMPs could be "secluded" from the Standard Model of particle physics, making them significantly harder to detect directly but still providing potential observable γ-ray signals through indirect signatures.

The scientists illustrate their theory with examples involving WIMPs connected to the Standard Model by metastable bosons or fermions. If the WIMP mass is greater than that of the mediator, it could be isolated from the Standard Model, resulting in an extremely low elastic scattering cross-section on nuclei and a minimized rate for direct collider production. However, the indirect signatures from WIMP annihilation would remain consistent with a weak scale cross-section, offering the possibility of potentially observable γ-ray signals.

Despite the proposed seclusion, the researchers highlight that MeV-scale variants of this model face severe restrictions from γ-ray constraints and flavor physics. They narrow down classes of models that could potentially pass all observational constraints, contributing to ongoing efforts in the vast and evolving field of dark matter detection.
allAuthors: Maxim Pospelov; Adam Ritz; M.B. Voloshin
institutions: Perimeter Institute; University of Victoria; Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics; University of Minnesota

title: Physics at a future Neutrino Factory and super-beam facility
abstract: The conclusions of the Physics Working Group of the international scoping study of a future Neutrino Factory and super-beam facility (the ISS) are presented. The ISS was carried by the international community between NuFact05, (the 7th International Workshop on Neutrino Factories and Superbeams, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Rome, June 21-26, 2005) and NuFact06 (Ivine, California, 24{30 August 2006). The physics case for an extensive experimental programme to understand the properties of the neutrino is presented and the role of high-precision measurements of neutrino oscillations within this programme is discussed in detail. The performance of second generation super-beam experiments, beta-beam facilities, and the Neutrino Factory are evaluated and a quantitative comparison of the discovery potential of the three classes of facility is presented. High-precision studies of the properties of the muon are complementary to the study of neutrino oscillations. The Neutrino Factory has the potential to provide extremely intense muon beams and the physics potential of such beams is discussed in the final section of the report.
summary:
Headline: "Global Physicists Chart Course for Future Neutrino Research Hub"

Summary:
A group of international physicists have outlined plans for a future Neutrino Factory and super-beam facility, following a two-year scoping study. The initiative, named the International Scoping Study (ISS), highlights the importance of understanding neutrinos' properties through high-precision measurements of neutrino oscillations. The report, published in Reports on Progress in Physics, evaluates the performance of second generation super-beam experiments, beta-beam facilities, and the Neutrino Factory, comparing their discovery potential. The study also emphasizes the complementary role of high-precision studies of muons alongside neutrino oscillation research. Moreover, the Neutrino Factory presents an opportunity for generating extremely intense muon beams, offering exciting prospects in future physics explorations.

title: Applications of the Chiral<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi>U</mml:mi><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mn>6</mml:mn><mml:mo>)</mml:mo><mml:mn/><mml:mo>⊗</mml:mo><mml:mi>U</mml:mi><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mn>6</mml:mn><mml:mo>)</mml:mo><mml:mn/></mml:math>Algebra of Current Densities
abstract: Consequences of the local commutation relations of vector and axial currents proposed by Gell-Mann are explored: (1) A recipe for detecting and isolating Schwinger terms in the commutators, proportional to derivatives of the $\ensuremath{\delta}$ function, is discussed. (2) Under assumptions of smooth asymptotic behavior of form factors for forward scattering of the isovector current from a proton, we show that the $U(3)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}U(3)$ algebra for the time components of the currents implies the $U(6)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}U(6)$ algebra for space components, at least for spin-averaged diagonal single-particle states. (3) The derivation of the Adler-Weisberger formula for $\frac{{G}_{A}}{{G}_{V}}$ is sharpened by giving arguments that, at fixed energy, the forward $\ensuremath{\pi}\ensuremath{-}p$ Green's function satisfies an unsubtracted dispersion relation in the pion mass. (4) A lower bound for inelastic electron-nucleon scattering at high momentum transfer is derived on the basis of $U(6)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}U(6)$. (5) The contribution of very virtual photons to the hyperfine anomaly in hydrogen is shown to be related to an equal-time commutator of currents; this contribution is crudely estimated to be 4 parts per million (ppm). (6) The logarithmically divergent part of electromagnetic mass differences of hadrons is shown to be proportional to matrix elements of the equal-time commutator of the electromagnetic current with its time derivative. It is suggested that this "divergent" part be identified with the Coleman-Glashow "tadpoles"; this suggestion is discussed in the framework of a simple quark model. (7) The logarithmically divergent part of the electromagnetic correction to the process ${\ensuremath{\pi}}^{\ensuremath{-}}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}{\ensuremath{\pi}}^{0}+{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}+\overline{\ensuremath{\nu}}$ is, on the basis of the $U(6)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}U(6)$ current algebra, shown to be nonvanishing, and is computed. (8) A speculative argument is presented that the rate ${e}^{+}+{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}\mathrm{hadrons}$ is comparable to the rate ${e}^{+}+{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}{\ensuremath{\mu}}^{+}+{\ensuremath{\mu}}^{\ensuremath{-}}$ in the limit of large energies.
summary:
Headline: New Algebra of Current Densities Offers Insights into Nuclear Physics

Summary: A prominent physicist, James D. Bjorken, presents a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review that explores the local commutation relations of vector and axial currents proposed by Gell-Mann. The research uncovers a relationship between the time and space components of these currents, potentially refining our understanding of isovector current scattering from protons within mathematical physics. Bjorken's work also addresses the Adler-Weisberger formula for ratios of nucleon properties, inelastic electron-nucleon scattering at high momentum transfer, and various electromagnetic mass differences and corrections in hadrons. The study offers a fresh perspective on diverse aspects of nuclear and particle physics, contributing to ongoing efforts in the field.

title: "Natural" left-right symmetry
abstract: It is remarked that left-right symmetry of the starting gauge interactions is a "natural" symmetry if it is broken in no way except possibly by mass terms in the Lagrangian. The implications of this result for the unification of coupling constants and for parity nonconservation at low and high energies are stressed.
summary:
"Physicists propose 'Natural' Left-Right Symmetry Theory in New Study

In a groundbreaking paper, physicists Rabindra N. Mohapatra and Jogesh C. Pati suggest that left-right symmetry in gauge interactions - a longstanding concept in physics - could be considered "natural" if it is only broken by mass terms in the Lagrangian. The researchers emphasize the implications of this finding for unifying coupling constants and parity nonconservation at low and high energies, potentially opening new avenues for understanding fundamental particles' interactions."
