title: Next-to-Next-to-Leading-Order Subtraction Formalism in Hadron Collisions and its Application to Higgs-Boson Production at the Large Hadron Collider
abstract: We consider higher-order QCD corrections to the production of colorless high-mass systems (lepton pairs, vector bosons, Higgs bosons, etc.) in hadron collisions. We propose a new formulation of the subtraction method to numerically compute arbitrary infrared-safe observables for this class of processes. To cancel the infrared divergences, we exploit the universal behavior of the associated transverse-momentum (qT) distributions in the small-qT region. The method is illustrated in general terms up to the next-to-next-to-leading order in QCD perturbation theory. As a first explicit application, we study Higgs-boson production through gluon fusion. Our calculation is implemented in a parton level Monte Carlo program that includes the decay of the Higgs boson into two photons. We present selected numerical results at the CERN Large Hadron Collider.
summary: In Particle Physics, a groundbreaking study by Stefano Catani and Massimiliano Grazzini offers a new approach to calculate higher-order QCD corrections in hadron collisions for various colorless high-mass systems like lepton pairs, vector bosons, and even the Higgs boson. The novel subtraction method, published in Physical Review Letters, aims to numerically compute arbitrary infrared-safe observables by leveraging the universal behavior of associated transverse-momentum distributions in the small qT region. By illustrating the technique in the context of Higgs-boson production through gluon fusion and implementing it into a parton level Monte Carlo program, this research offers insights that could refine our understanding and predictions for Higgs-boson production at the Large Hadron Collider.

title: DarkSUSY: computing supersymmetric dark matter properties numerically
abstract: The question of the nature of the dark matter in the Universe remains one of the most outstanding unsolved problems in basic science. One of the best motivated particle physics candidates is the lightest supersymmetric particle, assumed to be the lightest neutralino—a linear combination of the supersymmetric partners of the photon, the Z boson and neutral scalar Higgs particles. Here we describe DarkSUSY, a publicly available advanced numerical package for neutralino dark matter calculations. In DarkSUSY one can compute the neutralino density in the Universe today using precision methods which include resonances, pair production thresholds and coannihilations. Masses and mixings of supersymmetric particles can be computed within DarkSUSY or with the help of external programs such as FeynHiggs, ISASUGRA and SUSPECT. Accelerator bounds can be checked to identify viable dark matter candidates. DarkSUSY also computes a large variety of astrophysical signals from neutralino dark matter, such as direct detection in low-background counting experiments and indirect detection through antiprotons, antideuterons, gamma-rays and positrons from the galactic halo or high-energy neutrinos from the centre of the Earth or of the Sun. Here we describe the physics behind the package. A detailed manual will be provided with the computer package.
summary:
"New Physics Software Aims to Unravel Dark Matter Mystery"

Scientists have developed a new software package called DarkSUSY that aims to solve one of the greatest mysteries in basic science: the nature of dark matter that makes up approximately 27% of the universe. The researchers, led by Paolo Gondolo and J Edsjö, believe that the lightest supersymmetric particle, known as the lightest neutralino, could be a strong candidate for this elusive substance.

DarkSUSY allows scientists to calculate the density of the neutralino today using advanced numerical methods including resonances, pair production thresholds and coannihilations. It can also compute the masses and mixings of supersymmetric particles with the help of external programs such as FeynHiggs, ISASUGRA, and SUSPECT. Acccelerator bounds will be checked using DarkSUSY to identify potential dark matter candidates. The software also calculates various astrophysical signals from neutralino dark matter, such as direct detection in low-background counting experiments, antiprotons, antideuterons, gamma-rays, positrons from the galactic halo or high-energy neutrinos from the centre of the Earth and Sun. The research provides a detailed overview of the physics behind DarkSUSY. A comprehensive manual will accompany the computer package.
journal: Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics

title: Indication of Electron Neutrino Appearance from an Accelerator-Produced Off-Axis Muon Neutrino Beam
abstract: The T2K experiment observes indications of ν(μ) → ν(e) appearance in data accumulated with 1.43×10(20) protons on target. Six events pass all selection criteria at the far detector. In a three-flavor neutrino oscillation scenario with |Δm(23)(2)| = 2.4×10(-3) eV(2), sin(2)2θ(23) = 1 and sin(2)2θ(13) = 0, the expected number of such events is 1.5±0.3(syst). Under this hypothesis, the probability to observe six or more candidate events is 7×10(-3), equivalent to 2.5σ significance. At 90% C.L., the data are consistent with 0.03(0.04) < sin(2)2θ(13) < 0.28(0.34) for δ(CP) = 0 and a normal (inverted) hierarchy.
summary:
Paper publishes findings of neutrino appearance in accelerator experiment
===================================================================

In a breakthrough for particle physics, researchers from an international collaboration have detected indications of the conversion of muon neutrinos into electron neutrinos in data collected from the T2K experiment, which involved 1.43 trillion protons on target.

The study, published in Physical Review Letters, observed six events passing stringent criteria at the far detector and provides evidence towards the phenomenon known as neutrino oscillation, where one type of neutrino transforms into another under certain conditions. The findings could provide additional insight into the nature of neutrinos, which are fundamental particles capable of transcending vast distances without deteriorating. This study supports the ongoing investigation of neutrino properties and their role in the universe's composition.

title: GALLEX solar neutrino observations: results for GALLEX IV
abstract: AI abstract - This work presents the results of solar neutrino observations conducted by GALLEX IV, focusing on data collected from the Physics Letters B journal in 1999. The study involves an international collaboration of researchers and reports findings related to solar neutrinos, neutrino oscillation, and astrophysics.
summary:
Title: International Collaboration Uncovers New Solar Neutrino Data with GALLEX IV

The latest research published in Physics Letters B presents new observations on solar neutrinos by the international collaboration known as GALLEX IV. The data was collected in 1999 and explores crucial aspects of solar neutrinos, neutrino oscillation, and astrophysics. This work builds upon previous studies focused on understanding the properties and behavior of these elusive particles, aiming to shed further light on our understanding of solar energy production and the Universe at large.

title: Combined Measurement of the Higgs Boson Mass in<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi>p</mml:mi><mml:mi>p</mml:mi></mml:math>Collisions at<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:msqrt><mml:mi>s</mml:mi></mml:msqrt><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>7</mml:mn></mml:math>and 8 TeV with the ATLAS and CMS Experiments
abstract: A measurement of the Higgs boson mass is presented based on the combined data samples of the ATLAS and CMS experiments at the CERN LHC in the H→γγ and H→ZZ→4ℓ decay channels. The results are obtained from a simultaneous fit to the reconstructed invariant mass peaks in the two channels and for the two experiments. The measured masses from the individual channels and the two experiments are found to be consistent among themselves. The combined measured mass of the Higgs boson is m_{H}=125.09±0.21 (stat)±0.11 (syst) GeV.
summary: In a research breakthrough, physicists have revealed the latest measurements of the elusive Higgs boson's mass, achieved through collaboration between the ATLAS and CMS experiments at CERN's Large Hadron Collider. The new measurement, presented in the journal Physical Review Letters, focuses on the decay channels H→γγ and H→ZZ→4ℓ and yields a combined result of mH=125.09±0.21 (stat)±0.11 (syst) GeV. The findings offer significant insights as they support the Standard Model of Particle Physics, reinforcing the existence of the Higgs boson and paving the way for further explorations into its properties and implications within our universe.

title: Leptogenesis
abstract: AI abstract - Leptogenesis is explored as a potential mechanism for the observed baryon asymmetry in the universe. The authors present a comprehensive review of the subject, discussing its implications for particle physics and potential experimental tests.
summary:
Title: Physicists Propose New Insights on Universe's Asymmetry

Subhead: Leptogenesis Revisited as Potential Answer to Baryon Asymmetry Riddle

A groundbreaking review paper by Sacha Davidson, Enrico Nardi and Yosef Nir in the prestigious Physics Reports offers fresh perspectives on the long-standing mystery of the baryon asymmetry in the universe. The authors delve into the concept of "Leptogenesis," exploring it as a potential primary mechanism responsible for this asymmetry. The study discusses the implications Leptogenesis could have for particle physics and proposes potential experimental tests that may further substantiate its role in shaping our cosmos, contributing significantly to the broader field of particle physics and advancing our understanding of the universe's fundamental properties.
allAuthors: Sacha Davidson; Enrico Nardi; Yosef Nir
institutions: Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique; Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1; Universidad de Antioquia; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati; Weizmann Institute of Science

title: Pileup subtraction using jet areas
abstract: AI abstract - This study presents a method for pileup subtraction using jet areas, applied in the context of high-energy collisions at the Large Hadron Collider. The proposed technique aims to mitigate experimental challenges associated with multiple overlapping proton-proton interactions, thereby improving the precision and accuracy of physics analyses.
summary:
New Method for Reducing Background Noise in Large Hadron Collider Data

Physicists Matteo Cacciari and Gavin P. Salam propose an innovative method called "pileup subtraction using jet areas" to improve the quality of data from high-energy particle collisions at the Large Hadron Collider. This technique addresses the challenge posed by multiple overlapping proton-proton interactions, also known as pileup, thereby enhancing the precision and accuracy of physics analyses crucial for discoveries in high-energy physics.
allAuthors: Matteo Cacciari; Gavin P. Salam
institutions: Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique; Sorbonne Université; Université Paris Cité

title: Massive neutrinos and neutrino oscillations
abstract: The theory of neutrino mixing and neutrino oscillations, as well as the properties of massive neutrinos (Dirac and Majorana), are reviewed. More specifically, the following topics are discussed in detail: (i) the possible types of neutrino mass terms; (ii) oscillations of neutrinos (iii) the implications of $\mathrm{CP}$ invariance for the mixing and oscillations of neutrinos in vacuum; (iv) possible varieties of massive neutrinos (Dirac, Majorana, pseudo-Dirac); (v) the physical differences between massive Dirac and massive Majorana neutrinos and the possibilities of distinguishing experimentally between them; (vi) the electromagnetic properties of massive neutrinos. Some of the proposed mechanisms of neutrino mass generation in gauge theories of the electroweak interaction and in grand unified theories are also discussed. The lepton number nonconserving processes $\ensuremath{\mu}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}e\ensuremath{\gamma}$ and $\ensuremath{\mu}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}3e$ in theories with massive neutrinos are considered. The basic elements of the theory of neutrinoless double-$\ensuremath{\beta}$ decay are discussed as well. Finally, the existing data on neutrino masses, oscillations of neutrinos, and neutrinoless double-$\ensuremath{\beta}$ decay are briefly reviewed. The main emphasis in the review is on the general model-independent results of the theory. Detailed derivations of these are presented.
summary:
"Physicists Review Neutrino Mixing and Oscillation Theory"

A new paper by Bilenky and Petcov, published in Reviews of Modern Physics, delves into the intriguing world of massive neutrinos and neutrino oscillations. The study explores various aspects of this field, including different types of neutrino mass terms, neutrino oscillations, CP invariance implications, distinct varieties of massive neutrinos (Dirac, Majorana, pseudo-Dirac), electromagnetic properties of these particles, and possible mechanisms for neutrino mass generation in theories of the electroweak interaction. The paper also considers lepton number nonconserving processes like muon decay into electron and photons or three electrons, and discusses the basics of neutrinoless double-beta decay. The review focuses on model-independent theoretical results, providing a comprehensive overview of current data regarding neutrino masses, oscillations, and double-betas decay.
allAuthors: S. M. Bilenky; S.T. Petcov
institutions: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research; Bulgarian Academy of Sciences

title: Verifiable radiative seesaw mechanism of neutrino mass and dark matter
abstract: A minimal extension of the Standard Model is proposed, where the observed left-handed neutrinos obtain naturally small Majorana masses from a one-loop radiative seesaw mechanism. This model has two candidates (one bosonic and one fermionic) for the dark matter of the Universe. It has a very simple structure and should be verifiable in forthcoming experiments at the Large Hadron Collider.
summary:
Headline: New Physics Model Proposed for Neutrino Masses and Dark Matter, Set for Testing at LHC

Summary:
Physicist Ernest Ma presents a groundbreaking model that explains the small masses of neutrinos through a one-loop radiative seesaw mechanism. The model, which could be verified in forthcoming experiments at the Large Hadron Collider, also offers two potential candidates - one bosonic and one fermionic - for the dark matter of the universe. By incorporating only minimal extensions to the Standard Model, the proposed model offers a simple yet promising direction for understanding some of the universe's most enigmatic components.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology
allAuthors: Ernest Ma
institutions: University of California, Riverside

title: Neutrino physics with JUNO
summary:
Title: Neutrino Observatory Offers New Insights into Fundamental Physics

In a breakthrough for particle physics, an international team of researchers has proposed the Jiangmen Underground Neutrino Observatory (JUNO) – a large-scale, multi-purpose underground detector aimed at solving pressing questions about neutrinos.

Primarily designed to determine the neutrino mass hierarchy and provide unprecedented insights into various topics in neutrino and astro-particle physics, the JUNO research will help tackle crucial issues such as understanding supernova explosions and exploring novel phenomena like collective neutrino oscillations.

The impressive energy resolution and large detection volume of the JUNO detector promise to yield significant data on subjects ranging from geoneutrinos to terrestrial and extra-terrestrial sources, solar neutrinos, atmospheric neutrinos, and even past core-collapse supernova explosions in the visible universe.

Significantly improving the statistics of existing geoneutrino event samples, the JUNO detector will also offer unique opportunities for testing beyond-the-standard-model physics by searching for proton decay, neutrinos from dark matter annihilation in the Sun, Lorentz invariance violation, and non-standard interactions.

The researchers envision that JUNO's potential to answer numerous critical questions in particle and astrophysics promises substantial advancements in our understanding of these fundamental aspects of our Universe.
journal: Journal of Physics G Nuclear and Particle Physics

title: Question of Parity Conservation in Weak Interactions
abstract: The question of parity conservation in $\ensuremath{\beta}$ decays and in hyperon and meson decays is examined. Possible experiments are suggested which might test parity conservation in these interactions.
summary:
Paper Challenges Conventional Understanding of Parity Conservation in Weak Interactions

In a groundbreaking paper published in Physical Review, scientists T.D. Lee and C.N. Yang delve into the question of parity conservation in beta decays, as well as decays involving hyperons and mesons. The researchers propose experiments that could potentially test whether parity is conserved in these interactions, which could challenge our current understanding of physics. The paper focuses on concepts like parity conservation and conservation laws, contributing to the broader field of particle physics.
allAuthors: T.D. Lee; C. N. Yang
institutions: Columbia University

title: Upper Bound of the Lightest Higgs Boson Mass in the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model
abstract: AI abstract - We present an upper bound for the lightest Higgs boson mass within the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model, using theoretical calculations and analysis. The results provide valuable constraints for further exploration in particle physics.
summary:
Title: New Upper Limit on Lightest Higgs Boson Mass Set in Physics Study

Summary: A groundbreaking study by Yuko Okada, Masahiro Yamaguchi, and Tim M. P. Tait published in Progress of Theoretical Physics has set a new upper limit for the lightest Higgs boson mass within the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM). Using comprehensive theoretical calculations, the researchers provide crucial constraints that will guide future research in particle physics, building upon prior work within the MSSM framework.
allAuthors: Yuko Okada; Masahiro Yamaguchi; Tim M. P. Tait

title: Baryons as relativistic three-quark bound states
abstract: AI abstract - We present a study investigating baryons as relativistic three-quark bound states within the framework of Quantum Chromodynamics and Lattice QCD. The work aims to further our understanding of these fundamental particles in particle physics.
summary:
Headline: New Study deepens understanding of Baryons as Fundamental Particles in Physics

Summary: A team of researchers, including Gernot Eichmann, Hèlios Sanchis-Alepuz, Richard Williams, Reinhard Alkofer, and Christian S. Fischer, have published a new paper in the journal Progress in Particle and Nuclear Physics. The study investigates baryons - a class of particles in particle physics - as relativistic three-quark bound states using Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) and Lattice QCD. By further exploring these fundamental particles, the work aims to enhance our understanding of their properties and behavior within the broader field of particle physics.
journal: Progress in Particle and Nuclear Physics
allAuthors: Gernot Eichmann; Hèlios Sanchis-Alepuz; Richard Williams; Reinhard Alkofer; Christian S. Fischer
institutions: Justus-Liebig-Universität Gießen; Nawi Graz; University of Graz; Helmholtz International Center for FAIR

title: The hadronic properties of the photon in high-energy interactions
abstract: High-energy photon interactions are discussed in terms of the hadronic structure of the photon, which is expressed by means of a formulation which is akin to, but somewhat more general than, vector-meson-dominance or specific generalized vector-dominance models. Experiments which demonstrate and yield information about this hadronic structure are discussed critically, and the resulting information is carefully evaluated. Special attention is paid to diffractive processes such as the photoproduction of vector mesons and to photon shadowing effects on nuclei. Relationships to other views of photon interactions, such as the parton model and the space-time description, are also discussed; these views are seen to complement the hadronic structure picture rather than to be in conflict. The general overview is that there is ample evidence which shows that the photon's hadronic structure plays a significant role in its interactions. What further work would most significantly enhance the understanding of the hadronic structure of the photon is also pointed out.
summary:
Headline: Study Explores Hadronic Structure of High-Energy Photons in Physics Interactions

Summary:
A new review by physicists T.H. Bauer, Robin Spital, D.R. Yennie, and F.M. Pipkin published in Reviews of Modern Physics delves into the hadronic properties of high-energy photons in interactions. The study, using a formulation similar to vector-meson dominance models, discusses experiments that demonstrate and provide insights on this structure. Particular focus is placed on diffractive processes like the photoproduction of vector mesons and photon shadowing effects on nuclei. Also addressed are relationships with other views of photon interactions, such as the parton model and space-time description, which are seen to complement rather than conflict with the hadronic structure picture. The review suggests that more work is needed to further understand the hadronic structure of the photon.
allAuthors: T.H. Bauer; Robin Spital; D. R. Yennie; F. M. Pipkin
institutions: Cornell University; Harvard University

title: Observation of Top Quark Production in<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mover><mml:mrow><mml:mi mathvariant="italic">p</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>¯</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:mover></mml:mrow></mml:mrow><mml:mi mathvariant="italic">p</mml:mi></mml:math>Collisions with the Collider Detector at Fermilab
abstract: We establish the existence of the top quark using a 67pb[superscript −1] data sample of [¯ over p]p collisions at √s = 1.8TeV collected with the Collider Detector at Fermilab (CDF). Employing techniques similar to those we previously published, we observe a signal consistent with t[¯ over t] decay to WWb[¯ over b], but inconsistent with the background prediction by 4.8σ. Additional evidence for the top quark is provided by a peak in the reconstructed mass distribution. We measure the top quark mass to be 176±8(stat)±10(syst)GeV/c[superscript 2], and the t[¯ over t] production cross section to be 6.8[+3.6 over −2.4]pb.
summary:
Headline: Scientists Confirm Top Quark Existence in Historic Collider Study

Summary: A team of researchers, led by F. Abe et al., have announced the discovery of the top quark at the Collider Detector at Fermilab (CDF), using data from 67 pb-1 of proton–antiproton collisions at a center-of-mass energy of 1.8 TeV. The study builds on previous research, employing similar techniques to identify the decay of top quarks into WWb-bar, and finds a signal that is 4.8 standard deviations away from the expected background. Additionally, the data reveals a peak in the reconstructed mass distribution, further supporting the existence of the top quark. The team reports a measured top quark mass of 176±8 (stat)±10 (syst) GeV/c² and a t-bar-t production cross section of 6.8+3.6 over -2.4 pb in this landmark finding within the realm of high-energy physics.

title: Results from a Search for Dark Matter in the Complete LUX Exposure
abstract: We report constraints on spin-independent weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP)-nucleon scattering using a 3.35×10^{4} kg day exposure of the Large Underground Xenon (LUX) experiment. A dual-phase xenon time projection chamber with 250 kg of active mass is operated at the Sanford Underground Research Facility under Lead, South Dakota (USA). With roughly fourfold improvement in sensitivity for high WIMP masses relative to our previous results, this search yields no evidence of WIMP nuclear recoils. At a WIMP mass of 50 GeV c^{-2}, WIMP-nucleon spin-independent cross sections above 2.2×10^{-46} cm^{2} are excluded at the 90% confidence level. When combined with the previously reported LUX exposure, this exclusion strengthens to 1.1×10^{-46} cm^{2} at 50 GeV c^{-2}.
summary:
Title: Major Steps Forward in Dark Matter Search as LUX Experiment Unveils New Results

Summary:
A diverse team of physicists, led by D. S. Akerib and others, have published their findings from the Large Underground Xenon (LUX) experiment in the prestigious journal Physical Review Letters. The study, which took place deep beneath Lead in South Dakota's Sanford Underground Research Facility, aimed to discover weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs), one of the leading dark matter candidates. Using a dual-phase xenon time projection chamber with 250 kg of active mass, the researchers have made significant strides in detection technology and sensitivity compared to previous results. Despite confirming no evidence of WIMP nuclear recoils during their 3.35×10^{4} kg day exposure, the team was able to exclude WIMP-nucleon spin-independent cross sections above 2.2×10^{-46} cm^{2} at a WIMP mass of 50 GeV c^{-2}, marking an important step in the search for dark matter. When combined with previous LUX data, this exclusion strengthens to 1.1×10^{-46} cm^{2} at 50 GeV c^{-2}. The study furthers our understanding of the mystery surrounding dark matter and sets a stronger baseline for future experiments in the field.

title: The Standard Model Higgs boson as the inflaton
abstract: AI abstract - The Standard Model Higgs boson is proposed as a potential candidate for the inflaton field, providing a novel approach to reconcile the electroweak scale with the inflationary scale in the early universe. This work explores the implications of this hypothesis on particle physics and the electroweak interaction within the framework of the Standard Model.
summary:
New Study Suggests Higgs Boson Could Be Key to Universe's Early Expansion

In a groundbreaking paper published in Physics Letters B, Russian physicists Fedor Bezrukov and Mikhail Shaposhnikov propose that the Standard Model's Higgs boson could be a potential candidate for the inflaton field. This revolutionary idea aims to reconcile the electroweak scale with the inflationary scale during the early universe's expansion.

The study delves into the implications of this hypothesis on particle physics and the electroweak interaction, offering a fresh perspective within the Standard Model framework. By linking the Higgs boson, essential to the electroweak interaction, with the inflaton field, which drives inflation in the early universe, researchers might be one step closer to resolving long-standing questions about the formation of our cosmos.

title: Successive combination jet algorithm for hadron collisions
abstract: Jet finding algorithms, as they are used in $e^+ e^-$ and hadron collisions, are reviewed and compared. It is suggested that a successive combination style algorithm, similar to that used in $e^+ e^-$ physics, might be useful also in hadron collisions, where cone style algorithms have been used previously.
summary:
Headline: New Jet Finding Algorithm Proposed for Hadron Collisions

Summary:
Physicists Stephen Ellis and Davison E. Soper suggest a change in the traditional jet finding algorithms used in particle physics, presenting a "successive combination" method that could improve analysis in hadron collisions. This new algorithm is inspired by its success in electron-positron collisions but offers potential benefits for hadron collisions where cone style algorithms have been predominantly utilized thus far. The paper published in Physical Review D encourages further exploration and possible implementation of this novel approach, potentially revolutionizing the field of particle physics.

title: The Low-Energy Frontier of Particle Physics
abstract: Most embeddings of the Standard Model into a more unified theory, in particular those based on supergravity or superstrings, predict the existence of a hidden sector of particles that have only very weak interactions with visible-sector Standard Model particles. Some of these exotic particle candidates [for instance, axions, axion-like particles, and hidden U(1) gauge bosons] may be very light, with masses in the subelectronvolt range, and may have very weak interactions with photons. Correspondingly, these very weakly interacting subelectronvolt particles (WISPs) may lead to observable effects in experiments (as well as in astrophysical and cosmological observations) searching for light shining through a wall, for changes in laser polarization, for nonlinear processes in large electromagnetic fields, and for deviations from Coulomb's law. We present the physics case and a status report of this emerging low-energy frontier of fundamental physics.
summary:
Title: New Frontier in Physics: Exploring Subtle Interactions of 'Invisible' Particles

The paper "The Low-Energy Frontier of Particle Physics" by Joerg Jaeckel and Andreas Ringwald published in the Annual Review of Nuclear and Particle Science, delves into a promising new direction in physics. This research focuses on a hidden sector of particles, scarcely interacting with visible matter, often comprising axions, axion-like particles, and hidden U(1) gauge bosons, which could have masses around subelectronvolt range.

This frontier of exploring these weakly interacting subelectronvolt particles (WISPs), as the research termed it, could potentially lead to observable effects in various experiments, such as searches for light passing through walls, changes in laser polarization, nonlinear processes in large electromagnetic fields, and deviations from Coulomb's law. The work offers an overview of this burgeoning field, providing insights into the physics beyond the Standard Model.
journal: Annual Review of Nuclear and Particle Science
allAuthors: Joerg Jaeckel; Andreas Ringwald
institutions: Durham University; Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY

**Physics Report Highlights Advances in Quantum Chromodynamics and Light-Cone Theories**

Pinsky delve into the intricate realms of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) and other field theories on the light cone. title: Neutrinos and collider physics
abstract: We review the collider phenomenology of neutrino physics and the synergetic aspects at energy, intensity and cosmic frontiers to test the new physics behind the neutrino mass mechanism. In particular, we focus on seesaw models within the minimal setup as well as with extended gauge and/or Higgs sectors, and on supersymmetric neutrino mass models with seesaw mechanism and with $R$-parity violation. In the simplest Type-I seesaw scenario with sterile neutrinos, we summarize and update the current experimental constraints on the sterile neutrino mass and its mixing with the active neutrinos. We also discuss the future experimental prospects of testing the seesaw mechanism at colliders and in related low-energy searches for rare processes, such as lepton flavor violation and neutrinoless double beta decay. The implications of the discovery of lepton number violation at the LHC for leptogenesis are also studied.
summary:
Headline:
"Collider Physics Review Examines Neutrinos and New Physics behind Mass Mechanism"

Summary:
This new paper, published in the New Journal of Physics, delves into the realm of particle physics, focusing on neutrino research and the new physics underlying their mass mechanism. The study reviews collider phenomenology for neutrino physics, with a focus on seesaw models, both minimal and extended, as well as supersymmetric neutrino mass models. The authors discuss current experimental constraints on sterile neutrinos' mass and mixing, update future prospects testing the seesaw mechanism at colliders, and examine low-energy searches for rare processes like lepton flavor violation and neutrinoless double beta decay. Lastly, they explore the potential implications of lepton number violation at the LHC for leptogenesis.
allAuthors: Frank F. Deppisch; P. S. Bhupal Dev; Apostolos Pilaftsis
institutions: University College London; University of Manchester

title: An investigation of the spin structure of the proton in deep inelastic scattering of polarised muons on polarised protons
abstract: The spin asymmetry in deep inelastic scattering of longitudinally polarised muons by longitudinally polarised protons has been measured in the range 0.01<×<0.7. The spin dependent structure function g1(x) for the proton has been determined and, combining the data with earlier SLAC measurements, its integral over x found to be 0.126±0.010(stat.)±0.015(syst.), in disagreement with the Ellis-Jaffe sum rule. Assuming the validity of the Biorken sum rule, this result implies a significant negative value for the integral of g1 for the neutron. These integrals lead to the conclusion, in the naïve quark parton model, that the total quark spin constitutes a rather small fraction of the spin of the nucleon. Results are also presented on the asymmetries in inclusive hadron production which are consistent with the above picture.
summary:
New Research Challenges Nucleon's Spin Composition
----------------------------------------
Polarized scientists, led by J.G. Ashman and a team of over 70 researchers from various institutions, have published a groundbreaking study in *Nuclear Physics B*. The research, which focuses on the deep inelastic scattering of polarized muons on polarized protons, provides insights into the spin structure of the proton.

According to the investigation, the spin-dependent structure function g1(x) for the proton and its integral, found to be 0.126±0.010(stat.)±0.015(syst.), challenges the Ellis-Jaffe sum rule. The findings suggest a significant negative value for the neutron's integral of g1, leading experts to conclude that the total quark spin constitutes only a minor fraction of a nucleon's spin in the simplified quark parton model – challenging established knowledge about the proton's and neutron's internal structure. The research also provides consistent results on asymmetries in inclusive hadron production, further emphasizing these revolutionary findings for understanding particle physics.

summary:
New Boson Observed Near 125 GeV Mass, Supporting the Standard Model
---------------

A team of scientists led by S. Chatrchyan reported the discovery of a new boson with a mass around 125 GeV in proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt{s}=7$ and 8 TeV, using data from the Large Hadron Collider. The discovery of this new particle could lead to further investigations and potential refinements of the Standard Model, ultimately offering deeper insights into the fundamental structure of the universe.

title: Asymptotically Free Gauge Theories. I
abstract: Asymptotically free gauge theories of the strong interactions are constructed and analyzed. The reasons for doing this are recounted, including a review of renormalization-group techniques and their application to scaling phenomena. The renormalization-group equations are derived for Yang-Mills theories. The parameters that enter into the equations are calculated to lowest order and it is shown that these theories are asymptotically free. More specifically the effective coupling constant, which determines the ultraviolet behavior of the theory, vanishes for large spacelike momenta. Fermions are incorporated and the construction of realistic models is discussed. We propose that the strong interactions be mediated by a "color" gauge group which commutes with SU(3) \ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{} SU(3). The problem of symmetry breaking is discussed. It appears likely that this would have a dynamical origin. It is suggested that the gauge symmetry might not be broken and that the severe infrared singularities prevent the occurrence of noncolor singlet physical states. The deep-inelastic structure functions, as well as the electron-positron total annihilation cross section are analyzed. Scaling obtains up to calculable logarithmic corrections, and the naive light-cone or parton-model results follow. The problems of incorporating scalar mesons and breaking the symmetry by the Higgs mechanism are explained in detail.
summary:
"New Gauge Theory Approach Unveiled for Strong Interactions"

In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review, physicists David J. Gross and Frank Wilczek present a novel approach to understanding strong interactions - the forces that bind atomic nuclei together. The paper, titled "Asymptotically Free Gauge Theories," delves into the construction and analysis of gauge theories that could potentially explain the behavior of these powerful forces.

The research is rooted in renormalization-group techniques, used to interpret scaling phenomena, and applied to Yang-Mills theories. The researchers demonstrate that these theories exhibit an intriguing property known as asymptotic freedom, where effective coupling constants vanish for large spacelike momenta. Fermions are also integrated into the models, bringing us a step closer to realistic applications.

The authors propose a "color" gauge group, which could potentially mediate strong interactions, and discuss the problem of symmetry breaking, suggesting it may have a dynamic origin. The study also touches upon deep-inelastic structure functions and electron-positron total annihilation cross sections, showing that scaling holds up to logarithmic corrections, supporting the parton model results. However, challenges such as incorporating scalar mesons and breaking symmetry by the Higgs mechanism still remain.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: David J. Gross; Frank Wilczek
institutions: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory; Princeton University

title: Neutrino mass and mixing with discrete symmetry
abstract: This is a review paper about neutrino mass and mixing and flavour model building strategies based on discrete family symmetry. After a pedagogical introduction and overview of the whole of neutrino physics, we focus on the PMNS mixing matrix and the latest global fits following the Daya Bay and RENO experiments which measure the reactor angle. We then describe the simple bimaximal, tri-bimaximal and golden ratio patterns of lepton mixing and the deviations required for a non-zero reactor angle, with solar or atmospheric mixing sum rules resulting from charged lepton corrections or residual trimaximal mixing. The different types of see-saw mechanism are then reviewed as well as the sequential dominance mechanism. We then give a mini-review of finite group theory, which may be used as a discrete family symmetry broken by flavons either completely, or with different subgroups preserved in the neutrino and charged lepton sectors. These two approaches are then reviewed in detail in separate chapters including mechanisms for flavon vacuum alignment and different model building strategies that have been proposed to generate the reactor angle. We then briefly review grand unified theories (GUTs) and how they may be combined with discrete family symmetry to describe all quark and lepton masses and mixing. Finally, we discuss three model examples which combine an SU(5) GUT with the discrete family symmetries A₄, S₄ and Δ(96).
summary:
Paper Review: "Neutrino Mass and Mixing with Discrete Symmetry" - King, Luhn (Reports on Progress in Physics)

The latest research by Stephen F. King and Christoph Luhn sheds light on neutrino mass and mixing in particle physics, focusing particularly on discrete family symmetry. The paper builds upon the PMNS mixing matrix and recent data from Daya Bay and RENO experiments to discuss the bimaximal, tri-bimaximal, and golden ratio patterns of lepton mixing.

The authors explore varying seesaw mechanisms, sequential dominance mechanism, and the use of finite group theory as a discrete family symmetry broken by flavons to create new models for neutrino mass and mixing. Detailed reviews of both approaches are provided, delving into mechanisms for flavon vacuum alignment and proposed model building strategies to generate the reactor angle.

Finally, three model examples combining an SU(5) Grand Unified Theory with discrete family symmetries A₄, S₄, and Δ(96) are presented to describe all quark and lepton masses and mixing. The paper brings together these ideas to provide a comprehensive understanding of the complex relationship between neutrinos, particle physics, and discrete symmetry in the field of particle physics research.
allAuthors: Stephen F. King; Christoph Luhn
institutions: University of Southampton; Durham University

title: Relativistic hadron-hadron collisions in the ultra-relativistic quantum molecular dynamics model
abstract: Hadron-hadron collisions at high energies are investigated in the Ultrarelativistic-Quantum-Molecular-Dynamics approach. This microscopic transport model describes the phenomenology of hadronic interactions at low and intermediate energies ( √ s &lt; 5 GeV) in terms of interactions between known hadrons and their resonances. At higher energies, √ s&gt; 5 GeV, the excitation of color strings and their subsequent fragmentation into hadrons dominates the multiple production of particles in the UrQMD model. The model shows a fair overall agreement with a large body of experimental h-h data over a wide range of h-h center-of-mass energies. Hadronic reaction data with higher precision would be useful to support the use of the UrQMD model for relativistic heavy ion collisions. PACS: 24.10.Lx, 13.75.-n, 13.85.-t 2 I.
summary:
Researchers led by Marcus Bleicher propose a new approach to studying high-energy hadron-hadron collisions using the Ultrarelativistic Quantum Molecular Dynamics (UrQMD) model, published in Journal of Physics G: Nuclear and Particle Physics.

The study builds on prior work in hadronic interactions at lower energies, where known hadrons and their resonances interact. At higher energies above 5 GeV, color strings are excites and fragmented into various hadrons in the UrQMD model, aiding in understanding multiple particle production.

While showing a general agreement with experimental data, the authors suggest improved precision in hadronic reaction data could further support the application of the UrQMD model for analyzing relativistic heavy ion collisions.
journal: Journal of Physics G Nuclear and Particle Physics

title: Charmonium: The model
abstract: A comprehensive treatment of the charmonium model of the $\ensuremath{\psi}$ family is presented. The model's basic assumption is a flavor-symmetric instantaneous effective interaction between quark color densities. This interaction describes both quark-antiquark binding and pair creation, and thereby provides a unified approach for energies below and above the threshold for charmed-meson production. If coupling to decay channels is ignored, one obtains the "naive" model wherein the dynamics is completely described by a single charmed-quark pair. A detailed description of this "naive" model is presented for the case where the instantaneous potential is a superposition of a linear and Coulombic term. A far more realistic picture is attained by incorporating those terms in the interaction that couple charmed quarks to light quarks. The coupled-channel formalism needed for this purpose is fully described. Formulas are given for the inclusive ${e}^{+}{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}$ cross section and for ${e}^{+}{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}$ annihilation into specific charmed-meson pairs. The influence of closed decay channels on $\ensuremath{\psi}$ states below charm threshold is investigated, with particular attention to leptonic and radiative widths.
summary:
Title: New Physics Model for Charmonium Family Unveiled

In a groundbreaking development in the field of particle physics, researchers E. Eichten, Kurt Gottfried, T. Kinoshita, Kenneth Lane, and T. -M. Yan have unveiled a comprehensive model for the charmonium family in the latest issue of Physical Review D: Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology.

The Charmonium model, as proposed by the authors, assumes a flavor-symmetric instantaneous effective interaction between quark color densities. This interaction allows for both quark-antiquark binding and pair creation, creating a unified approach to energies below and above the threshold for charmed-meson production.

The "naive" model presented is a simplified version of this Charmonium model, consisting entirely of a single charmed-quark pair interaction with a superposition of a linear and Coulombic term. To create a more realistic picture, the researchers further incorporate terms in the interaction that couple charmed quarks to light quarks. The study offers formulas for the inclusive ${e}^{+}{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}$ cross section and for ${e}^{+}{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}$ annihilation into specific charmed-meson pairs, as well as investigating the influence of closed decay channels on $\ensuremath{\psi}$ states below charm threshold.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: E. Eichten; Kurt Gottfried; T. Kinoshita; Kenneth Lane; T. -M. Yan
institutions: Cornell University

title: Remarks on the chiral phase transition in chromodynamics
abstract: The phase transition restoring chiral symmetry at finite temperatures is considered in a linear $\ensuremath{\sigma}$ model. For three or more massless flavors, the perturbative $\ensuremath{\epsilon}$ expansion predicts the phase transition is of first order. At high temperatures, the ${\mathrm{U}}_{A}(1)$ symmetry will also be effectively restored.
summary:
Title: Pioneering Study Sheds Light on Chiral Phase Transition in Quantum Chromodynamics

In a groundbreaking paper published in Physical Review D, physicists Robert D. Pisarski and Frank Wilczek have presented a remarkable analysis of the chiral phase transition in quantum chromodynamics (QCD). The study builds upon previous research on massless particles and phase transitions, focusing specifically on a linear sigma model that predicts a first-order phase transition for three or more flavors at finite temperatures. The researchers also highlight the restoration of the UA(1) symmetry at high temperatures as another significant finding in this field of study. This work is poised to deepen our understanding of QCD and its implications for particle physics.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Robert D. Pisarski; Frank Wilczek
institutions: University of California, Santa Barbara

title: Wave Functions, Evolution Equations and Evolution Kernels from Light-Ray Operators of QCD
abstract: The widely used nonperturbative wave functions and distribution functions of QCD are determined as matrix elements of light-ray operators. These operators appear as large momentum limit of nonlocal hadron operators or as summed up local operators in light-cone expansions. Nonforward one-particle matrix elements of such operators lead to new distribution amplitudes describing both hadrons simultaneously. These distribution functions depend besides other variables on two scaling variables. They are applied for the description of exclusive virtual Compton scattering in the Bjorken region near forward direction and the two meson production process. The evolution equations for these distribution amplitudes are derived on the basis of the renormalization group equation of the considered operators. This includes that also the evolution kernels follow from the anomalous dimensions of these operators. Relations between different evolution kernels (especially the Altarelli-Parisi and the Brodsky-Lepage) kernels are derived and explicitly checked for the existing two-loop calculations of QCD. Technical basis of these results are support and analytically properties of the anomalous dimensions of light-ray operators obtained with the help of the $\\alpha$-representation of Green's functions.
summary:
Paper Title: New Approach to Quantum Chromodynamics Unveils Distribution Functions for Exclusive Processes

In a groundbreaking development in Physics, researchers from multiple institutions have proposed a novel method to determine crucial nonperturbative wave functions and distribution functions within the framework of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). The study, published in Fortschritte der Physik/Progress of Physics, uses light-ray operators, derived from hadron operators or local operators in light-cone expansions.

This approach leads to unique distribution amplitudes capable of describing simultaneous behavior of hadrons. These functions, dependent on two scaling variables, are applied to describe exclusive virtual Compton scattering and the two-meson production process. The paper also derives evolution equations for these distribution amplitudes, extending from the renormalization group equation of the operators under consideration.

Significantly, this study reveals relationships between different evolution kernels like the Altarelli-Parisi and Brodsky-Lepage kernels, providing a foundation for future advancements in our understanding of QCD's intricate dynamics.
allAuthors: D. Müller; D. Robaschik; B. Geyer; F.-M. Dittes; J. Hořejší
institutions: Leipzig University; Charles University

title: Handbook of perturbative QCD
abstract: The elements, theoretical basis, and experimental status of perturbative quantum chromodynamics are presented. Relevant field-theoretic methods are introduced at a nonspecialist level, along with a review of the basic ideas and methods of the parton model. This is followed by an account of the fundamental theorems of quantum chromodynamics, which generalize the parton model. Summaries of the theoretical and experimental status of the most important hard-scattering processes are then given, including electron-positron annihilation, deeply inelastic scattering, and hard hadron-hadron scattering, as induced both by electoweak interactions and by quantum chromodynamics directly. In addition, a discussion is presented of the global fitting approach to the determination of parton distributions in nucleons.
summary:
Title: Experts Chart Progress in Perturbative Quantum Chromodynamics

In the latest issue of the Reviews of Modern Physics, a group of leading physicists have compiled a comprehensive handbook on Perturbative Quantum Chromodynamics (PQCD). The work aims to bring together key elements, concepts, and breakthroughs in this field, which formulates the theory of strong nuclear force between quarks.

The handbook offers an accessible overview of fundamental theories, methods, and the parton model. It also delves into important processes such as electron-positron annihilation, deeply inelastic scattering, and hard hadron-hadron scattering. These are crucial areas in particle physics where PQCD plays a significant role. The work provides extensive summaries of each process's contemporary theoretical and experimental status, helping to advance our understanding of such interactions. Additionally, it discusses the global fitting approach to determining parton distributions in nucleons, offering insight into the behavior of these fundamental particle building blocks.

title: Infrared singularities and massive fields
abstract: We examine some problems associated with the low-momentum behavior of gauge theories and other renormalizable field theories. Our main interest is in the infrared structure of unbroken non-Abelian gauge theories and how this is affected by the presence of other heavy fields coupled to the massless gauge fields. It is shown in the context of a simple model of gauge mesons coupled to massive fermions that the heavy fields decouple at low momenta except for their contribution to renormalization effects. This result is used to discuss the mass-shell structure of the fermion propagator. The decoupling theorem is then stated for a general renormalizable theory and applied to some interesting examples. One is a more general gauge theory which makes use of the Higgs mechanism and attempts to unify the elementary particle forces. Another is the connection of the linear and nonlinear $\ensuremath{\sigma}$ models in the limit ${m}_{\ensuremath{\sigma}}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}\ensuremath{\infty}$.
summary:
Headline: Physicists Propose New Insights on Gauge Theories and Heavy Fields Interactions

Summary:
In a recent paper published in Physical Review D, Thomas Appelquist and J. Carazzone delve into the low-momentum behavior of gauge theories and other renormalizable field theories. The focus is on the infrared structure of unbroken non-Abelian gauge theories and how this is affected by the presence of heavy fields coupled to massless gauge fields. The scientists propose a simple model of gauge mesons coupled to massive fermions, revealing that heavy fields decouple at low momenta except for their contribution to renormalization effects. These findings contribute to a better understanding of the mass-shell structure of the fermion propagator and have implications for more complex theories such as a unified gauge theory approach to elementary particle forces and the connection between linear and nonlinear sigma models in the limit of infinite mass.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Massive Lepton-Pair Production in Hadron-Hadron Collisions at High Energies
abstract: On the basis of a parton model studied earlier we consider the production process of large-mass lepton pairs from hadron-hadron inelastic collisions in the limiting region, $s\ensuremath{\rightarrow}\ensuremath{\infty}$, $\frac{{Q}^{2}}{s}$ finite, ${Q}^{2}$ and $s$ being the squared invariant masses of the lepton pair and the two initial hadrons, respectively. General scaling properties and connections with deep inelastic electron scattering are discussed. In particular, a rapidly decreasing cross section as $\frac{{Q}^{2}}{s}\ensuremath{\rightarrow}1$ is predicted as a consequence of the observed rapid falloff of the inelastic scattering structure function $\ensuremath{\nu}{W}_{2}$ near threshold.
summary:
New Physics Paper Explores Lepton-Pair Production in High-Energy Collisions

In a new study published in Physical Review Letters, Sidney D. Drell and Tung-Mow Yan delve into the production of large-mass lepton pairs from inelastic collisions between hadrons at extremely high energies. The work builds upon the authors' previous research on the parton model and discusses potential links with deep inelastic electron scattering.

The paper predicts a rapid decrease in the cross section as the squared invariant masses of the lepton pair and the two initial hadrons approach unity, a significant finding that could advance our understanding of particle physics.

In a groundbreaking paper published in Progress in Particle and Nuclear Physics, authors Craig D. Roberts and Anthony G. Williams explore the potential of Dyson-Schwinger equations to further our understanding of hadronic physics within the framework of Quantum Chromodynamics and Gauge Theory. The study offers insights into the intricate dynamics governing subatomic particles, contributing significantly to the ongoing research in this field.
journal: Progress in Particle and Nuclear Physics

title: Scaling violations in inclusive<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mrow><mml:msup><mml:mrow><mml:mi>e</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mo>+</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:msup></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:msup><mml:mrow><mml:mi>e</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mo>−</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:msup></mml:mrow></mml:math>annihilation spectra
abstract: The origin of the observed scaling violations in inclusive e+e- annihilation is investigated. Perturbative jet evolution is not necessarily the only reason for scale breaking in the hadron spectra at present energies. Remnants of finite-transverse-momentum and mass effects are still important in nonperturbative, cascade-type, jet formation in the 10 GeV range. Heavy-quark fragmentation has a strong impact on hadronic inclusive spectra. A simple parametrization for the heavy-quark fragmentation function is given which describes well recently measured charmed-meson spectra. Taking these effects into account, good agreement with the observed scaling violations is obtained in cascade-type jet models with hard-gluon bremsstrahlung.
summary:
New Study Sheds Light on Scale Breaking in Particle Physics

Physicists led by Carsten Peterson have made strides in understanding the origin of scale breaking in particle collisions, specifically in inclusive electron-positron annihilation. The team's findings published in Physical Review D suggest that perturbative jet evolution is not the sole cause of this phenomenon at current energies. Instead, remnants of finite-transverse-momentum and mass effects persist in nonperturbative jet formation within the 10 GeV range. Moreover, heavy-quark fragmentation plays a crucial role in shaping hadronic inclusive spectra, as evident from a new parametrization for heavy-quark fragmentation functions presented in the study. These insights could pave the way for more accurate models of high-energy particle collisions.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Carsten Peterson; D. Schlatter; Ingo Schmitt; P.M. Zerwas
institutions: SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory; Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource; Stanford University

title: Symmetry Breaking in Non-Abelian Gauge Theories
abstract: According to the Goldstone theorem, any manifestly covariant broken-symmetry theory must exhibit massless particles. However, it is known from previous work that such particles need not appear in a relativistic theory such as radiation-gauge electrodynamics, which lacks manifest covariance. Higgs has shown how the massless Goldstone particles may be eliminated from a theory with broken $U(1)$ symmetry by coupling in the electromagnetic field. The primary purpose of this paper is to discuss the analogous problem for the case of broken non-Abelian gauge symmetries. In particular, a model is exhibited which shows how the number of massless particles in a theory of this type is determined, and the possibility of having a broken non-Abelian gauge symmetry with no massless particles whatever is established. A secondary purpose is to investigate the relationship between the radiation-gauge and Lorentz-gauge formalisms. The Abelian-gauge case is reexamined, in order to show that, contrary to some previous assertions, the Lorentz-gauge formalism, properly handled, is perfectly consistent, and leads to physical conclusions identical with those reached using the radiation gauge.
summary:
**New Theory Explores Massless Particles in Non-Abelian Gauge Theories**

Physicist T.W.B. Kibble's groundbreaking work published in Physical Review offers significant insight into the realm of relativistic theories and broken symmetry. This study extends Higgs' previous findings on eliminating massless Goldstone particles from a broken $U(1)$ symmetry theory by coupling in the electromagnetic field, now delving into non-Abelian gauge symmetries.

Kibble's paper presents a model demonstrating how theories of this nature determine the number of massless particles, thereby establishing the possibility of having broken non-Abelian gauge symmetries without any massless particles at all. Additionally, the research investigates the relationship between radiation-gauge and Lorentz-gauge formalisms, providing a clear picture of their compatibility and providing identical physical conclusions.

The work highlights the continuing exploration and refinement of Gauge Theory, aiming not only to deepen our understanding of relativistic symmetries but also to rectify earlier misconceptions in the field.
allAuthors: T. W. B. Kibble
institutions: Imperial College London

title: Finite-Temperature Field Theory
abstract: The 2006 second edition of this book develops the basic formalism and theoretical techniques for studying relativistic quantum field theory at high temperature and density. Specific physical theories treated include QED, QCD, electroweak theory, and effective nuclear field theories of hadronic and nuclear matter. Topics include: functional integral representation of the partition function, diagrammatic expansions, linear response theory, screening and plasma oscillations, spontaneous symmetry breaking, Goldstone theorem, resummation and hard thermal loops, lattice gauge theory, phase transitions, nucleation theory, quark-gluon plasma, and color superconductivity. Applications to astrophysics and cosmology cover white dwarf and neutron stars, neutrino emissivity, baryon number violation in the early universe, and cosmological phase transitions. Applications to relativistic nucleus-nucleus collisions are also included. The book is written for theorists in elementary particle physics, nuclear physics, astrophysics, and cosmology. Problems are given at the end of each chapter, and numerous references to the literature are included.
summary:
**New Physics Book Offers Insights on High-Temperature Quantum Field Theory**

In a new second edition released in 2006, researchers Joseph I. Kapusta and Charles Gale present an updated book that delves into the study of Relativistic Quantum Field Theory at extreme temperatures and densities. The text explores various physical theories such as Quantum Electrodynamics (QED), Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), electroweak theory, and more in the context of particle physics and nuclear matter.

Topics covered in the book include functional integral representation of the partition function, diagrammatic expansions, linear response theory, screening and plasma oscillations, spontaneous symmetry breaking, and resummation techniques (hard thermal loops). The book also discusses phase transitions, nucleation theory, quark-gluon plasma, color superconductivity, and their connections to astrophysics, cosmology, white dwarfs, neutron stars, neutrino emissivity, baryon number violation in the early universe, and cosmological phase transitions. It is aimed at theorists in elementary particle physics, nuclear physics, astrophysics, and cosmology with problem sets provided at the end of each chapter and a wealth of literature references.
allAuthors: Joseph I. Kapusta; Charles Gale
institutions: McGill University

abstract: In these classic lectures, Feynman analyses the theoretical questions related to electron and photon interactions at high energies. These lectures are based on a special topics course taught by Feynman at Caltech in 1971 and 1972. The material is dealt with on an advanced level and includes discussions of vector meson dominance and deep inelastic scattering. The possible consequences of the parton model are also analyzed.
summary: In groundbreaking insights presented in the Physics journal, Nobel laureate Richard Feynman explores high-energy interactions between electrons and photons – a fundamental aspect of nuclear and particle physics. His lectures, delivered at Caltech in 1971 and 1972, delve into advanced concepts like vector meson dominance, deep inelastic scattering, and the parton model, offering potential implications for understanding these intricate interactions at unprecedented levels.

title: QCD Factorization for<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi mathvariant="italic">B</mml:mi><mml:mi/><mml:mo>→</mml:mo><mml:mi/><mml:mi mathvariant="italic">π</mml:mi><mml:mi mathvariant="italic">π</mml:mi></mml:math>Decays: Strong Phases and<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi mathvariant="italic">CP</mml:mi></mml:math>Violation in the Heavy Quark Limit
abstract: We show that, in the heavy quark limit, the hadronic matrix elements that enter $B$ meson decays into two light mesons can be computed from first principles, including `non-factorizable' strong interaction corrections, and expressed in terms of form factors and meson light-cone distribution amplitudes. The conventional factorization result follows in the limit when both power corrections in $1/m_b$ and radiative corrections in $\\alpha_s$ are neglected. We compute the order-$\\alpha_s$ corrections to the decays $B_d\\to\\pi^+\\pi^-$, $B_d\\to\\pi^0\\pi^0$ and $B^+\\to\\pi^+\\pi^0$ in the heavy quark limit and briefly discuss the phenomenological implications for the branching ratios, strong phases and CP violation.
summary:
New Physics Study Unveils Factorization Approach for Heavy Quark Decays

A team of physicists led by M. Beneke, G. Buchalla, Matthias Neubert, and Christopher Sachrajda have made a significant stride in the field of particle physics. Their latest report published in Physical Review Letters presents an innovative method for computing key components in $B$ meson decays involving two light mesons. This breakthrough allows for the inclusion of "non-factorizable" strong interaction corrections and expresses these elements using form factors and meson light-cone distribution amplitudes.

In simpler terms, this work provides a unique first-principles computation strategy in the heavy quark limit for a crucial aspect of B meson decay processes. The report underscores the fundamental factorization result, offering insights when both power corrections in $1/m_b$ and radiative corrections in $\alpha_s$ are disregarded.

Furthermore, the researchers have calculated order-$\alpha_s$ corrections for selected decays, such as $B_d \to \pi^+ \pi^-$, $B_d \to \pi^0 \pi^0$ and $B^+ \to \pi^+ \pi^0$, in the heavy quark limit. Their findings offer valuable information on the branching ratios, strong phases, and CP violation within these decays, contributing to a deeper understanding of this area's complex dynamics.
allAuthors: Μ. Beneke; G. Buchalla; Matthias Neubert; Christopher Sachrajda
institutions: European Organization for Nuclear Research; SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory; Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Lightsource; Stanford University; University of Southampton

title: Aspects of Grand Unified Models with Softly Broken Supersymmetry
abstract: The minimal SU(3)× SU(2)× U(1) gauge model with softly broken supersymmetry is studied in the framework of the standard grand unification. It is assumed that the supersymmetry is left intact at an energy scale μ≃ MX, the grand unification mass scale, except for Majorana masses of gauge fermions. The other soft breaking parameters at low energies are shown to be generated by renormalization effects. The gauge symmetry breaking SU(2)× U(1)→ U(1)em is also caused through radiative corrections. The super-GIM mechanism apparently works well to suppress flavor changing neutral interactions. The mass of the top quark is remarkably found to be constrained as 60 GeV ≾ mt ≾ 180 GeV. Futhermore various mass relations for unconventional particles are obtained as well as crude estimates for numerical masses of them. It is found that there is a plethola of new particles in a mass range from a few tens of GeV to a few hundred GeV.
summary:
**Newspaper Article Headline:**
"Grand Unified Model with Softly Broken Supersymmetry Reveals Top Quark Constraints and Abundance of New Particles, Study Suggests"

**Article Summary:**
Physicists Kenzo Inoue, A. Kakuto, H. Komatsu, and Seiichiro Takeshita have recently published a study in the "Progress of Theoretical Physics", proposing a new perspective within particle physics - the minimal SU(3)× SU(2)× U(1) gauge model with softly broken supersymmetry. This model builds upon the Grand Unified Theory (GUT), aiming to unify the three fundamental forces of nature under a single framework.

The study assumes that supersymmetry holds at the grand unification mass scale, except for Majorana masses of gauge fermions. The researchers have found that other soft breaking parameters at low energies can be generated through renormalization effects, and the SU(2)× U(1) symmetry breaking, leading to the electroweak symmetry breakdown (SU(2)× U(1)→ U(1)em), occurs through radiative corrections.

One of the interesting findings is the successful suppression of flavor-changing neutral interactions by the super-GIM mechanism. Moreover, the study suggests a specific range for the top quark mass: 60 GeV ≾ mt ≾ 180 GeV. Furthermore, various mass relations for unconventional particles are obtained along with crude estimates for their numerical masses. The researchers conclude that this model indicates the presence of a plethora of new particles in a mass range from few tens to hundreds of GeV, broadening our understanding of potential new physics beyond the Standard Model.
allAuthors: Kenzo Inoue; A. Kakuto; H. Komatsu; Seiichiro Takeshita
institutions: Kyushu University; Kindai University

title: Feebly-interacting particles: FIPs 2022 Workshop Report
abstract: AI abstract - This work presents the findings from the Feebly-interacting particles (FIPs) 2022 Workshop, where a multi-disciplinary team of physicists explored potential signatures and detection strategies for dark matter candidates with weak interactions. The report discusses the outcomes of simulations using data from the Large Hadron Collider and other frontier experiments, providing insights into the ongoing search for elusive dark matter particles in particle physics.
summary:
New Research Explores Elusive Dark Matter Particles
-----------------------------------------------------

A collaborative team of physicists recently published their findings from the Feebly-interacting particles (FIPs) 2022 Workshop, investigating potential signatures and detection methods for dark matter candidates with weak interactions. Harnessing data generated by the Large Hadron Collider and other frontier experiments, the report sheds light on the ongoing search for these elusive dark matter particles in particle physics research.

According to the authors of this European Physical Journal C article, their work builds upon prior explorations into dark matter candidates with minimized interactions. The new research serves to support continued efforts in understanding the mysterious substance that makes up approximately 85% of the universe's total matter.

By simulating and analyzing data from various experiments, the team provides insights that contribute to the ongoing mission of identifying and uncovering these illusive particles, which have previously proven challenging to detect due to their minimal interaction with known fundamental forces.

title: Gauge singlet scalars as cold dark matter
abstract: In light of recent interest in minimal extensions of the Standard Model and gauge singlet scalar cold dark matter, we provide an arXiv preprint of the paper, published as Phys.Rev. D50 (1994) 3637, which presented the first detailed analysis of gauge singlet scalar cold dark matter.
summary:
Headline: Research revisits old idea with new perspective: Gauge Singlet Scalars as potential candidates for Cold Dark Matter

A recent preprint delves back into a 1994 study published in Physical Review D, looking at gauge singlet scalars as potential components of cold dark matter. The paper highlights an interesting aspect of minimal extensions of the Standard Model, where gauge singlet scalars are suggested as candidates that were previously overlooked or under-explored, contributing to ongoing research on particle physics and dark matter.

title: QCD at finite baryon density: nucleon droplets and color superconductivity
abstract: AI abstract - We investigate the behavior of quarks and nucleons in Quantum Chromodynamics at finite baryon density, focusing on the formation of nucleon droplets and the emergence of color superconductivity as intriguing phenomena that may shed light on the properties of dense nuclear matter.
summary: In a groundbreaking study published in Physics Letters B, a team of researchers led by Mark Alford, Krishna Rajagopal, and Frank Wilczek have delved into the behavior of quarks and nucleons at high densities using Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). Their investigation focuses on two intriguing phenomena: the formation of nucleon droplets and the emergence of color superconductivity. These findings could potentially unlock new insights about dense nuclear matter. The study builds upon prior work in particle physics, particularly the study of quarks and QCD, and suggests that these concepts may play crucial roles in understanding extreme states of matter.
