title: Implications of dynamical symmetry breaking
abstract: An analysis is presented of the physical implications of theories in which the masses of the intermediate vector bosons arise from a dynamical symmetry breaking. In the absence of elementary spin-zero fields or bare fermion masses, such theories are necessarily invariant to zeroth order in the weak and electromagnetic gauge interactions under a global $\mathrm{U}(N)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}\mathrm{U}(N)$ symmetry, where $N$ is the number of fermion types, not counting color. This symmetry is broken both intrinsically by the weak and electromagnetic interactions and spontaneously by dynamical effects of the strong interactions. An effective Lagrangian is constructed which allows the calculation of leading terms in matrix elements at low energy; this effective Lagrangian is used to analyze the relative direction of the intrinsic and spontaneous symmetry breakdown and to construct a unitarity gauge. Spontaneously broken symmetries which belong to the gauge group of the weak and electromagnetic interactions correspond to fictitious Goldstone bosons which are removed by the Higgs mechanism. Spontaneously broken symmetries of the weak and electromagnetic interactions which are not members of the gauge group correspond to true Goldstone bosons of zero mass; their presence makes it difficult to construct realistic models of this sort. Spontaneously broken elements of $\mathrm{U}(N)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}\mathrm{U}(N)$ which are not symmetries of the weak and electromagnetic interactions correspond to pseudo-Goldstone bosons, with mass comparable to that of the intermediate vector bosons and weak couplings at ordinary energies. Quark masses in these theories are typically less than 300 GeV by factors of order $\ensuremath{\alpha}$. These theories require the existence of "extra-strong" gauge interactions which are not felt at energies below 300 GeV.
summary:
Headline: Nobel Laureate Weinberg Offers Fresh Take on the Golden Rules of Particle Physics

Summary:
In a new publication for Physical Review D, esteemed scientist Steven Weinberg delves into theories revolving around dynamical symmetry breaking – a concept that could reshape our understanding of particle physics. This study revolves around bosons, subatomic particles with integral spin, and aims to establish how these particles' masses derive from dynamic symmetry breaking rather than predefined masses. The work focuses on three primary aspects: (1) a global $\mathrm{U}(N)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}\mathrm{U}(N)$ symmetry is initially maintained due to the absence of elementary spin-zero fields or bare fermion masses; (2) this symmetry is subsequently broken by the interactions between particles, both intrinsically and spontaneously; and (3) the construction of a unitarity gauge for estimating low energy matrix elements. Goldstone bosons, a crucial aspect in the study, can either be fictitious (removed by the Higgs mechanism) or true with zero mass, posing challenges for constructing realistic models. Pseudo-Goldstone bosons, corresponding to broken elements of $\mathrm{U}(N)\ensuremath{\bigotimes}\mathrm{U}(N)$ not linked to the weak and electromagnetic interactions, weigh masses comparable to that of intermediate vector bosons with weak couplings at ordinary energies. Additionally, this research points towards the need for "extra-strong" gauge interactions that aren't detected until energies exceed 300 GeV.

title: Electroweak baryogenesis
abstract: Electroweak baryogenesis (EWBG) remains a theoretically attractive and experimentally testable scenario for explaining the cosmic baryon asymmetry. We review recent progress in computations of the baryon asymmetry within this framework and discuss their phenomenological consequences. We pay particular attention to methods for analyzing the electroweak phase transition and calculating CP-violating asymmetries, the development of Standard Model extensions that may provide the necessary ingredients for EWBG, and searches for corresponding signatures at the high energy, intensity and cosmological frontiers.

title: Wilson renormalization group for lowxphysics: Towards the high density regime
abstract:
We continue the study of the effective action for low $x$ physics based on a
Wilson renormalization group approach. We express the full nonlinear
renormalization group equation in terms of the average value and the average
fluctuation of extra color charge density generated by integrating out gluons
with intermediate values of $x$. This form clearly exhibits the nature of the
phenomena driving the evolution and should serve as the basis of the analysis
of saturation effects at high gluon density at small $x$.
summary:
Headline:
Research advances in understanding high-density physics with new approach to Wilson renormalization group

Newspaper Article:
Scientists from various institutes have published a pioneering paper in the Physical Review, discussing further development of an effective action for low x physics using a Wilson renormalization group approach. This study offers a novel perspective on the nonlinear renormalization group equation, expressing it in terms of average value and fluctuation of extra color charge density generated by integrating out gluons with intermediate values of x. The new formulation promises to provide better insights into saturation effects observed at high gluon density at small x - a critical aspect in the realm of nuclear and particle physics. Additionally, this work may pave the way for deeper understanding and modeling of complex phenomena taking place in highly dense systems.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

institutions: University of Minnesota; University of Oxford; P.N. Lebedev Physical Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences; University of Cambridge

title: Erratum: Rigorous QCD analysis of inclusive annihilation and production of heavy quarkonium [Phys. Rev. D51, 1125 (1995)]
abstract: A rigorous QCD analysis of the inclusive annihilation decay rates of heavy quarkonium states is presented. The effective-field-theory framework of nonrelativistic QCD is used to separate the short-distance scale of annihilation, which is set by the heavy quark mass $M$, from the longer-distance scales associated with quarkonium structure. The annihilation decay rates are expressed in terms of nonperturbative matrix elements of 4-fermion operators in nonrelativistic QCD, with coefficients that can be computed using perturbation theory in the coupling constant $\alpha_s(M)$. The matrix elements are organized into a hierarchy according to their scaling with $v$, the typical velocity of the heavy quark. An analogous factorization formalism is developed for the production cross sections of heavy quarkonium in processes involving momentum transfers of order $M$ or larger. The factorization formulas are applied to the annihilation decay rates and production cross sections of S-wave states, up to corrections of relative order $v^3$, and of P-wave states, up to corrections of relative order $v^2$.
summary:
"Physicists Refine Understanding of Heavy Quarkonium Decay Rates"

In a new paper published in Physical Review D, Geoffrey T. Bodwin, Eric Braaten, and G. Peter Lepage provide a refined analysis of the annihilation and production rates for heavy quarkonium states using quantum chromodynamics (QCD), a theory describing the strong interaction between quarks and gluons.

The researchers employed an effective-field-theory framework from nonrelativistic QCD, separating the short-distance annihilation scale set by the heavy quark mass, from the longer scales related to quarkonium structure. They expressed the decay rates as a combination of nonperturbative matrix elements and coefficients that can be calculated using perturbation theory in the coupling constant (α_s(M)). The Matrix elements are arranged into a hierarchy based on their dependence on v, the typical velocity of the heavy quark.

The study also offers an analogous factorization formalism for the production cross sections of heavy quarkonium in processes involving momentum transfers of approximately M or larger. The researchers applied this factorization to S-wave states up to corrections of relative order v^3, and P-wave states up to corrections of relative order v^2, contributing valuable insights into the behavior of these complex particle systems in various high-energy interactions.

title: Are there real goldstone bosons associated with broken lepton number?
abstract: AI abstract - This work explores the potential existence of real Goldstone bosons associated with the breaking of lepton number, as suggested by the Peccei-Mohapatra-Chikashige model in particle physics. The study further investigates the implications of this hypothesis on the MAJORANA experiment.
summary:
Article Headline:
New Physics Study Suggests Potential Presence of Real Goldstone Bosons and Broken Lepton Number

Summary:
In a newly published paper in Physics Letters B, researchers Yuji Chikashige, R.N. Mohapatra, and R.D. Peccei have explored the concept of real Goldstone bosons associated with broken lepton number. The study builds upon Peccei-Mohapatra-Chikashige model from particle physics, where goldstone bosons are predicted to exist during a specific phase transition. This research delves into the potential implications of this hypothesis on the MAJORANA experiment, an ongoing project in neutrino physics that aims to detect neutrinoless double beta decay – a phenomenon related to lepton number violations. The authors' findings could significantly advance our understanding of particle physics and perhaps revolutionize Neutrino detectors if their theory is supported by future experiments.

institutions: Max Planck Institute for Astrophysics; Max Planck Institute for Physics

title: Asymptotic freedom in deep inelastic processes in the leading order and beyond
abstract: The present status of quantum chromodynamics formalism for inclusive deep-inelastic scattering is reviewed. Leading-order and higher-order asymptotic freedom corrections are discussed in detail. Both the formal language of operator product expansion and renormalization group and the intuitive parton model picture are used. Systematic comparison of asymptotic freedom predictions with deep-inelastic data is presented. Extensions of asymptotic freedom ideas to other processes such as massive $\ensuremath{\mu}$-pair production, semi-inclusive deep-inelastic scattering, ${e}^{+}{e}^{\ensuremath{-}}$ annihilation, and photon-photon scattering are briefly discussed. The importance of higher-order corrections is emphasized.
summary:
Article Headline: "Quantum Chromodynamics Review Highlights Asymptotic Freedom in Deep Inelastic Scattering"

Summary:
In a new review published in Reviews of Modern Physics, Andrzej J. Buras delves into the current status of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) as it pertains to inclusive deep-inelastic scattering. The paper focuses on both leading-order and higher-order corrections related to Asymptotic Freedom, a key concept in QCD. Buras utilizes both sophisticated mathematical language, like Operator Product Expansion and Renormalization Group, as well as the more intuitive Parton Model picture to present a comprehensive overview of the topic. The work also includes a systematic comparison of Asymptotic Freedom predictions with deep-inelastic data, underscoring the significance of higher-order corrections in this field. Beyond deep-inelastic scattering, Buras briefly discusses how asymptotic freedom ideas may extend to other processes such as electron-positron annihilation and photon-photon scattering.

title: Low energy dynamical supersymmetry breaking simplified
abstract: We present a model in which supersymmetry is dynamically broken at comparatively low energies. Previous efforts to construct simple models of this sort have been hampered by the presence of axions. The present model, which exploits an observation of Bagger, Poppitz and Randall to avoid this problem, is far simpler than previous constructions. Models of this kind do not suffer from the naturalness difficulties of conventional supergravity models, and make quite definite predictions for physics over a range of scales from 100’s of GeV to 1000’s of TeV. Thus “Renormalizable Visible Sector Models ” are a viable alternative to more conventional approaches. Our approach also yields a viable example of hidden sector dynamical supersymmetry breaking. 8/94
summary:
Headline: Simplified Model of Low Energy Dynamical Supersymmetry Breaking Offered

Summary: A groundbreaking model that simplifies the process of low energy dynamical supersymmetry breaking has been introduced by researchers Michael Dine, Ann E. Nelson, and Yuri Shirman. This model, published in Physical Review D, overcomes challenges faced in previous constructions due to axions, making it significantly less complex. The new model, based on an observation by Bagger, Poppitz, and Randall, is a notable alternative to conventional supergravity models as it avoids naturalness difficulties and offers precise predictions for physics spanning scales from hundreds of GeV to thousands of TeV. Furthermore, the authors provide a viable example of hidden sector dynamical supersymmetry breaking, which could significantly impact the broader field of physics research.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Strange matter
abstract: We explore the properties of quark matter in equilibrium with the weak interactions, containing comparable numbers of up, down, and strange quarks. Witten has recently conjectured that this "strange matter" may be absolutely stable. Using a Fermi-gas model including $O({\ensuremath{\alpha}}_{c})$ corrections we establish the conditions under which strange matter in bulk is stable and describe its characteristics. Augmenting our model with surface-tension and Coulomb effects we study strange matter with intermediate baryon number ${10}^{2}\ensuremath{\lesssim}A\ensuremath{\lesssim}{10}^{7}$. For low baryon numbers $A\ensuremath{\lesssim}{10}^{2}$, we replace the Fermi gas by the bag model and study shell effects and the approach to the bulk limit. Finally, we discuss the phenomenology of strange matter in all its forms.
summary:
**New Paper Suggests Absolute Stability of "Strange Matter"**

Physicists Edward Farhi and R.L. Jaffe, in a new study published in Physical Review D, explore the properties of a unique form of matter known as "strange matter." This matter contains equal numbers of up, down, and strange quarks, and according to a recent conjecture by Witten, it may be absolutely stable.

In their research, Farhi and Jaffe use a Fermi-gas model including $O({\ensuremath{\alpha}}_{c})$ corrections to establish the conditions under which this strange matter remains stable, detailing its characteristic properties. They also incorporate surface-tension and Coulomb effects to study intermediate-baryon number strange matter, that is, ranging from ${10}^{2}$ to ${10}^{7}$.

For low baryon numbers ($A\ensuremath{\lesssim}{10}^{2}$), the researchers replace the Fermi gas with the bag model and scrutinize shell effects as well as the transition towards the bulk limit. Finally, they discuss the various phenomenological aspects of strange matter in all its forms, shedding light on potential implications for particle physics and nuclear astrophysics.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: Edward Farhi; R. L. Jaffe

title: Evidence for High-Energy Extraterrestrial Neutrinos at the IceCube Detector
abstract: Extraterrestrial Neutrinos Neutrinos are thought to be produced in astrophysical sources outside our solar system but, up until recently, they had only been observed from one supernova in 1987. Aartsen et al. ( 10.1126/science.1242856 ; see the cover) report data obtained between 2010 and 2012 with the IceCube neutrino detector that reveal the presence of a high-energy neutrino flux containing the most energetic neutrinos ever observed, including 28 events at energies between 30 and 1200 TeV. Although the origin of this flux is unknown, the findings are consistent with expectations for a neutrino population with origins outside the solar system.
summary:
**Headline:**
"IceCube Neutrino Detector Sparks Extraterrestrial Life Debate with Discovery of High-Energy Neutrinos"

**Summary:**
In a groundbreaking discovery, scientists from the IceCube Collaboration – led by M. G. Aartsen – have detected high-energy neutrinos at the South Pole's IceCube Detector. This finding marks the first observation of such particles coming from sources beyond our solar system, surpassing the previous record set by a 1987 supernova. With an unprecedented energy range between 30 and 1200 TeV encompassed in 28 events, this extraterrestrial neutrino flux could stem from astrophysical phenomena outside our solar system, potentially opening the door to new speculations about distant cosmic mysteries and potential signs of extraterrestrial life. [Science]

title: CP-conserving two-Higgs-doublet model: The approach to the decoupling limit
abstract: A CP-even neutral Higgs boson with Standard-Model-like couplings may be the lightest scalar of a two-Higgs-doublet model. We study the decoupling limit of the most general CP-conserving two-Higgs-doublet model, where the mass of the lightest Higgs scalar is significantly smaller than the masses of the other Higgs bosons of the model. In this case, the properties of the lightest Higgs boson are nearly indistinguishable from those of the Standard Model Higgs boson. The first non-trivial corrections to Higgs couplings in the approach to the decoupling limit are also evaluated. The importance of detecting such deviations in precision Higgs measurements at future colliders is emphasized. We also clarify the case in which a neutral Higgs boson can possess Standard-Model-like couplings in a regime where the decoupling limit does not apply. The two-Higgs-doublet sector of the minimal supersymmetric model illustrates many of the above features.
summary:
**Physicists explore the future of Higgs Boson research**

In a new study published in *Physical Review D*, John F. Gunion and Howard E. Haber present an analysis of the decoupling limit of CP-conserving two-Higgs-doublet models, shedding light on potential discoveries at future colliders. The research builds upon previous investigations into the properties of Higgs bosons, focusing particularly on the lightest scalar - a CP-even neutral Higgs Boson that may exhibit Standard Model-like couplings.

The authors delve into the implications of this scenario, emphasizing that small yet significant deviations from Standard Model predictions could offer compelling evidence for the more complex two-Higgs-doublet models. The minimal supersymmetric model, in particular, provides a prime example where such features manifest.

As precision measurements at future colliders become increasingly detailed, the clarification of these subtleties and their potential detection will serve as a crucial next step for particle physics research, paving the way for a more comprehensive understanding of the world beyond our current models.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: John F. Gunion; Howard E. Haber
institutions: University of California, Davis; University of California, Santa Cruz

title: From the Trees to the Forest: A Review of Radiative Neutrino Mass Models
abstract:
A plausible explanation for the lightness of neutrino masses is that
neutrinos are massless at tree level, with their mass (typically Majorana)
being generated radiatively at one or more loops. The new couplings, together
with the suppression coming from the loop factors, imply that the new degrees
of freedom cannot be too heavy (they are typically at the TeV scale).
Therefore, in these models there are no large mass hierarchies and they can be
tested using different searches, making their detailed phenomenological study
very appealing. In particular, the new particles can be searched for at
colliders and generically induce signals in lepton-flavor and lepton-number
violating processes (in the case of Majorana neutrinos), which are not
independent from reproducing correctly the neutrino masses and mixings. The
main focus of the review is on Majorana neutrinos. We order the allowed theory
space from three different perspectives: (i) using an effective operator
approach to lepton number violation, (ii) by the number of loops at which the
Weinberg operator is generated, (iii) within a given loop order, by the
possible irreducible topologies. We also discuss in more detail some popular
radiative models which involve qualitatively different features, revisiting
their most important phenomenological implications. Finally, we list some
promising avenues to pursue.
summary:
Paper Review: "Radiative Neutrino Mass Models" Explored
--------------------------------------------------------

In a new review article published in Frontiers in Physics, researchers Yi Cai, Juan Herrero-García, Michael A. Schmidt, Avelino Vicente, and Raymond R. Volkas delve into the realm of Majorana neutrinos and their mass generation via radiative processes.

The paper focuses on a theory where neutrinos are massless at their base level (tree level), but acquire mass through higher-order loop processes. This approach, known as radiative neutrino mass models, suggests that any new particles associated with this mass generation would likely be within the TeV scale and could potentially be discovered in collider experiments.

The study highlights the importance of these models due to their ability to predict lepton-flavor and lepton-number violating processes, particularly for Majorana neutrinos. The researchers outline three perspectives to navigate the vast theory space: (i) through effective operators of lepton number violation, (ii) by the number of loops generating the Weinberg operator, and (iii) within a loop order, by examining possible topologies.

The review also provides in-depth analysis on popular radiative models with distinct features and their key phenomenological implications, as well as pointing out promising directions for future research.
allAuthors: Yi Cai; Juan Herrero-García; Michael A. Schmidt; Avelino Vicente; Raymond R. Volkas
institutions: ARC Centre of Excellence for Particle Physics at the Terascale; The University of Melbourne; Sun Yat-sen University; The University of Adelaide; The University of Sydney; Instituto de Física Corpuscular; Universitat de València

title: Accurate charge-dependent nucleon-nucleon potential at fourth order of chiral perturbation theory
abstract: We present the first nucleon-nucleon potential at next-to-next-to-next-to-leading order (fourth order) of chiral perturbation theory. Charge-dependence is included up to next-to-leading order of the isospin-violation scheme. The accuracy for the reproduction of the NN data below 290 MeV lab. energy is comparable to the one of phenomenological high-precision potentials. Since NN potentials of order three and less are known to be deficient in quantitative terms, the present work shows that the fourth order is necessary and sufficient for a reliable NN potential derived from chiral effective Lagrangians. The new potential provides a promising starting point for exact few-body calculations and microscopic nuclear structure theory (including chiral many-body forces derived on the same footing).
summary:
Title: New, Accurate Charged Nucleon Potential Developed in Fourth Order of Chiral Perturbation Theory

Subhead: Physics breakthrough could advance nuclear science research

In an important contribution to nuclear physics, researchers D. R. Entem and R. Machleidt have developed a new nucleon-nucleon potential at fourth order (next-to-next-to-next-to-leading) of chiral perturbation theory. This is the first such potential presented which includes charge-dependence up to next-to-leading order in the isospin-violation scheme.

The new potential achieved comparable accuracy for the reproduction of nuclear data below 290 MeV lab energy to that of existing high-precision phenomenological potentials, marking a significant improvement over previous potentials of order three or less that have been found to fall short in quantitative terms. This work indicates that the fourth order derivation from chiral effective Lagrangians is both necessary and sufficient for a reliable NN potential.

The novel potential paves the way for more exact few-body calculations and microscopic nuclear structure theory, offering promising new insights into the behavior of nucleons in atomic nuclei. The work has been published in Physical Review C.
allAuthors: D. R. Entem; R. Machleidt
institutions: Universidad de Salamanca; University of Idaho

title: Electroweak gauge boson production at hadron colliders through<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi mathvariant="script">O</mml:mi><mml:mo stretchy="false">(</mml:mo><mml:msubsup><mml:mi>α</mml:mi><mml:mi>s</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msubsup><mml:mo stretchy="false">)</mml:mo></mml:math>
abstract: We describe a calculation of the O(alpha_s^2) QCD corrections to the fully differential cross section for W and Z boson production in hadronic collisions. The result is fully realistic in that it includes spin correlations, finite width effects, gamma-Z interference and allows for the application of arbitrary cuts on the leptonic decay products of the W and Z. We have implemented this calculation into a numerical program. We demonstrate the use of this code by presenting phenomenological results for several future LHC analyses and recent Tevatron measurements, including the W cross section in the forward rapidity region and the central over forward cross section ratio.
summary:
Title: New Advancement in Electroweak Boson Production at Hadron Colliders

Physicists Kirill Melnikov and Frank Petriello have made a significant breakthrough in their calculation of QCD corrections to the fully differential cross section for W and Z boson production in hadronic collisions. The work, published in Physical Review D, delves into the intricate realm of particle physics where the electroweak interaction intertwines with quantum chromodynamics (QCD). Their findings are not only rigorous enough to accommodate spin correlations and finite width effects but also enable the application of arbitrary cuts on leptonic decay products. The new numerical program, embodying their research, promises a deeper understanding of electroweak boson production at future LHC analyses and recent Tevatron measurements. Results so far include predictions for the W cross section in the forward rapidity region and the central over forward cross section ratio.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology
allAuthors: Kirill Melnikov; Frank Petriello
institutions: University of Hawaii System; University of Wisconsin–Madison

title: Reactor antineutrino anomaly
abstract:
Recently new reactor antineutrino spectra have been provided for 235U, 239Pu,
241Pu and 238U, increasing the mean flux by about 3 percent. To good
approximation, this reevaluation applies to all reactor neutrino experiments.
The synthesis of published experiments at reactor-detector distances <100 m
leads to a ratio of observed event rate to predicted rate of 0.976(0.024). With
our new flux evaluation, this ratio shifts to 0.943(0.023), leading to a
deviation from unity at 98.6% C.L. which we call the reactor antineutrino
anomaly. The compatibility of our results with the existence of a fourth
non-standard neutrino state driving neutrino oscillations at short distances is
discussed. The combined analysis of reactor data, gallium solar neutrino
calibration experiments, and MiniBooNE-neutrino data disfavors the
no-oscillation hypothesis at 99.8% C.L. The oscillation parameters are such
that |Delta m_{new}^2|>1.5 eV^2 (95%) and sin^2(2\theta_{new})=0.14(0.08)
(95%). Constraints on the theta13 neutrino mixing angle are revised.
summary:
Title: New Reactor Antineutrino Findings Suggest Oscillation Puzzle Deepens

Subhead: Study by Mention et al. published in Physical Review D, Particles, Fields, Gravitation, and Cosmology reveals an anomaly in reactor antineutrino data that could suggest the existence of a fourth neutrino state.

Summary: A new evaluation of reactor antineutrino spectra has led to a 3 percent increase in mean flux, with implications for all experiments involving these subatomic particles at distances under 100 meters. The analysis conducted by researchers G. Mention, M. Fechner, and others reveals a discrepancy between observed event rates and predicted ones, labeled the "reactor antineutrino anomaly." This shift challenges the current understanding of neutrino oscillation, prompting debate over the potential existence of a fourth non-standard state of neutrinos that could drive oscillations at short distances. The study's results also challenge the "no-oscillation" hypothesis, as the combined analysis of reactor data, gallium solar neutrino calibration experiments, and MiniBooNE-neutrino data makes it possible to rule out the absence of oscillation with 99.8% confidence. The study's findings could potentially revise constraints on the theta13 neutrino mixing angle.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology
allAuthors: G. Mention; M. Fechner; Th. Lasserre; Th. A. Mueller; D. Lhuillier; M. Cribier; A. Letourneau
institutions: CEA Paris-Saclay; Commissariat à l'Énergie Atomique et aux Énergies Alternatives; Institut de Recherche sur les Lois Fondamentales de l'Univers; Laboratoire AstroParticule et Cosmologie

title: A comprehensive guide to the physics and usage of PYTHIA 8.3
abstract: This manual describes the Pythia event generator, the most recent version of an evolving physics tool used to answer fundamental questions in particle physics. The program is most often used to generate high-energy-physics collision “events”, i.e. sets of particles produced in association with the collision of two incoming high-energy particles, but has several uses beyond that. The guiding philosophy is to produce and re-produce properties of experimentally obtained collisions as accurately as possible. The program includes a wide ranges of reactions within and beyond the Standard Model, and extending to heavy ion physics. Emphasis is put on phenomena where strong interactions play a major role. The manual contains both pedagogical and practical components. All included physics models are described in enough detail to allow the user to obtain a cursory overview of used assumptions and approximations, enabling an informed evaluation of the program output. A number of the most central algorithms are described in enough detail that the main results of the program can be reproduced independently, allowing further development of existing models or the addition of new ones. Finally, a chapter dedicated fully to the user is included towards the end, providing pedagogical examples of standard use cases, and a detailed description of a number of external interfaces. The program code, the online manual, and the latest version of this print manual can be found on the Pythia web page: https://www.pythia.org/.
summary:
Title: "New Comprehensive Guide Simplifies High-Energy Physics with PYTHIA 8.3"

Summary:
A group of researchers has released a comprehensive guide for PYTHIA 8.3, the latest evolution of a powerful physics tool used to address fundamental questions in particle physics. The program, primarily used for generating high-energy particle collision events, extends to numerous other uses as well. According to the study published in SciPost Physics Codebases, the manual aims to reproduce properties of experimentally obtained collisions with unprecedented accuracy. This latest update includes a wide range of reactions within and beyond the Standard Model and applies particular emphasis on phenomena involving strong interactions. The guide offers both theoretical and practical components, detailing the physics models for users to evaluate program output, as well as allowing reproduction of key algorithms for independent research and further development. The complete program, online manual, and print manual can be found on the Pythia web page.

title: QCD Matrix Elements + Parton Showers
abstract:
We propose a method for combining QCD matrix elements and parton showers in
Monte Carlo simulations of hadronic final states in $e^+e^-$ annihilation. The
matrix element and parton shower domains are separated at some value $y_{ini}$
of the jet resolution, defined according to the $k_T$-clustering algorithm. The
matrix elements are modified by Sudakov form factors and the parton showers are
subjected to a veto procedure to cancel dependence on $y_{ini}$ to
next-to-leading logarithmic accuracy. The method provides a leading-order
description of hard multi-jet configurations together with jet fragmentation,
while avoiding the most serious problems of double counting. We present first
results of an approximate implementation using the event generator APACIC++.
summary:
Article Headline:
"New Method Combines QCD Matrix Elements and Parton Showers for Improved Analysis of High-Energy Physics Events"

Summary:
In a new paper published in the Journal of High Energy Physics,Stefano Catani, Frank Krauss, B.R. Webber, and Ralf Kuhn propose a groundbreaking method to merge Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) matrix elements and parton showers in Monte Carlo simulations of high-energy particle collisions, specifically focusing on $e^+e^-$ annihilation events. The researchers separate the matrix element and parton shower domains using a jet resolution parameter called $y_{ini}$, defined through the $k_T$-clustering algorithm. They modify the matrix elements with Sudakov form factors and subject the parton showers to a veto procedure for next-to-leading logarithmic accuracy, providing an efficient way to describe complex multi-jet configurations that includes jet fragmentation while minimizing double counting issues. The authors present initial findings using the event generator APACIC++, offering promise for future advancements in particle physics studies.

Collider Data Shed Light on Elusive Higgs Boson: A Significant Step Towards Standard Model Confirmation

Summary:
Physics researchers have made progress in their search for the elusive Standard Model Higgs boson, using data collected from proton-proton collisions at a high energy of 7 TeV. The study, led by the CMS collaboration during the Large Hadron Collider's initial operation phase in 2012, brings scientists closer to confirming the theory underlying particle physics known as the Standard Model. This latest study contributes crucial information towards understanding the Higgs boson and its role in our universe.

title: Physics beyond colliders at CERN: beyond the Standard Model working group report
abstract: Abstract The Physics Beyond Colliders initiative is an exploratory study aimed at exploiting the full scientific potential of the CERN’s accelerator complex and scientific infrastructures through projects complementary to the LHC and other possible future colliders. These projects will target fundamental physics questions in modern particle physics. This document presents the status of the proposals presented in the framework of the Beyond Standard Model physics working group, and explore their physics reach and the impact that CERN could have in the next 10–20 years on the international landscape.
summary:
Title: "Exploring Beyond Standard Model Physics: Experts Propose New Directions at CERN"

Summary:
A team of distinguished physicists has put forward a comprehensive plan to uncover mysteries in modern particle physics, going beyond the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN. Known as the 'Physics Beyond Colliders' initiative, the proposals aim to harness the full scientific potential of CERN's accelerator complex and infrastructure for projects that complement future colliders. The report, compiled by J. B. Beacham and colleagues, discusses the current state of proposals from the Beyond Standard Model physics working group, their anticipated impact on the international landscape, and their potential to answer fundamental physics questions not within the scope of the LHC in the next decade or more.

title: Diquark Bose Condensates in High Density Matter and Instantons
abstract:
Instantons lead to strong correlations between up and down quarks with spin
zero and anti-symmetric color wave functions. In cold and dense matter,
$n_b>n_c\simeq 1 fm^{-3}$ and $T<T_c\sim$ 50 MeV, these pairs Bose-condense,
replacing the usual $< \bar qq >$ condensate and restoring chiral symmetry. At
high density, the ground state is a color superconductor in which diquarks play
the role of Cooper pairs. An interesting toy model is provided by QCD with two
colors: it has a particle-anti-particle symmetry which relates $<\bar qq>$ and
$< qq>$ condensates.
summary:
In a groundbreaking study published in Physical Review Letters, Ralf Rapp and colleagues explore the formation of diquark Bose condensates in high-density matter. The researchers build upon the theory that instantons – exotic solutions of non-abelian theories – cause strong correlations between up and down quarks with spin-zero and anti-symmetric color wave functions.

At nuclear densities greater than critical values, these diquark pairs are posited to Bose-condense, restoring chiral symmetry and transforming the matter into a color superconductor as proposed in quantum chromodynamics (QCD). This intriguing model, presented by Rapp, Schäfer, Shuryak, and Velkovsky, also introduces an interesting parallel between QCD with two colors: it holds a particle-antiparticle symmetry that relates traditional $< \bar{qq}>$ condensates to the newly proposed diquark condensates. The findings have profound implications for our understanding of high-density matter and could potentially advance theories concerning the fundamental nature of quarks and strong interactions in physics.
allAuthors: Ralf Rapp; Thomas Schäfer; Edward Shuryak; M. Velkovsky
institutions: State University of New York; University of Washington; Brookhaven National Laboratory

title: Improved naturalness with a heavy Higgs boson: An alternative road to CERN LHC physics
abstract: The quadratic divergences of the Higgs mass may be cancelled either accidentally or by the exchange of some new particles. Alternatively its impact on naturalness may be weakened by raising the Higgs mass, which requires changing the Standard Model below its natural cut-off. We show in detail how this can be achieved, while preserving perturbativity and consistency with the electroweak precision tests, by extending the Standard Model to include a second Higgs doublet that has neither a vev nor couplings to quarks and leptons. This Inert Doublet Model yields a perturbative and completely natural description of electroweak physics at all energies up to 1.5 TeV. The discrete symmetry that yields the Inert Doublet is unbroken, so that Dark Matter may be composed of neutral inert Higgs bosons, which may have escaped detection at LEP2. Predictions are given for multilepton events with missing transverse energy at the Large Hadron Collider, and for the direct detection of dark matter.
summary:
Headline: Alternative approach proposed to strengthen Higgs Boson's naturalness in CERN LHC physics

Summary: In a new study published in Physical Review, researchers Riccardo Barbieri, Lawrence J. Hall, and Slava Rychkov present an innovative approach that seeks to enhance the 'naturalness' of the Higgs boson within the broader context of particle physics. The study builds upon previous research around quadratic divergences affecting the Higgs mass and suggests a solution by extending the Standard Model with an additional Higgs doublet. This new model preserves perturbativity and aligns with electroweak precision tests, offering a natural description of electroweak physics up to 1.5 TeV without compromising the Large Hadron Collider's physics findings. The study further proposes potential detection methods for dark matter composed of neutral inert Higgs bosons that may have been missed at previous experiments such as LEP2 and offers predictions for multilepton events with missing transverse energy at the Large Hadron Collider.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D, Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology

title: A Complete Analysis of FCNC and CP Constraints in General SUSY Extensions of the Standard Model
abstract: We analyze the full set of constraints on gluino- and photino-mediated SUSY contributions to FCNC and CP violating phenomena. We use the mass insertion method, hence providing a model-independent parameterization which can be readily applied in testing extensions of the MSSM. In addition to clarifying controversial points in the literature, we provide a more exhaustive analysis of the CP constraints, in particular concerning ε ′ /ε. As physically meaningful applications of our analysis, we study the implications in SUSY-GUT’s and effective supergravities with flavour non-universality. This allows us to detail the domain of applicability and the correct In looking for new physics beyond the electroweak Standard Model (SM) it is useful to regard the SM itself as an effective low energy theory valid up to some energy scale Λ at which the new physics sets in. One is then led to write all possible operators invariant under SU(3)⊗SU(2)⊗U(1) using the fields of the SM. They can be organized according to
summary:
**Newspaper Headline:
Researchers Explore New Physics Frontier with Analysis of SUSY Extensions in Particle Physics**

Summary:
A group of scientists, led by Fabrizio Gabbiani, Emidio Gabrielli, A. Masiero, and L. Silvestrini, have released a paper delving into the constraints of supersymmetry (SUSY) extensions within the Standard Model of particle physics. The study focuses on the analysis of flavour-changing neutral currents (FCNC) and CP violating phenomena, using gluino- and photino-mediated SUSY contributions. This model-independent work offers valuable insights into testing extensions of the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (MSSM), aiming to clarify discrepancies in previous literature and provide a comprehensive analysis, particularly concerning the ε'/ε ratio. The researchers also explore implications for SUSY-GUT models and effective supergravities dealing with flavour non-universality, thereby outlining the domain of applicability and guiding further research into physics beyond the electroweak Standard Model.

title: A next-generation liquid xenon observatory for dark matter and neutrino physics
abstract: Abstract The nature of dark matter and properties of neutrinos are among the most pressing issues in contemporary particle physics. The dual-phase xenon time-projection chamber is the leading technology to cover the available parameter space for weakly interacting massive particles, while featuring extensive sensitivity to many alternative dark matter candidates. These detectors can also study neutrinos through neutrinoless double-beta decay and through a variety of astrophysical sources. A next-generation xenon-based detector will therefore be a true multi-purpose observatory to significantly advance particle physics, nuclear physics, astrophysics, solar physics, and cosmology. This review article presents the science cases for such a detector.
summary:
Title: Scientists outline plans for advanced dark matter and neutrino detector

New paper published in Journal of Physics G Nuclear and Particle Physics proposes the development of a next-generation liquid xenon observatory. The project, led by an international team comprising over 150 scientists from around the world, aims to address some of the most intriguing questions in contemporary physics.

The proposed detector, utilizing cutting-edge dual-phase xenon time-projection chamber technology, will focus on unraveling the mystery of dark matter and exploring neutrino properties. The new observatory will push boundaries by offering sensitivity to various alternative dark matter candidates as well as enabling studies on neutrinoless double-beta decay and multiple astral sources. If successful, this multi-purpose facility is expected to make significant strides in particle physics, nuclear physics, astrophysics, solar physics, and cosmology.

abstract: AI abstract - This work presents a resummation of the perturbative series for hard processes in Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), focusing on the annihilation of particles. The authors propose a method to improve the convergence of the series, thereby providing more accurate predictions for high-energy particle physics experiments.

Researchers Stefano Catani and L. Trentadue reveal a groundbreaking method in the Nuclear Physics B journal, aiming to enhance the precision of high-energy particle physics experiments through resummation of perturbative series for hard processes in Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). The focus is on particle annihilation, and this innovative approach seeks to improve the convergence of the series, providing more accurate predictions.

title: Charmonium and gluons
abstract: AI abstract - This work presents an in-depth study of Charmonium and gluons within the framework of Quantum Chromodynamics. The authors explore the properties and interactions of these particles, contributing to our understanding of mesons and the fundamental nature of gluons in particle physics.
summary:
New Research Deepens Understanding of Charmonium and Gluons

In a groundbreaking study published by Physics Reports, an international team of scientists has delved into the complex world of Charmonium and gluons within the realm of Quantum Chromodynamics. The research sheds light on the properties and interactions of these particles, adding crucial insights to our understanding of mesons and the fundamental nature of gluons in particle physics. This work builds upon previous studies regarding the behavior of Charmonium and continues the pursuit of unraveling intricate connections between quantum mechanics and the strong force that governs the interactions between quarks in subatomic particles.

title: Baryon spectroscopy
abstract:
About 120 baryons and baryon resonances are known, from the abundant nucleon
with $u$ and $d$ light-quark constituents up to the recently discovered
$\Omega_b^-=bss$, and the $\Xi_b^-=bsd$ which contains one quark of each
generation. In spite of this impressively large number of states, the
underlying mechanisms leading to the excitation spectrum are not yet
understood. Heavy-quark baryons suffer from a lack of known spin-parities. In
the light-quark sector, quark-model calculations have met with considerable
success in explaining the low-mass excitations spectrum but some important
aspects like the mass degeneracy of positive-parity and negative-parity baryon
excitations are not yet satisfactorily understood. At high masses, above 1.8
GeV, quark models predict a very high density of resonances per mass interval
which is not observed. In this review, issues are identified discriminating
between different views of the resonance spectrum; prospects are discussed how
open questions in baryon spectroscopy may find answers from photo- and
electro-production experiments which are presently carried out in various
laboratories.
summary:
New Review Shines Light on the Exciting World of Baryon Spectroscopy

In a new review published in Reviews of Modern Physics, two experts delve into the complexities of baryon spectroscopy, a key area within nuclear and particle physics. The paper explains over 120 known baryons and baryon resonances, including recently discovered heavy-quark baryons like the $\Omega_b^-$ and $\Xi_b^-$. Despite this impressive tally, the underlying mechanisms behind these states remain elusive.

The review highlights that while quark model calculations have been successful in explaining the low-mass excitement spectrum, the mass degeneracy of positive-parity and negative-parity baryon excitations remains a mystery. In higher masses above 1.8 GeV, quark models predict an unusually high density of resonances per mass interval, which contradicts current observations.

The review discusses possible answers to open questions in baryon spectroscopy and looks forward to photo- and electroproduction experiments currently being conducted at various laboratories as potential sources of insights.
allAuthors: E. Klempt; Jean-Marc Richard
institutions: University of Bonn

title: U(1) without instantons
abstract: AI abstract - This work presents an exploration of U(1) gauge theory in the absence of instantons, shedding light on the implications for Quantum Chromodynamics and the potential role of algebraically closed fields in this context. The paper delves into the theoretical framework without instantons, offering a significant contribution to our understanding of non-perturbative effects in quantum field theories.
summary:
Headline: "New Perspective on Gauge Theories: U(1) without Instantons Offered"

Summary:
Giacomo Veneziano's paper published in Nuclear Physics B provides a fresh outlook on U(1) gauge theory, a fundamental concept in Quantum Chromodynamics. The research focuses on exploring the theory without instantons, which are crucial for understanding non-perturbative effects in quantum field theories. The study offers insights into the potential role of algebraically closed fields and could pave the way for a deeper comprehension of gauge theories and their applications.
allAuthors: G. Veneziano
institutions: European Organization for Nuclear Research

title: Bounds on universal extra dimensions
abstract: We show that the bound from the electroweak data on the size of extra dimensions accessible to all the standard model fields is rather loose. These “universal” extra dimensions could have a compactification scale as low as 300 GeV for one extra dimension. This is because the Kaluza-Klein number is conserved and thus the contributions to the electroweak observables arise only from loops. The main constraint comes from weak-isospin violation effects. We also compute the contributions to the S parameter and the Zb ¯ b vertex. The direct bound on the compactification scale is set by CDF and D0 in the few hundred GeV range, and the Run II of the Tevatron will either discover extra dimensions or else it could significantly raise the bound on the compactification scale. In the case of two universal extra dimensions, the current lower bound on the compactification scale depends logarithmically on the ultra-violet cutoff of the higher dimensional theory, but can be estimated to lie between 400 and 800 GeV. With three or more extra dimensions, the cutoff dependence may be too strong to allow an estimate.
summary: In "Bounds on Universal Extra Dimensions," researchers led by Thomas Appelquist at Physical Review suggest a relatively lenient bound for the size of 'universal' extra dimensions accessible to standard model fields, potentially as low as 300 GeV for one added dimension. The study highlights that the Kaluza-Klein number conservation restricts impacts on electroweak observables, mainly due to loop contributions. Main constraints originate from weak-isospin violation effects. Furthermore, the paper calculates the influence on the S parameter and Zb ¯ b vertex while direct bounds on compactification scale are set by CDF and D0 within a few hundred GeV range, with Tevatron Run II poised to either discover extra dimensions or raise the boundary even further. For two universal extra dimensions, the lower bound depends logarithmically on the higher dimensional theory's ultraviolet cutoff, ranging between 400 and 800 GeV, but estimations in three or more cases may prove too complex.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

abstract: AI abstract - This work presents a comprehensive review of the role and implications of neutrinos in cosmology, discussing their contribution to the cosmic neutrino background, leptogenesis, and other related phenomena. The paper delves into the current understanding of these topics and explores potential future directions in neutrino research within the cosmological context.

Headline: "Comprehensive Review Challenges Our Understanding of Neutrinos in Cosmology"

Summary:
In a new paper published in Physics Reports, physicist A. D. Dolgov reviews the role and implications of neutrinos in cosmic evolution. The work discusses the contribution of neutrinos to the cosmic neutrino background, leptogenesis – a theory of baryon asymmetry – and other related phenomena. By examining the latest research findings, the paper provides an overview of our current understanding of these topics and offers ideas for future directions in neutrino studies within the cosmological context. The research could potentially reshape our comprehension of the universe's fundamental building blocks and their role in its formation.

title: Four-dimensional string compactifications with D-branes, orientifolds and fluxes

title: Measurement of Day and Night Neutrino Energy Spectra at SNO and Constraints on Neutrino Mixing Parameters
abstract: The Sudbury Neutrino Observatory (SNO) has measured day and night solar neutrino energy spectra and rates. For charged current events, assuming an undistorted 8B spectrum, the night minus day rate is 14.0%+/-6.3%(+1.5%)(-1.4%) of the average rate. If the total flux of active neutrinos is additionally constrained to have no asymmetry, the nu(e) asymmetry is found to be 7.0%+/-4.9%(+1.3%)(-1.2%). A global solar neutrino analysis in terms of matter-enhanced oscillations of two active flavors strongly favors the large mixing angle solution.
summary:
Groundbreaking Research in Physics Sheds Light on Solar Neutrinos

In a recent study published in Physical Review Letters, a team of scientists led by Rushdy Ahmad and including over 100 collaborators, measured day and night solar neutrino energy spectra at the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory (SNO). Their findings reveal an intriguing 14.0% discrepancy in rates between day and night, suggesting a potential asymmetry in the flux of active neutrinos.

The research, which builds upon previous work on solar neutrinos, found a nu(e) asymmetry of 7.0%, reinforcing the large mixing angle solution in global solar neutrino analysis. This breakthrough represents another key step towards understanding one of the longest-standing mysteries in particle physics: the solar neutrino problem.

title: Nonlinear Realizations of Chiral Symmetry
abstract: We explore possible realizations of chiral symmetry, based on isotopic multiplets of fields whose transformation rules involve only isotopic-spin matrices and the pion field. The transformation rules are unique, up to possible redefinitions of the pion field. Chiral-invariant Lagrangians can be constructed by forming isotopic-spin-conserving functions of a covariant pion derivative, plus other fields and their covariant derivatives. The resulting models are essentially equivalent to those that have been derived by treating chirality as an ordinary linear symmetry broken by the vacuum, except that we do not have to commit ourselves as to the grouping of hadrons into chiral multiplets; as a result, the unrenormalized value of $\frac{{g}_{A}}{{g}_{V}}$ need not be unity. We classify the possible choices of the chiral-symmetry-breaking term in the Lagrangian according to their chiral transformation properties, and give the values of the pion-pion scattering lengths for each choice. If the symmetry-breaking term has the simplest possible transformation properties, then the scattering lengths are those previously derived from current algebra. An alternative method of constructing chiral-invariant Lagrangians, using $\ensuremath{\rho}$ mesons to form covariant derivatives, is also presented. In this formalism, $\ensuremath{\rho}$ dominance is automatic, and the current-algebra result from the $\ensuremath{\rho}$-meson coupling constant arises from the independent assumption that $\ensuremath{\rho}$ mesons couple universally to pions and other particles. Including $\ensuremath{\rho}$ mesons in the Lagrangian has no effect on the $\ensuremath{\pi}\ensuremath{-}\ensuremath{\pi}$ scattering lengths, because chiral invariance requires that we also include direct pion self-couplings which cancel the $\ensuremath{\rho}$-exchange diagrams for pion energies near threshold.
summary:
Article Headline:
Weinberg Proposes New Approach to Pion Symmetry Breaking in Particle Physics

Summary:
In a groundbreaking article published in Physical Review, renowned physicist Steven Weinberg introduces a novel approach to understanding chiral symmetry, particularly its breaking, within particle physics. Instead of treating chirality as an ordinary linear symmetry, Weinberg's theory utilizes isotopic-multiplets of fields that involve only isotopic-spin matrices and the pion field for transformation rules. This unique approach allows a more flexible classification of choices for the chiral-symmetry-breaking term in the Lagrangian and provides new insight into pion-pion scattering lengths, potentially altering the value of a crucial ratio governing nuclear forces. The author also presents an alternative method using rho mesons to construct chiral-invariant Lagrangians, which has implications for understanding how rho mesons couple with other particles, including pions.

institutions: Massachusetts Institute of Technology

title: Soft-gluon resummation for Higgs boson production at hadron colliders
abstract:
AI abstract -
We present a soft-gluon resummation approach for the production of Higgs bosons at hadron colliders, focusing on the Tevatron. This study is aimed at improving the precision of Higgs boson production cross sections by systematically accounting for higher-order corrections in the perturbative expansion.
summary:
Study Advances Prediction of Higgs Boson Production at Tevatron Collider

Researchers Stefano Catani, Daniel de Florian, Massimiliano Grazzini and Paolo Nason have published a paper in Journal of High Energy Physics proposing a new method to enhance the precision of predictions for Higgs boson production at hadron colliders. The focus is primarily on the Tevatron, an early high-energy particle accelerator.

The innovative approach, termed 'soft-gluon resummation', aims to refine the accuracy of cross sections for Higgs boson production by systematically incorporating higher-order corrections in the theoretical framework. This can potentially provide essential insights into the behavior of these particles at the fundamental level.

title: Explanation and prediction of observables using continuum strong QCD
abstract: AI abstract - We present an explanation and prediction method for observables in high-energy physics using the framework of continuum strong QCD. The study is conducted through the application of parton distribution functions within the context of quantum chromodynamics, focusing on hadron properties and their associated observables.
summary: In "Explanation and Prediction of Observables Using Continuum Strong QCD," researchers Ian C. Cloët and Craig D. Roberts propose a novel method to understand and forecast high-energy physics observables. This study revolves around the framework of strong quantum chromodynamics (QCD) and employs parton distribution functions to analyze hadron properties and their associated observables, building upon prior work in quantum chromodynamics and furthering efforts to explain complex phenomena in particle and nuclear physics.

title: Improved parton distributions from global analysis of recent deep inelastic scattering and inclusive jet data
abstract: The impact of recent precision measurements of DIS structure functions and inclusive jet production at the Tevatron on the global QCD analysis of parton distribution functions is studied in detail. Particular emphasis is placed on exploring the range of variation of the gluon distribution G(x,Q) allowed by these new data. The strong coupling of G(x,Q) with αs is fully taken into account. A new generation of CTEQ parton distributions, CTEQ4, is presented. It consists of the three standard sets (MS, DIS and leading order), a series that gives a range of parton distributions with corresponding αs’s, and a set with a low starting value of Q. Previously obtained gluon distributions that are consistent with the high Et jet cross-section are also discussed in the context of this new global analysis. Lepton-lepton, lepton-hadron, and hadron-hadron interactions probe different and complementary aspects of Quantum Chromodynamics. Each of these interactions provides a window onto the elementary interactions of quarks and gluons and probes the running coupling
summary:
Title: New Parton Distribution Functions Unveiled for Deep Inelastic Scattering and Jet Production

In an innovative study published in Physical Review D, a team led by H. L. Lai has presented a new generation of parton distribution functions called CTEQ4. This work builds upon recent precision measurements from the Tevatron, focusing on deep inelastic scattering (DIS) structure functions and inclusive jet production.

These new functions improve our understanding of Quantum Chromodynamics, particularly the behavior of gluons. The study takes into account the strong coupling between the gluon distribution (G(x,Q)) and the strong coupling constant αs, providing a more accurate picture of the parton structure of hadrons.

The CTEQ4 series offers various parton distributions with corresponding αs’s, and a set with a low starting value of Q. The study also discusses previously obtained gluon distributions consistent with high Et jet cross-sections in the context of this new global analysis. This research paves the way for better understanding particle-particle interactions at different energy scales.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields

title: Heterotic String
abstract: A new type of superstring theory is constructed as a chiral combination of the closed $D=26$ bosonic and $D=10$ fermionic strings. The theory is supersymmetric, Lorentz invariant, and free of tachyons. Consistency requires the gauge group to be $\frac{\mathrm{Spin}(32)}{{Z}_{2}}$ or ${E}_{8}\ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{}{E}_{8}$.
summary:
Paper Title: New Superstring Theory Unveiled, Free of Troublesome Tachyons

The latest work published in Physical Review Letters by David J. Gross, Jeffrey A. Harvey, Emil J. Martinec, and Ryan Rohm presents a groundbreaking superstring theory that combines elements from the 26-dimensional bosonic string and 10-dimensional fermionic strings.

This new theory, situated within the broader field of physics, aims to surpass previous theories by being free of tachyons - unstable particles that have been a persistent challenge in string theory research and superstring theory specifically. The consistency of this novel approach necessitates a gauge group of either $\frac{\mathrm{Spin}(32)}{{Z}_{2}}$ or ${E}_{8}\ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{} {E}_{8}$, paving the way for further exploration into heterotic string theory.
allAuthors: David J. Gross; Jeffrey A. Harvey; Emil J. Martinec; Ryan Rohm
institutions: Princeton University

title: Measurement of Neutrino Oscillation with KamLAND: Evidence of Spectral Distortion
abstract: We present results of a study of neutrino oscillation based on a 766 ton/year exposure of KamLAND to reactor antineutrinos. We observe 258 nu (e) candidate events with energies above 3.4 MeV compared to 365.2+/-23.7 events expected in the absence of neutrino oscillation. Accounting for 17.8+/-7.3 expected background events, the statistical significance for reactor nu (e) disappearance is 99.998%. The observed energy spectrum disagrees with the expected spectral shape in the absence of neutrino oscillation at 99.6% significance and prefers the distortion expected from nu (e) oscillation effects. A two-neutrino oscillation analysis of the KamLAND data gives Deltam(2)=7.9(+0.6)(-0.5)x10(-5) eV(2). A global analysis of data from KamLAND and solar-neutrino experiments yields Deltam(2)=7.9(+0.6)(-0.5)x10(-5) eV(2) and tan((2)theta=0.40(+0.10)(-0.07), the most precise determination to date.
summary:
Headline: Physicists Detect Distortion in Neutrino Oscillation, Providing New Insights on Subatomic Particles

Summary:
A team of international scientists, including participants from institutions such as Stanford University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has found evidence of distortion in neutrino oscillations. Using data from KamLAND, a large-scale detector designed to study reactor antineutrinos, they detected 258 candidate events with energies above 3.4 MeV – significantly less than expected in the absence of neutrino oscillation. This discovery not only lends credence to the existence of neutrino oscillation but also supports a distortion pattern expected from these effects. The study provides some of the most precise determinations to date regarding Delta m² and tan(2theta), crucial parameters that describe how neutrinos change identities as they travel. The findings could potentially reshape our understanding of the behavior of these enigmatic subatomic particles.

title: Resonant leptogenesis
abstract: AI abstract - Leptogenesis as a mechanism for generating the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the universe is investigated, focusing on resonant leptogenesis scenarios within the context of the MAJORANA experiment in particle physics. The study explores the potential implications for neutrino properties and the search for CP violation in the early universe.
summary:
Paper title: "Resonant Leptogenesis: A Step Forward in Understanding Universe's Matter-Antimatter Imbalance"

Summary: In this research published in Nuclear Physics B, authors Apostolos Pilaftsis and Thomas Underwood delve into the concept of 'Leptogenesis', a theory explaining the universe's matter-antimatter asymmetry. Building upon previous work exploring resonant leptogenesis scenarios within the MAJORANA experiment in particle physics, they analyze potential implications for neutrino properties and seek to further evidence for CP violation - a type of symmetry breakage - in the early universe. This study contributes significantly to the ongoing quest for understanding the fundamental forces shaping our cosmos.

title: Nonperturbative QCD simulations with<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mrow><mml:mn>2</mml:mn><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math>flavors of improved staggered quarks
abstract:
Dramatic progress has been made over the last decade in the numerical study
of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) through the use of improved formulations of QCD
on the lattice (improved actions), the development of new algorithms and the
rapid increase in computing power available to lattice gauge theorists. In this
article we describe simulations of full QCD using the improved staggered quark
formalism, ``asqtad'' fermions. These simulations were carried out with two
degenerate flavors of light quarks (up and down) and with one heavier flavor,
the strange quark. Several light quark masses, down to about 3 times the
physical light quark mass, and six lattice spacings have been used. These
enable controlled continuum and chiral extrapolations of many low energy QCD
observables. We review the improved staggered formalism, emphasizing both
advantages and drawbacks. In particular, we review the procedure for removing
unwanted staggered species in the continuum limit. We then describe the asqtad
lattice ensembles created by the MILC Collaboration. All MILC lattice ensembles
are publicly available, and they have been used extensively by a number of
lattice gauge theory groups. We review physics results obtained with them, and
discuss the impact of these results on phenomenology. Topics include the heavy
quark potential, spectrum of light hadrons, quark masses, decay constant of
light and heavy-light pseudoscalar mesons, semileptonic form factors, nucleon
structure, scattering lengths and more. We conclude with a brief look at highly
promising future prospects.
summary:
Headline: Quantum Chromodynamics Simulations Progress With Improved Methods Yielding New Insights on Particle Physics

Summary: A groundbreaking study in the Journal of Reviews of Modern Physics by Alexei Bazavov and colleagues has made significant strides in understanding quantum chromodynamics (QCD), a fundamental theory of particle physics. The researchers employed improved formulations of QCD on the lattice, "improved actions," and developed new algorithms to study full QCD using "asqtad" fermions, which are two-degenerate flavors of light quarks (up and down) and one heavier flavor, the strange quark. This work paves the way for controlled continuum and chiral extrapolations of numerous low energy QCD observables, providing valuable insights into various topics such as the heavy quark potential, light hadron spectra, quark masses, decay constants, semileptonic form factors, nucleon structure, scattering lengths and more. This breakthrough work opens promising avenues for future research.

title: Radiative corrections in the<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">SU</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mn/><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mn>2</mml:mn><mml:mo>)</mml:mo><mml:mn/></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>L</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:msub></mml:mrow><mml:mo>×</mml:mo><mml:mi mathvariant="normal">U</mml:mi><mml:mn/><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mo>)</mml:mo><mml:mn/></mml:math>theory: A simple renormalization framework
abstract: A simple renormalization framework to carry out practical calculations in the $\mathrm{SU}{(2)}_{L}\ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{}\mathrm{U}(1)$ theory is discussed. The basic counterterms associated with the mass matrix of the gauge bosons and their interactions with quarks and leptons are generated and determined in a straightforward manner. They can then be applied, in a systematic fashion, to study the radiative corrections to the various processes of interest: $\ensuremath{\mu}$ decay, $\ensuremath{\beta}$ decay, $\ensuremath{\nu}$-induced reactions, and other leptonic and semileptonic processes. The role played by ${cos\ensuremath{\theta}}_{W}$ is discussed in some detail. Using the results and methods of the current-algebra formulation of radiative corrections, an effective Lagrangian is derived for $\ensuremath{\mu}$ decay in which the contributions of the heavy particles and some of the photonic corrections are reduced to a renormalization factor of the zeroth-order amplitude. This analysis determines the connection between the renormalized constants of the present framework and ${G}_{\ensuremath{\mu}}$. The corrections to the relation ${m}_{W}=\frac{{(\frac{\ensuremath{\pi}\ensuremath{\alpha}}{\sqrt{2}{G}_{\ensuremath{\mu}}})}^{\frac{1}{2}}}{{sin\ensuremath{\theta}}_{W}}$ are discussed. This leads to some relevant observations concerning certain model-dependent hadronic contributions to these corrections and their cancellation in the comparison between charged-current transitions and neutral-current processes occurring at large momentum transfers.
summary: In a groundbreaking contribution to physics, physicist A. Sirlin presents a straightforward renormalization framework for practical calculations in the Standard Model, specifically focusing on $\mathrm{SU}{(2)}_{L}\ifmmode\times\else\texttimes\fi{}\mathrm{U}(1)$ theory. The new method generates and determines basic counterterms associated with gauge boson mass matrices and their interactions with quarks and leptons, allowing for the systematic study of radiative corrections in various processes like muon decay, beta decay, neutrino-induced reactions, and other leptonic and semileptonic processes. The paper discusses the role of ${cos\ensuremath{\theta}}_{W}$ in detail, and the effective Lagrangian for muon decay includes a reduction of heavy particle contributions and some photonic corrections to a renormalization factor of the zeroth-order amplitude. This work elucidates the connection between renormalized constants within this framework and the fundamental constant ${G}_{\mu}$. The study also delves into the corrections to the formula for the mass of the W boson, leading to insightful observations about certain model-dependent hadronic contributions in charged-current and neutral-current processes at high momentum transfers.
journal: Physical review. D. Particles, fields, gravitation, and cosmology/Physical review. D. Particles and fields
allAuthors: A. Sirlin
institutions: Institute for Advanced Study

Subheading: A new review offers clarity on 500 MeV particle's identity

With advanced analysis of experimental data and theoretical models, this study aims to dispel long-standing controversies and bring the sigma meson into clearer focus for researchers around the world. New Study Advances Understanding of Particle Physics Beyond the Standard Model

A new paper published in the Journal of High Energy Physics explores the renormalization group evolution of the Standard Model dimension six operators, focusing on their gauge coupling dependence and associated phenomenology. The study, led by Rodrigo Alonso, Elizabeth Jenkins, Aneesh V Manohar, and Michael Trott, aims to shed light on physics beyond the current understanding of the Standard Model. title: Double beta decay, Majorana neutrinos, and neutrino mass
abstract: The theoretical and experimental issues relevant to neutrinoless double-beta decay are reviewed. The impact that a direct observation of this exotic process would have on elementary particle physics, nuclear physics, astrophysics and cosmology is profound. Now that neutrinos are known to have mass and experiments are becoming more sensitive, even the non-observation of neutrinoless double-beta decay will be useful. If the process is actually observed, we will immediately learn much about the neutrino. The status and discovery potential of proposed experiments are reviewed in this context, with significant emphasis on proposals favored by recent panel reviews. The importance of and challenges in the calculation of nuclear matrix elements that govern the decay are considered in detail. The increasing sensitivity of experiments and improvements in nuclear theory make the future exciting for this field at the interface of nuclear and particle physics.
summary:
Title: A Groundbreaking Review Explores Double Beta Decay and Majorana Neutrinos

In a new research review published in Reviews of Modern Physics, physicists F. T. Avignone, S. R. Elliott, and J. Engel delve into the intriguing concept of neutrinoless double-beta decay. This exotic process, if observed, could have profound implications for elementary particle physics, nuclear physics, astrophysics, and cosmology alike. With neutrinos now confirmed to possess mass, and experimental sensitivity on the rise, both the observation and non-observation of this phenomenon are expected to yield valuable insights. The study examines the latest proposals for neutrinoless double-beta decay experiments and discusses the vital role of nuclear matrix elements in governing the decay process. As the field advances at the intersection of nuclear and particle physics, the researchers highlight key challenges and exciting possibilities that lie ahead in this significant area of research.
allAuthors: F. T. Avignone; S. R. Elliott; J. Engel

abstract: AI abstract - We present an investigation into the behavior of nucleons within the framework of chiral loops in Quantum Chromodynamics, providing insights into the associated amplitudes and their implications for nuclear physics. The study aims to further our understanding of the scalar properties of these systems.
summary:
Headline: "New Study Explores Nucleon Behavior with 'Chiral Loops' in Quantum Physics"

Summary: New research by J. Gasser, M.E. Sainio, and A. Švarc, published in Nuclear Physics B, delves into the behavior of nucleons within the framework of chiral loops in Quantum Chromodynamics. The study aims to shed light on associated amplitudes and their implications for nuclear physics, contributing significantly to our understanding of the scalar properties of these systems.

title: Neutrino mass problem and gauge hierarchy
abstract: AI abstract - We explore the neutrino mass problem and gauge hierarchy in this study, focusing on the interplay between these factors in particle physics. The investigation aims to provide insights into potential solutions for the discrepancy between the observed neutrino masses and the theoretical expectations.
summary:
**New Studies Shed Light on Neutrino Mass Problem and Gauge Hierarchy**

In a new scientific paper published in Physics Letters B, researchers M. Magg and C. Wetterich delve into an intriguing area of particle physics: the neutrino mass problem and gauge hierarchy. The study investigates how these factors interact in the realm of physics, aiming to uncover potential solutions for the pervasive discrepancy between observed neutrino masses and theoretical predictions. This work builds upon years of research exploring neutrinos and their properties, offering further insight into one of particle physics' most compelling mysteries.
