title: Performance of CMS muon reconstruction in pp collision events at√s = 7TeV
abstract: The performance of muon reconstruction, identification, and triggering in CMS has been studied using 40 pb-1 of data collected in pp collisions at s = 7 TeV at the LHC in 2010. A few benchmark sets of selection criteria covering a wide range of physics analysis needs have been examined. For all considered selections, the efficiency to reconstruct and identify a muon with a transverse momentum pT larger than a few GeV/c is above 95% over the whole region of pseudorapidity covered by the CMS muon system, < 2.4, while the probability to misidentify a hadron as a muon is well below 1%. The efficiency to trigger on single muons with pT above a few GeVc is higher than 90% over the full η range, and typically substantially better. The overall momentum scale is measured to a precision of 0.2% with muons from Z decays. The transverse momentum resolution varies from 1% to 6% depending on pseudorapidity for muons with pT below 100GeV/c and, using cosmic rays, it is shown to be better than 10% in the central region up to pT = 1 TeV/c. Observed distributions of all quantities are well reproduced by the Monte Carlo simulation. © 2012 IOP Publishing Ltd and Sissa Medialab srl.
summary:
Study Reveals High-Performance Muon Detection in Particle Physics

A new study published in the Journal of Instrumentation, led by an international team of researchers, presents findings on the efficiency and accuracy of muon reconstruction and identification in proton-proton collisions at 7 TeV. The work, conducted using data collected at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in 2010, demonstrates that the muon system within the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) has high efficiency, exceeding 95%, to reconstruct and identify muons with a transverse momentum exceeding a few GeV/c across the pseudorapidity range of below 2.4.

The study also establishes that the probability of misidentifying a hadron as a muon is kept well below 1%. The trigger efficiency for single muons with pT above several GeV/c exceeds 90% across the full pseudorapidity range, significantly outperforming expectations.

Furthermore, the overall momentum scale of muons is measured with a precision of 0.2%, while the transverse momentum resolution varies from 1% to 6% depending on pseudorapidity for muons with pT below 100 GeV/c. As determined using cosmic rays, the central region shows better than 10% resolution in the transverse momentum up to 1 TeV/c. The observed distributions are found to be well-reproduced by the Monte Carlo simulation.

This robust muon detection system plays a crucial role in ongoing and future high-energy physics research, aiming to further expand our understanding of the subatomic world.

title: Dark Matter Results from 100 Live Days of XENON100 Data
abstract: We present results from the direct search for dark matter with the XENON100 detector, installed underground at the Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso of INFN, Italy. XENON100 is a two-phase time-projection chamber with a 62 kg liquid xenon target. Interaction vertex reconstruction in three dimensions with millimeter precision allows the selection of only the innermost 48 kg as the ultralow background fiducial target. In 100.9 live days of data, acquired between January and June 2010, no evidence for dark matter is found. Three candidate events were observed in the signal region with an expected background of (1.8 ± 0.6) events. This leads to the most stringent limit on dark matter interactions today, excluding spin-independent elastic weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP) nucleon scattering cross sections above 7.0 × 10(-45) cm(2) for a WIMP mass of 50 GeV/c(2) at 90% confidence level.
summary:
**Newsbrief: Scientists Rule Out Most Common Type of Dark Matter Hypothesis**

In a groundbreaking discovery, an international team of researchers, led by E. Aprile, published their findings from the XENON100 experiment in Physical Review Letters. The study, conducted at Italy's Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso, is a significant step towards understanding dark matter using a unique two-phase time-projection chamber filled with over 62 kg of liquid xenon.

The research focused on the Search for Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs), one of the leading theories about the invisible matter that constitutes approximately 85% of the universe's mass. Despite observing three candidate events, the team could not find evidence confirming the existence of dark matter, as the observed occurrences were significantly fewer than expected.

The study presents the most stringent limit yet on WIMP-nucleon interaction cross sections, ruling out values higher than 7.0 x 10⁻⁴⁵ cm² for a WIMP mass of 50 GeV/c². The team's innovative approach, including employing millimeter-precision three-dimensional interaction vertex reconstruction, is set to further refine our understanding of the elusive dark matter.

title: Echoes of a hidden valley at hadron colliders
abstract: AI abstract - This study explores the potential echoes of a hidden valley in the collision data from Tevatron and Large Hadron Collider experiments, suggesting implications for the discovery of new physics beyond the Standard Model, particularly in relation to the Higgs boson sector.
summary:
New Research Sheds Light on potential "Hidden Valleys" at Particle Physics Experiments

A groundbreaking study by Matthew J. Strassler and Kathryn M. Zurek, published in Physics Letters B, is delving into fascinating possibilities within particle physics experiments at Tevatron and Large Hadron Collider facilities. They propose that unseen areas, known as "Hidden Valleys," could be influencing the collision data involving the Higgs boson, potentially guiding discoveries of new physics beyond our current understanding captured in the Standard Model.
allAuthors: Matthew J. Strassler; Kathryn M. Zurek
institutions: University of Washington; University of Wisconsin–Madison
